title: Intro to limits
description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Limits from tables
description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: One-sided limits from tables
description: Sal finds the one-sided limit of x²/(1-cosx) as x approaches zero from the right, using a table of values.

title: One-sided limits from graphs
description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: 1-sided vs. 2-sided limits (algebraic)
description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point, using an algebraic example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: 1-sided vs. 2-sided limits (more examples)
description: Sal analyzes various 1- and 2-sided limits of a function given graphically.

title: Finding limits by factoring
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Limit properties
description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Finding limits by factoring (cubic)
description: Sal finds the limit of (x³-1)/(x²-1) at x=1 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Mean absolute deviation (MAD)
description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) of a data set is the average distance between each data value and the mean. Mean absolute deviation is a way to describe variation in a data set. Mean absolute deviation helps us get a sense of how "spread out" the values in a data set are.

title: Mean absolute deviation example
description: Sal finds the mean absolute deviation of a data set that's given in a bar chart.

title: Finding area by rearranging parts
description: Sometimes it helps to rearrange the parts of geometric figures to find the area. That's what we're going to do here.

title: Area of composite shapes
description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Components of vectors
description: Sal finds the x and y-components of a vector given its graph.

title: Components of vectors (example 2)
description: Sal figures out which vectors have the same x-component given the graphs of 4 different vectors.

title: Converting percents to decimals: 59.2%
description: Decimals can be written in percent form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So, we multiply the decimal by 100 to get an equivalent percent. Then, we add a percent sign (%). For example, 0.8 can be converted to percent form by solving 0.8✕100. So, 0.8=80%. Another way to think of multiplying by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the right.

title: Converting percents to decimals: 113.9%
description: Sal converts 113.9% to a decimal by demonstrating how to move the decimal point

title: Converting percents to decimals & fractions example
description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.

title: Intro to theoretical probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Intuitive sense of probabilities
description: Think about what probabilities really mean. What does a probability of 0 mean? How about 1?

title: Comparing rational numbers
description: Comparing Rational Numbers

title: Age word problem: Imran
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Age word problem: Ben & William
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago, William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?

title: Age word problem: Arman & Diya
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?

title: Triangle inequality theorem
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: The Seven Years' War: background and combatants
description: The Seven Years' War (known in North America as the French and Indian War) was the first truly global war, in which the British and the French competed to be the world's foremost imperial power. In this video, Kim discusses the background to the conflict and what each combatant wished to achieve.

title: The Seven Years' War: battles and legacy
description: The first years of the Seven Years' War didn't go well for the British (even though 22 year old George Washington was in command!). Then they decided to spend a lot of money on winning the war -- and they succeeded! The only problem was how to pay back their debt . . . maybe some new taxes on the American colonists?

title: Comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers
description: Worked examples comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers

title: Comparing fractions 1 (unlike denominators)
description: Sal compares fractions by finding a common denominator.

title: Comparing fractions 2 (unlike denominators)
description: Sal compares fractions by finding a common denominator.

title: Shell method for rotating around vertical line
description: Introducing the shell method for rotation around a vertical line.

title: Evaluating integral for shell method example
description: Evaluating the definite integral set up using the shell method

title: Shell method for rotating around horizontal line
description: Find the volume of a solid of revolution by rotating around the x-axis using the shell method

title: Shell method with two functions of x
description: Using the shell method to rotate around a vertical line.

title: Calculating integral with shell method
description: Evaluating integral set up with shell method for two functions.

title: Shell method with two functions of y
description: Stepping it up a notch, our solid is now defined in terms of two separate functions.

title: Part 2 of shell method with 2 functions of y
Compound inequalities: OR
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.

title: Compound inequalities: OR
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.

title: Compound inequalities: AND
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 3y+7<2y AND 4y+8>-48.

title: A compound inequality with no solution
description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5x-3<12 AND 4x+1>25, only to realize there's no x-value that makes both inequalities true.

title: Terms, factors, & coefficients
description: This video explains what the words term, factor, and coefficient mean. Think of an expression as a sentence. A sentence has parts, and so does an algebraic expression.

title: Representing linear systems with matrix equations
description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the variable vector, and b is the constant vector.

title: Find measure of vertical angles
description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles, watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.

title: Find measure of angles word problem
description: Solve this word problem to find the measure of angles. In this example you'll split up a pie (don't forget to share!)

title: Equation practice with supplementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Equation practice with complementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Intro to logarithm properties (1 of 2)
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for addition and subtraction of logarithms.

title: Intro to logarithm properties (2 of 2)
description: Sal introduces the logarithm identities for multiplication of logarithm by a constant, and the change of base rule.

title: Using the logarithmic product rule
description: Sal rewrites log₃(27x) as log₃(27)+log_3(x), which is simplified as 3+log₃(x).

title: Using the logarithmic power rule
description: Sal rewrites log₅(x³) as 3log₅(x).

title: Simplifying rational expressions: common binomial factors
description: Given a rectangle with length a²+6a+27 and width a²-9, Sal writes the ratio of the width to the length as a simplified rational expression.

title: Simplifying rational expressions: opposite common binomial factors
description: Sal simplifies and states the domain of (x^2-36)/(6-x).

title: Negative exponents
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Negative exponent intuition
description: Intuition on why a^-b = 1/(a^b) (and why a^0 =1)

title: Intro to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: Evaluating logarithms (advanced)
description: Sal evaluates log₂(8), log₈(2), log₂(⅛), and log₈(½).

title: Using the logarithm change of base rule
description: Sal rewrites logarithmic expressions like 1/(logₐ4) or logₐ(16)*log₂(a) using the change of base rule.

title: Coordinate plane: graphing points
description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Coordinate plane graphing word problem
description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

title: Multi-digit division strategies for decimals
description: Sal uses understanding of place value, expanded form, and fractions to help divide with decimals.

title: Division strategies for decimal quotients
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value and fractions to introduce dividing with decimals.

title: Review of trig angle addition identities
description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b), sin(a-c), cos(a+b), cos(a-b), cos(2a), and sin(2a).

title: Using the cosine angle addition identity
description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine angle addition formula.

title: Using the cosine double-angle identity
description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this, he must use the cosine double-angle formula.

title: Linear models word problem: book
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Linear models word problem: marbles
description: Sal solves a word problem about a person filling a glass tank with marbles, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Rounding to nearest 10
description: Learn to use a number line to round 2-digit numbers to the nearest ten.

title: Rounding to nearest 100
description: Learn to use a number line to round 3-digit numbers to the nearest hundred.

title: Rounding to nearest 10 and 100
description: Learn to round up to 4-digit numbers to the nearest ten and hundred.

title: Worked example: equation from slope field
description: Given a slope field and a few differential equations, we can determine which equation corresponds to the slope field by considering specific slopes.

title: Worked example: slope field from equation
description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we match an equation to its slope field by considering the various slopes in the diagram.

title: Worked example: forming a slope field
description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we determine the slopes of a few segments in the slope field of an equation.

title: Zeros of polynomials & their graphs
description: Sal uses the zeros of y=x^3+3x^2+x+3 to determine its corresponding graph.

title: Two-way relative frequency tables
description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: Visually converting tenths and hundredths
description: Sal rewrites 8/10 with a denominator of 100.

title: Instantaneous speed and velocity
description: Instantaneous speed and velocity looks at really small displacements over really small periods of time

title: Position vs. time graphs
description: Learn how to read a position vs. time graph. He then explains how to use the graph to determine the following quantities: displacement, distance, average velocity, average speed, instantaneous velocity, and instantaneous speed.

title: Solutions to 2-variable equations
description: The solution of an equation with one variable is a number. How does the solution of a 2-variable equation look like? Well, it is an ordered pair. Learn more about it and how to test solutions to 2-variable equations.

title: Worked example: solutions to 2-variable equations
description: How do you check if an ordered pair is a solution to a given equation? You need to plug in the numbers and see what equality results. Watch this video to see a worked example.

title: Equation practice with segment addition
description: Given information about the lengths of line segments, Sal forms and solves an equation in order to find the lengths of the segments.

title: The idea of division
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Intro to remainders
description: Sal shows how a remainder is what's left over in a division problem.

title: Worked example: Long division with remainders: 3771÷8
description: Learn to divide 3771÷8 with long division.

title: Worked example: Long division with remainders: 2292÷4
description: Learn to divide 2292÷4 and 1,735,092÷3 with long division.

title: Intro to long division (remainders)
description: Introduction to long division with remainders

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

title: One-step subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54

title: Simple equations: examples solving a variety of forms
description: Some quick examples to practice solving a variety of one step equations. All 4 operations (add, subtract, multiple, divide) are paired with variables.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: Converting metric units of length
description: Learn convert kilometers, meters, and centimeters.

title: Rates & proportional relationships example
description: Sal compares a rate given in an equation to a rate shown on a graph.

title: Rates & proportional relationships: gas mileage
description: Sal chooses equations that give a faster rate than the relationship given in a table.

title: Balancing chemical equations
description: How to balance a chemical reaction by making sure you have the same number of atoms of each element on both sides.

title: Balancing more complex chemical equations
description: Example of balancing the combustion reaction of ethylene, C₂H₄. Some tips on how to balance more complicated reactions.

title: Visually understanding balancing chemical equations
description: Relating the balanced chemical equation to the structural formulas of the reactants and products.

title: Balancing another combustion reaction
description: Balancing the combustion reaction of ethane, C₂H₆

title: Balancing chemical equation with substitution
description: Using the substitution method to balance a reaction where a reactant and product have a polyatomic ion in common.

title: Differentiating composite functions 1
description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=cos³x using the chain rule.

title: Differentiating composite functions 2
description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=ln(√x) using the chain rule.

title: Differentiating composite functions 3
description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=√(3x²-x) using the chain rule.

title: Dividing polynomials with remainders
description: Sal divides (x^3+5x-4) by (x^2-x+1) using long division.

title: Intro to long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Strategies for subtracting more complex decimals with tenths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals to the tenths place, such as 2-1.2.

title: Strategies for subtracting basic decimals
description: Sal uses place value and a number line to subtract decimals, such as 1.5-0.7.

title: Properties and patterns for multiplication
description: Sal changes the order of numbers or decomposes numbers to simplify multiplication problems.

title: Writing two-variable inequalities word problem
description: Sal solves a word problem about scores in a chess tournament by creating a two-variable linear inequality.

title: Solving two-variable inequalities word problem
description: Given a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about watering plants, Sal finds how many flowers can be watered.

title: Graphs of two-variable inequalities word problem
description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about dog biscuits, Sal finds if the dog can get enough biscuits.

title: Unknowns with multiplication and division
description: Sal finds the missing number in multiplication and division equations.

title: Equations with parentheses
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

title: Meet the preposition
description: Prepositions help show us where things are in space and time.

title: DNA cloning and recombinant DNA
description: Introduction to DNA cloning

title: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
description: Introduction to PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

title: Gel electrophoresis
description: Introduction to gel electrophoresis. How it's used to separate DNA fragments or other macromoleculs.

title: Rounding to nearest 10
description: Learn to use a number line to round 2-digit numbers to the nearest ten.

title: Rounding to nearest 100
description: Learn to use a number line to round 3-digit numbers to the nearest hundred.

title: Rounding to nearest 10 and 100
description: Learn to round up to 4-digit numbers to the nearest ten and hundred.

title: Classifying triangles
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Worked example: Classifying triangles
description: Work through sample problems categorizing triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Classifying triangles by angles
description: You say you can't categorize a triangle because you don't know the length of the sides. Guess what? If you know the size of the angles you can!

title: Definite integral properties (algebraic): function combination
description: Given the definite integrals of f and g over a specific interval, Sal finds the definite integral (on that interval) of a combination of f and g.

title: Definite integral properties (algebraic): breaking interval
description: Given the definite integral of f over two intervals, Sal finds the definite integral of f over another, related, interval.

title: Linking function of the colon
description: KA grammarian Paige introduces an important piece of punctuation that helps link items in a sentence: the colon!

title: The colon as a separator
description: The colon can separate parts of a title, citations of religious texts, and the hour and minutes in the time of day. Paige explains how!

title: Counting outcomes: flower pots
description: Find the number of ways you can put four types of flowers into three types of pots.

title: Count outcomes using tree diagram
description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Position vs. time graphs
description: Learn how to read a position vs. time graph. He then explains how to use the graph to determine the following quantities: displacement, distance, average velocity, average speed, instantaneous velocity, and instantaneous speed.

title: Calculating average velocity or speed
description: Although speed and velocity are often words used interchangeably, in physics, they are distinct concepts. Speed is calculated by dividing the distance traveled by time. It does not have direction. Average velocity is the displacement (change in position) divided by time.

title: Exponent properties with quotients
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Average value over a closed interval
description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Calculating average value of function over interval
description: Here we find the average value of x^2+1 on the interval between 0 and 3.

title: Average acceleration over interval
description: As an example of finding a mean value, we find an average acceleration.

title: Mean value theorem for integrals
description: Here Sal goes through the connection between the mean value theorem and integration.

title: Obtaining a function from an equation
description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. In this video, we obtain a function from an equation. The function represents the same relationship between the quantities in the equation.

title: Continuity introduction
description: Sal introduces a formal definition of continuity at a point using limits.

title: Discontinuity points challenge example
description: Based on out definition of continuity, we can see the relationship between points of discontinuity and two-sided limits.

title: Removing discontinuities (factoring)
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Infinite limits intro
description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0, and as x approaches infinity.

title: Visually determining vertical asymptotes (old)
description: An old video where Sal identifies all the vertical asymptotes of a function given graphically.

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions (example)
description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10).

title: Squeeze theorem intro
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Using the squeeze theorem
description: An example applying the squeeze theorem.

title: Measuring angles using a protractor
description: Learn to use a virtual protractor to measure angles.

title: Measuring angles in degrees
description: Learn how to measure an angle with a protractor.

title: Angles: introduction
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Measuring angles using a protractor 2
description: Sal measures several angles with a protractor.

title: Drawing parallel line segments
description: Sal draws parallel line segments with given points.

title: Lines, line segments, & rays
description: Learn the difference between lines, line segments, and rays.

title: Relative pronouns
description: We use the relative pronouns to connect clauses together, like "the man *who sold the world* is coming over for dinner." David, KA's Grammar Fellow, explains.

title: Vector components from magnitude & direction
description: Sal finds the components of a couple of vectors given in magnitude and direction form.

title: Area of a triangle
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Variables, expressions, & equations
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Testing solutions to equations
description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: Worked example: relative maxima and minima
description: Sal gives multiple examples where he identifies relative maximum points, relative minimum points, absolute maximum points, and absolute minimum points.

title: Graphs of rational functions: y-intercept
description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(ax^m+bx+12)/(cx^m+dx+12) based on its y-intercept.

title: Graphs of rational functions: horizontal asymptote
description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(-x²+ax+b)/(x²+cx+d) based on its horizontal asymptote.

title: Graphs of rational functions: vertical asymptotes
description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=g(x)/(x²-x-6) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its discontinuities.

title: Graphs of rational functions: zeros
description: Sal picks the graph that matches f(x)=(2x²-18)/g(x) (where g(x) is a polynomial) based on its zeros.

title: Subtracting 1, 10, or 100
description: Sal subtracts 1, 10, or 100 from a number.

title: Intro to quadrilaterals
description: Sal discovers attributes and features of four-sided shapes, including parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.

title: Multiplying in scientific notation example
description: Learn how to solve a multiplication problem using scientific notation: (9.1 * 10^6)(3.2 * 10^-5)

title: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation
description: Learn how to simplify a multiplication and division expression using scientific notation. The expression in this problem is (7 * 10^5) / ((2 * 10^-2)(2.5 * 10^9)).

title: Scientific notation word problem: speed of light
description: Amazingly, we can figure out how far the sun is from the earth if we know how to multiply numbers in scientific notation.

title: Multiplying three numbers in scientific notation
description: Multiplying really big or really small numbers is much easier when using scientific notation. This video gives an example of multiplying three numbers that are written in scientific notation.

title: Scientific notation word problem: U.S. national debt
description: Ever wonder what your part of the national debt is? It might surprise you. What isn't surprising is that you can use scientific notation and division to figure out the answer.

title: Comparing rational numbers
description: Comparing Rational Numbers

title: Worked example: Converting a fraction (7/8) to a decimal
description: Learn how to write the fraction, 7/8 as a decimal.

title: Area of a parallelogram
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Caravaggio, Calling of Saint Matthew and Inspiration of St. Matthew
description: Caravaggio, Calling of St. Matthew and Inspiration of St. Matthew, oil on canvas, c. 1599-1600 (Contarelli Chapel, San Luigi dei Francesi, Rome)

title: Function as a geometric series
description: Expressions of the form a/(1-r) represent the infinite sum of a geometric series whose initial term is a and constant ratio is r, which is written as Σa(r)ⁿ. Since geometric series are a class of power series, we obtained the power series representation of a/(1-r) very quickly.

title: Limits by direct substitution
description: Sal explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

title: Undefined limits by direct substitution
description: Sal gives an example of a limit where direct substitution ends in a quotient with 0 in the denominator and non-0 in the numerator. Such limits are undefined. What about limits where substitution ends in 0/0? Keep going and you'll see!

title: Concrete and abstract nouns
description: A concrete noun refers to a physical object in the real world, such as a dog, a ball, or an ice cream cone. An abstract noun refers to an idea or concept that does not exist in the real world and cannot be touched, like freedom, sadness, or permission.

title: Subtraction word problem: snow
description: Sal solves a subtraction word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Subtraction word problem: crayons
description: Sal solves a subtraction word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Area under rate function
description: If you have a function representing rate, what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Total water in a tub
description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

title: Graphing quadratics in factored form
description: An example for a quadratic function in factored form is y=½(x-6)(x+2). We can analyze this form to find the x-intercepts of the graph, as well as find the vertex.

title: Area of a circle
description: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared (A = π r²). Learn how to use this formula to find the area of a circle when given the diameter.

title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Intro to end behavior of polynomials
description: Sal explains what "end behavior" is and what affects the end behavior of polynomial functions.

title: End behavior of functions & their graphs
description: Sal picks a function that has a given end behavior based on its graph.

title: Combining like terms challenge problem
description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.

title: Related rates: Approaching cars
description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads, how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Related rates: Falling ladder
description: You're on a ladder.  The bottom of the ladder starts slipping away from the wall.  Amidst your fright, you realize this would make a great related rates problem...

title: Partial fraction expansion to evaluate integral
description: When you are integrating a function in the form of a fraction, it helps to find a way to break apart the expression.

title: Dividing expressions to evaluate integral
description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Trapezoidal Riemann approximations
description: Estimating the area under a curve with trapazoids instead of rectangles can give a closer approximation.

title: Trapezoidal approximation of area under curve
description: Another example of trapazoidal approximation

title: Fluid mosaic model of cell membranes
description: The fluid mosaic model describes the cell membrane as a tapestry of several types of molecules (phospholipids, cholesterols, and proteins) that are constantly moving. This movement helps the cell membrane maintain its role as a barrier between the inside and outside of the cell environments.

title: Diffusion - Introduction
description: Learn about how particles move from an area of greater concentration to an area of lesser concentration through the process of diffusion.

title: Concentration gradients
description: A concentration gradient occurs when the concentration of particles is higher in one area than another. In passive transport, particles will diffuse down a concentration gradient, from areas of higher concentration to areas of lower concentration, until they are evenly spaced.

title: Osmosis
description: Osmosis of water from an area of lower to an area of higher solute concentration across a semipermeable membrane.

title: Hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic solutions (tonicity)
description: Hypotonic, isotonic and hypertonic solutions (tonicity). Seeing the effect of various types of solution on the direction of osmosis.

title: Finding a sinusoidal function from its graph
description: Sal determines a function of the form y=a*sin(bx) or y=a*cos(bx) based on the graph of the function.

title: Fractions on a number line
description: Learn to graph and locate fractions on a number line.

title: Representing 1 as a fraction
description: Sal uses fraction models and a number line to represent 1 as a fraction.

title: Limits of composite functions
description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of a function that is a composition of the two functions.

title: The Monroe Doctrine
description: KA's US history fellow Kim discusses the Monroe Doctine.

title: The Market Revolution - textile mills and the cotton gin
description: The Market Revolution of the early nineteenth century changed the way Americans worked and did business. In this video, Kim discusses the inventions that brought new productivity and forms of work to American business - the Industrial Revolution.

title: The Market Revolution -  communication and transportation
description: Canals, railroads, steamboats, telegraphs! Kim talks about the transportation and communication revolutions of the early 19th century and how they changed American business.

title: The Market Revolution -  impact and significance
description: So what's the big deal about the Market Revolution, anyway? Kim describes how it changed the nature of American labor, markets, and culture.

title: Systems of equations with elimination (and manipulation)
description: In some cases, we need to slightly manipulate a system of equations before we can solve it using the elimination method. So how it's done in this video.

title: Example: Evaluating expressions with 2 variables
description: Evaluating Expressions with Two Variables

title: Equations with one rational expression (advanced)
description: Sal solves the following equation by first simplifying the rational expression: x^2-(x^2-4)/(x-2)=4.

title: Equations with one rational expression
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of geometric sequences
description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.

title: Negative signs in fractions
description: Sal finds equivalent expressions to -g/h.

title: Apoptosis
description: How apoptosis is different from cell death by injury. Role in development and body maintenance.

title: Photoperiodism
description: How plants can regulate processes like flowering based on day length (photoperiod).

title: Density word problem: blimp
description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry, using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers visually
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers 2
description: Sal relates mixed numbers to whole number/fraction multiplication problem.

title: More on equivalent fractions
description: Sal uses fraction models and multiplication to find equivalent fractions.

title: Salutations and valedictions
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, talk about how to address and sign off on letters using commas!

title: Commas in space and time
description: Learn how to use commas when writing addresses (in space) and dates (in time).

title: Comparing decimals: 9.97 and 9.798
description: Sal compares 9.97 and 9.798 using place value.

title: Ordering decimals 1
description: Sal orders 5 decimals from least to greatest.

title: Write decimal in expanded form
description: Learn to write 905.074 in expanded form.

title: Decimals in written form (thousandths)
description: Learn to write 20,000.507 using words.

title: Two-step equation word problem: oranges
description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video, we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41,790.

title: Two-step equation word problem: garden
description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!

title: Performing dilations
description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Determining dilations
description: Sal shows how we can use dilations to map a line into another, parallel, line.

title: Integrating power series
description: Within its interval of convergence, the integral of a power series is the sum of integrals of individual terms: ∫Σf(x)dx=Σ∫f(x)dx. See how this is used to find the integral of a power series.

title: Differentiating power series
description: Within its interval of convergence, the derivative of a power series is the sum of derivatives of individual terms: [Σf(x)]'=Σf'(x). See how this is used to find the derivative of a power series.

title: Dividing fractions: 3/5 ÷ 1/2
description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions are to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next, multiply the two numerators. Then, multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the fractions if needed.

title: DNA replication and RNA transcription and translation
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Interphase
description: Interphase of the cell cycle, including G₁, S, and G₂ phases. How the cell replicates its DNA before mitosis.

title: Mitosis
description: Mitosis is how cells divide! Learn what happens in all the phases of mitosis: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.

title: Phases of meiosis I
description: How homologous chromosomes separate into two sets. Prophase I, metaphase I, anaphase I, and telophase I.

title: Phases of meiosis II
description: How sister chromatids separate to form gametes. Prophase II, metaphase II, anaphase II, telophase II.

title: Introduction to heredity
description: Heredity and Classical Genetics. Dominant and recessive traits. Heterozygous and homozygous genotypes.

title: Sex-linked traits
description: Sex-linked traits are associated with genes found on sex chromosomes. In humans, the sex chromosomes are X and Y. Because the X-chromosome is larger, X-linked traits are more common than Y-linked traits. An example of a sex-linked trait is red-green colorblindness, which is carried on the X-chromosome. Because males only have one X-chromosome, they have a higher chance of having red-green colorblindness.

title: Silicon-based life
description: Could silicon play a role similar to carbon's in supporting life?

title: Carbon as a building block of life
description: Carbon as a building block of life.

title: Isomers
description: Structural isomers, stereoisomers, geometric isomers, cis-trans isomers, and enantiomers.

title: Functional groups
description: An overview of some common functional groups

title: Hydrocarbon overview
description: Hydrocarbon overview.

title: Representing structures of organic molecules
description: Representing structures of organic molecules using line (or line-angle) diagrams.

title: Strategies for subtracting more complex decimals with tenths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals to the tenths place, such as 2-1.2.

title: Strategies for subtracting basic decimals
description: Sal uses place value and a number line to subtract decimals, such as 1.5-0.7.

title: Indefinite integrals of x raised to a power
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Introduction to the possessive
description: Apostrophes can help show when something belongs to someone. Paige and David explain how!

title: Possession for words ending in “s”
description: Do words that end in "s" still need _'s_ to show possession? David and Paige explain!

title: Example: Correlation coefficient intuition
description: Sal explains the intuition behind correlation coefficients and does a problem where he matches correlation coefficients to scatter plots.

title: Ellipse standard equation from graph
description: Given an ellipse on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1.

title: Ellipse graph from standard equation
description: Given the standard equation of an ellipse, Sal finds the graph of the ellipse.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem example
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

title: Multiplying whole numbers by 10
description: Lindsay finds a pattern from multiplying whole numbers by 10.

title: Creating a histogram
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Interpreting a histogram
description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms, which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.

title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)
description: Sal factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b) (example 2)
description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-10) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).

title: More examples of factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)
description: Can't get enough of Sal factoring simple quadratics? Here's a handful of examples just for you!

title: Negative decimals on the number line
description: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.

title: Absolute minima & maxima (entire domain)
description: Sal analyzes the absolute minimum and maximum points of g(x)=x²ln(x) over its entire domain.

title: Euler's method
description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
description: Learn how to solve equations that involve decimals and fractions. The equations shown in this video are called "two-step" equations because they each take two steps to solve.

title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
description: Let's practice some two step equations, some of which require merging terms and using the distributive property.

title: Comparing models to fit data example
description: Sal determines if a quadratic or exponential model fits the data better, then uses the model to make a prediction.

title: Intro to order of operations
description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Order of operations example
description: The order of operations tells us the order to solve steps in expressions with more than one operation. First, we solve any operations inside of parentheses or brackets. Second, we solve any exponents. Third, we solve all multiplication and division from left to right. Fourth, we solve all addition and subtraction from left to right.

title: Worked example: Order of operations (PEMDAS)
description: Work through a challenging order of operations example with only positive numbers.

title: Order of operations example
description: Simplify this tricky expression using the order of operations.   Expression include negative numbers and exponents.

title: Limits from graphs: function undefined
description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits from graphs: point discontinuity
description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function's value at the limit is different from the limit's value, but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits from graphs: asymptote
description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function has an asymptote at the limiting value. This means the limit doesn't exist.

title: Quadratic word problem: mosquitoes
description: Sal analyzes the conditions for the maximum possible number of mosquitoes in New York City, which is given as a quadratic function.

title: Rectilinear motion example: speeding up
description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Rectilinear motion example: maximum acceleration
description: The speed of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by v(t)=-t³+6t²+2t. Sal analyzes it to find the time when the particle's acceleration attains its maximum value.

title: Performing translations
description: Sal shows how to perform a translation on a triangle using our interactive widget!

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Derivative of eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ)
description: Sal differentiates eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ) by applying both the product rule and the chain rule.

title: Derivative of sin(ln(x²))
description: Sal differentiates sin(ln(x²)) by applying the chain rule twice.

title: Linear functions word problem: fuel
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear functions word problem: pool
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a pool being filled with water, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Removing discontinuities (factoring)
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Removing discontinuities (rationalization)
description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(√(x+4)-3)/(x-5) should have at x=5 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Domain of a radical function
description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).

title: Worked example: domain of algebraic functions
description: Many examples of determining the domains of functions according to mathematical limitations.

title: Number of solutions to a system of equations
description: Sal is given three lines on the coordinate plane, and identifies one system of two lines that has a single solution, and one system that has no solution.

title: Number of solutions to a system of equations graphically
description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Performing dilations
description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions: trig
description: Sal finds the limit of cosx/(x²-1) at infinity, by putting it between two limits of rational functions, 1/(x²-1) and -1/(x²-1).

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions: trig (limit undefined)
description: Sal analyzes the limit of (x²+1)/sin(x) at infinity. It turns out this limit doesn't exist, as the function keeps oscillating between positive and negative infinity.

title: Points of inflection given the function (graphical)
description: Sal analyzes the graph of a function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Points of inflection given the derivative (graphical)
description: Sal analyzes the graph of a the derivative g' of function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Finding decreasing interval given the function
description: Sal finds the intervals where the function f(x)=x⁶-3x⁵ is decreasing by finding where f' is negative.

title: Finding increasing interval given the derivative
description: Sal is given that the derivative of function g, is g'(x)=x²/(x-2)³. He uses that to find the intervals where g is increasing, by looking for the intervals where g' is positive.

title: Unbounded limits: algebraic (rational)
description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=-1/(x-1)² around its asymptote at x=1.

title: Unbounded limits: algebraic (cosine)
description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=x/[1-cos(x-2)] around its asymptote at x=2.

title: Justification for the arc length formula
description: A non-rigorous justification of the arc length formula

title: Arc length integration example
description: A finely tuned example demonstrating how the arc length formula works.

title: Another arc length integration example
description: More arc length practice.

title: Linear functions word problem: iceberg
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a melting iceberg, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

title: Linear functions word problem: paint
description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a person painting his room, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

title: Differentiating composite exponential functions
description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Composite exponential function differentiation example
description: Sal differentiates the composite exponential function [ln(x)]ˣ and evaluates the derivative at x=e. Composite exponential functions are functions where the variable is in both the base and the exponent.

title: Writing equations of perpendicular lines
description: Given line A and point P, Sal finds the equation of the line perpendicular to A that passes through P.

title: Writing equations of perpendicular lines (example 2)
description: Sal finds the equation of a line perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form that passes through a specific point.

title: Limit of piecewise function: limit exists
description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case, the two one-sided limits are equal, so the limit exists.

title: Limit of piecewise function: limit doesn't exist
description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case, the two one-sided limits aren't equal, so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Appropriate statistical study example
description: Sal determines if a statistical study was a sample study, an experiment, or an observational study.

title: Correlation and causality
description: Understanding why correlation does not imply causality (even though many in the press and some researchers often imply otherwise)

title: Dilating shapes: shrinking
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the triangle under a dilation with scale factor 1/2 about the origin.

title: Dilating shapes: expanding
description: Sal is given a rectangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the rectangle under a dilation with scale factor 1 2/3 about an arbitrary point.

title: Intro to matrix multiplication
description: Sal explains what it means to multiply two matrices, and gives an example.

title: Multiplying matrices
description: Sal gives an example of a multiplication of two matrices that don't have the same dimensions.

title: Simple hypothesis testing
description: Sal walks through an example about who should do the dishes that gets at the idea behind hypothesis testing.

title: Developing strategies for multiplying 2-digit decimals
description: Sal uses place value and equivalent mixed numbers to multiply decimals.

title: Developing strategies for multiplying decimals
description: Sal uses place value and equivalent fractions to multiply decimals.

title: Multiplying decimals: place value
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Solving unit rate problem
description: Jayda takes 3 hours to deliver newspapers on her route. What is the rate per hour at which she delivers the newspapers?

title: Solving unit price problem
description: Miranda's Maid Service charges \$280 to clean 8 offices. What is the company's price for cleaning a single office?

title: Intro to rates
description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.

title: Intro to proportional relationships
description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

title: Proportional relationships: spaghetti
description: Given a table of ratios, watch as we test them for equivalence and determine whether the relationship is proportional.

title: Is side length & perimeter proportional?
description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and perimeter.

title: Is side length & area proportional?
description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and area.

title: Proportional relationships: movie tickets
description: When going to the movies, is the price you pay proportional to the number of tickets you buy?

title: Proportional relationships: bananas
description: A proportionality problem about eating bananas

title: Derivative & the direction of a function
description: Sal analyzes various graphs to find intervals where the derivative of the graphed function is positive or negative.

title: Relative minima & maxima example
description: Sal finds the relative maximum point of g(x)=x⁴-x⁵ by analyzing the intervals where its derivative, g', is negative or positive.

title: Area between curves
description: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

title: Quotient rule example
description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=2x³, Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)/g(x) at x=-1.

title: Points of inflection (algebraic)
description: Sal analyzes the points of inflection of g(x)=¼x⁴-4x³+24x² by looking for values where the second derivative g'' changes signs.

title: Derivative as a limit: numerical
description: Sal relates the derivative of a function and the average rate of change of the function over intervals that become infinitely small.

title: Differentiating polynomials example
description: Sal differentiates f(x)=x⁵+2x³-x², and evaluates the derivative at x=2.

title: Fractional powers differentiation
description: Sal differentiates h(x)=5x^¼+7, and evaluates the derivative at x=16. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Finding limits by factoring
description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Trig functions differentiation
description: Sal differentiates sec(3π/2-x) and evaluates the derivative at x=π/4.

title: Analyzing concavity (algebraic)
description: Sal finds the intervals where g(x)=-x⁴+6x²-2x-3 is concave down/up by finding where its second derivative, g'', is positive/negative.

title: Logarithmic functions differentiation intro
description: Sal finds the derivative of logₐx (for any positive base a≠1) using the derivative of ln(x) and the logarithm change of base rule. He then differentiates log₇x and -3log_π(x).

title: Sine & cosine differentiation
description: Sal differentiates g(x)=7sin(x)-3cos(x)-(π/∛x)². This can be done using the derivatives of sine and cosine, and the Power rule.

title: Second derivatives (vector-valued functions)
description: Sal finds the first and the second derivatives of the vector-valued function h(t)=(-t⁵-6,4t⁴+2t+1).

title: Rotating shapes: center ≠ (0,0)
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about an arbitrary point, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Derivative as slope of tangent line
description: Sal solves a couple of problems where the key to the solution is using the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point.

title: Derivative as slope of curve
description: Sal solves a couple of problems where he interprets the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the curve, or of the line tangent to the curve, at that point.

title: Writing expressions word problems
description: Learn how to write expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Inequality word problems
description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

title: Example: Evaluating expressions with 2 variables
description: Evaluating Expressions with Two Variables

title: Writing basic expressions word problems
description: Learn how to write basic expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Greater than and less than symbols
description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So, 9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are > (greater than or equal to) and < (less than or equal to).

title: Inequality word problem: one variable
description: This time we're creating a variable to represent a number, and then writing an inequality. We're building on our knowledge.

title: Plotting an inequality example
description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: One-step subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54

title: Constructing numerical expressions
description: Sal solves a word problem by constructing a numerical expression.

title: One-step multiplication equations
description: Remember that what you do to one side, you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction, x/a? Let's do it together.

title: Simple equations: examples solving a variety of forms
description: Some quick examples to practice solving a variety of one step equations. All 4 operations (add, subtract, multiple, divide) are paired with variables.

title: Translating expressions with parentheses
description: Sal interprets written statements and writes them as mathematical expressions.

title: Evaluating an expression with one variable
description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Plotting inequalities
description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (> or <), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Evaluating expressions with two variables
description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?

title: Writing expressions with variables
description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: One-step division equations
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: Testing solutions to equations
description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: Comparing whole numbers
description: Sal compares 394 and 397.

title: Expression value intuition
description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x, 5/x + 5, and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Modeling with one-step equations
description: Learn how to write basic equations to model real-world situations.

title: Evaluating expressions with & without parentheses
description: Sal evaluates an expression with and without parentheses

title: Evaluating expressions with variables: exponents
description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents, specifically, are our focus here.

title: Evaluating exponential expressions 2
description: Evaluating exponential expressions 2

title: Evaluating expressions with variables: temperature
description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

title: One-step equations word problem: super yoga (2 of 2)
description: If you're coming to this video before seeing the previous one, back up! Otherwise, we're solving one-step equations to learn which Super Plan is the best value for our budget.

title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals
description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

title: Writing basic expressions with variables
description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: One-step equations word problem: super yoga (1 of 2)
description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: Variables, expressions, & equations
description: Learn what variables, expressions, and equations are.

title: Converting US customary units of volume
description: Sal converts between gallons, quarts, pints, cups, and fluid ounces.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: x-4y=-18 & -x+3y=11
description: Sal solves the following system of equations by eliminating x: x-4y=-18 and -x+3y=11.

title: Creating rectangles with a given area 1
description: Lindsay creates a rectangle with a given area.

title: Creating rectangles with a given area 2
description: Lindsay creates a rectangle that has the same area (but different side lengths) than a given rectangle.

title: Intro to area and unit squares
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Testing solutions to inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.

title: Finding an error in polynomial subtraction
description: Sal analyzes a polynomial subtraction process to find the step that has an error.

title: Determinant of a 2x2 matrix
description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Intro to matrix inverses
description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.

title: Differentiating linear functions
description: Sal analyzes two attempts of students to differentiate linear functions.

title: Continuity at a point
description: Sal gives two examples where he analyzes the conditions for continuity at a point given a function's graph.

title: Comparing fractions 1 (unlike denominators)
description: Sal compares fractions by finding a common denominator.

title: Comparing and ordering fractions
description: Finding common denominators of multiple fractions to order them

title: Comparing fractions
description: Comparing Fractions

title: Comparing fractions 2 (unlike denominators)
description: Sal compares fractions by finding a common denominator.

title: Graphing patterns on coordinate plane
description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.

title: Graphing sequence relationships
description: Sal plots ordered pairs based on sequence relationships.

title: Interpreting patterns on coordinate plane
description: Sal examines the points on a number line and interprets the patterns to discover relationships.

title: Interpreting relationships in ordered pairs
description: Sal interprets and graphs the relationships between patterns in the given ordered pairs.

title: Classifying numbers: rational & irrational
description: Given a bunch of numbers, learn how to tell which are rational and which are irrational.

title: Intro to rational & irrational numbers
description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Combining like terms
description: Sal explains why 4a + 2a = 6a several ways

title: Combining like terms example
description: We're going to simplify this expression together putting to use our new knowledge of how to combine like terms. Ok? Let's do it!

title: Intro to quadrilateral
description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

title: Quadrilateral properties
description: Learn about the properties of quadrilaterals, parallelograms, trapezoids, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.

title: Quadrilateral types
description: Learn to identify quadrilaterals such as kites, trapezoids, parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares by line and angle type.

title: Kites as a geometric shape
description: Sal discusses a special type of quadrilateral, the kite.

title: Interpreting bar graphs: alligators
description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem using a bar graph.

title: Interpreting bar graphs: colors
description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem using a bar graph.

title: Reading bar graphs: movies
description: Sal interprets bar graphs to answer questions about a context.

title: Reading bar charts: comparing two sets of data
description: A bar chart is especially useful with comparing two sets of data. The difference in the bars give us a quick snapshot that allows us to draw some conclusions.

title: Origins of the Cold War
description: The Cold War was a period of increased tensions and competition for global influence between the United States that lasted from approximately 1945 until 1991. Tensions increased in the aftermath of World War II when the United States dropped the atom bomb and Russian forces took over Eastern Europe. During the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union never directly attacked one another, but instead fought proxy wars in order to repel or spread communism, respectively.

title: Communism
description: Overview of Communism and Marxist-Leninist states.

title: Worked example: domain & range of step function
description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function that is constant in each segment. Such functions are called "step functions."

title: Worked example: domain & range of piecewise linear functions
description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function where each segment is linear.

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Mean, median, & mode example
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Trig word problem: solving for temperature
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Finding reciprocal trig ratios
description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: Using reciprocal trig ratios
description: Sal is given two sides in a right triangle and the cotangent of one of the angles, and he uses this information to find the missing side.

title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables challenge
description: Sal subtracts -6x⁴-3x²y²+5y⁴ from 2x⁴-8x²y²-y⁴.

title: Evaluating expressions with variables: exponents
description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents, specifically, are our focus here.

title: Evaluating an expression with one variable
description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Evaluating expressions with variables: temperature
description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

title: Evaluating exponential expressions 2
description: Evaluating exponential expressions 2

title: Converting repeating decimals to fractions (part 2 of 2)
description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.363636... and 0.714141414... and 3.257257257... to fractions.

title: Solving exponential equations using exponent properties
description: Sal solves equations like 26^(9x+5) = 1 and 2^(3x+5) = 64^(x-7).

title: Ordering rational numbers
description: Sal puts 7/3, -5/2, 0, -2, -12/4, -3.25 in order from least to greatest.

title: Decimals & fractions on the number line
description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

title: Ordering negative numbers
description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Patterns in powers of 10
description: Sal examines patterns in powers of 10.  He also introduces the terms exponent and base.

title: Worked example: slope from graph
description: The slope of a line is rise over run. Learn how to calculate the slope of the line in a graph by finding the change in y and the change in x.

title: Function notation word problem: bank
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models an account balance over time.

title: Function notation word problem: beach
description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video, the function we interpret models the number of people at the beach over time.

title: Fraction word problem: pizza
description: Sal uses fraction models to figure out what fraction of a pizza is left.

title: More about fractions
description: Sal shows fractions as parts of a whole and parts of a group.

title: Evaluating fractional exponents
description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Evaluating fractional exponents: negative unit-fraction
description: How to evaluate powers that are negative unit fractions, like 9 raised to -½ and 27 raised to -⅓.

title: Evaluating fractional exponents: fractional base
description: Sal shows how to evaluate (25/9)^(1/2) and (81/256)^(-1/4).

title: Evaluating quotient of fractional exponents
description: Sal simplifies the complicated expression 256^(4/7) / 2^(4/7)  until he finds that the expression is equal to 16.

title: Evaluating mixed radicals and exponents
description: A worked example of calculating an expression that has both a radical and an exponent. In this example, we evaluate 6^(1/2)⋅(⁵√6)³.

title: Worked examples: Forms & features of quadratic functions
description: Choosing whether factored form, vertex form or standard form of a quadratic is best in different situations.

title: Fractions in lowest terms
description: Fractions in lowest terms.

title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 4
description: How may times have you been told, "Save your money!" We thought so. What if you wanted to save a fractional amount of your allowance? How would you go about figuring out how much to save?

title: Equivalent fractions
description: Learn how to write equivalent fractions.

title: Fractions in lowest terms
description: Fractions in lowest terms.

title: Multiplying binomials
description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials: area model
description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is y²-6y and width is 3y²-2y+1.

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials challenge
description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (2x+4)(5x-9)=ax²+bx-46 true for all x-values.

title: Finding arc measures with equations
description: Sal solves a few items where arc measures are given in equations, we have to find a variable, then use it to find an arc measure.

title: Intro to arc measure
description: Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.

title: Measuring Line Segments
description: In this example of measuring a line segment, the numbers span across the positive and negative. Remember, line segments and points are the foundations of geometry, so this is an important concept.

title: Terms & labels in geometry
description: Learn about geometry terms like point, line, and ray.  We will also learn how to label them.

title: Creating a histogram
description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Interpreting a histogram
description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms, which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.

title: Surface area of a cuboid
description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid, add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l), width (w), and height (h) of the prism and use the formula, SA=2lw+2lh+2hw, to find the surface area.

title: Surface area of a box using nets
description: Learn how to find the surface area of cereal box using nets.

title: Surface area using a net: triangular prism
description: Learn how to compute the surface area of a triangular prism.

title: Decimal place value
description: Introduction to decimal place values and the value of decimal digits

title: Shifting functions
description: Sal analyzes two cases where functions f and g are given graphically, and g is a result of shifting f. He writes formulas for g in terms of f and in terms of x.

title: Graphing shifted functions
description: Given the graph of f(x)=x², Sal graphs g(x)=(x-2)²-4, which is the graph of f shifted 2 units to the right and 4 units down.

title: Drawing a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane example
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Comparing numbers represented different ways
description: Examples of Khan Academy practice problems where you compare decimals, fractions, and number diagrams.

title: Trig word problem: length of day (phase shift)
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in the length of day by modeling it with a sinusoidal function that has a phase shift.

title: L’Hôpital’s rule (composite exponential functions)
description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (sinx)^(1/lnx).

title: Worked example: alternating series remainder
description: Using the alternating series remainder to approximating the sum of an alternating series to a given error bound.

title: Birth of the US Constitution
description: In this video, Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson talks to Sal about  the Declaration of Independence.

title: The Constitution and the Constitutional Convention
description: In this video, historian Joe Ellis and Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson discuss the Constitutional Convention and the replacement of the Articles of Confederation, the Virginia Plan and national government vs. states rights.

title: The Constitution and slavery part 1
description: In this video, historian Joe Ellis and Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson discuss the Constitution and the ideological divide around slavery in addition to the Three-Fifths compromise.

title: The Constitution and slavery part 2
description: In this video, historian Joe Ellis and Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson continue the discussion of the Constitution and slavery and what compromise meant at the Constitutional Convention and George Washington's involvement with slaves.

title: The Constitution and the Bill of Rights: Amendments 1-3
description: In this video, historian Joe Ellis and Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson discuss the Constitution's Bill of Rights, Amendments 1-3.

title: The Constitution and the Bill of Rights: Amendments 4, 5, 10
description: In this video, historian Joe Ellis and Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson discuss the Constitution's Bill of Rights, Amendments 4, 5, and 10.

title: Evaluating sequences in recursive form
