description: Sal shows how to evaluate a sequence that is defined with a recursive formula. This definition gives the base case and then defines how to find the subsequent terms using the base case.

title: Coordinating conjunctions
description: Coordinating conjunctions connect parts of sentences to each other. David explains how.

title: Subordinating conjunctions
description: Subordinating conjunctions join two parts of complex sentences––independent clauses to dependent clauses. David explains how.

title: Fractions on a number line
description: Learn to graph and locate fractions on a number line.

title: Fractions on number line widget
description: Sal uses the Khan Academy number line widget.

title: Plotting basic fractions on the number line
Multiple units word problem: road trip
description: Sal solves a word problem where he finds the cost of gas in a road trip given the car's fuel efficiency, length of the trip, and price of gas.

title: Measurement word problem: running laps
description: Sal solves a US customary distance word problem involving miles, yards, and feet.

title: Finding area by rearranging parts
description: Sometimes it helps to rearrange the parts of geometric figures to find the area. That's what we're going to do here.

title: Area of composite shapes
description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Vertical angles
description: By using our knowledge of supplementary, adjacent, and vertical angles, we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

title: Vertical angles are congruent proof
description: Proving that vertical angles are equal

title: Taxonomy and the tree of life
description: The science of taxonomy and where humans fit into the tree of life.

title: Species
description: What a species is and isn't. Ligers, tiglons, mule, hinnies, and dogs.

title: Understanding and building phylogenetic trees
description: Learn how to read and draw phylogenetic trees, or cladograms.

title: Creating picture and bar graphs 1
description: Sal creates and interprets bar and picture graphs.

title: Creating a bar graph
description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

title: Proving angles are congruent
description: Sal proves that two angles are congruent in a really interesting triangle like figure.

title: Writing systems of inequalities word problem
description: Sal models a word problem about baking cupcakes and muffins by creating a system of linear inequalities.

title: Solving systems of inequalities word problem
description: Given a system of linear inequalities that models a context about making chairs and tables, Sal finds how many can be made.

title: Graphs of systems of inequalities word problem
description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about chopping vegetables, Sal finds if there's enough time to chop!

title: Surface area using a net: triangular prism
description: Learn how to compute the surface area of a triangular prism.

title: Surface area using a net: rectangular prism
description: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional shape that has flat surfaces and straight edges.  Learn whether or not a certain net could be folded up into a certain rectangular prism.

title: Introduction to circuits and Ohm's law
description: Introduction to electricity, circuits, current, and resistance

title: Example: Analyzing a more complex resistor circuit
description: A hairy resistance problem

title: Resistivity and conductivity
description: Let's look at the properties of materials that cause a resistor to resist the flow of current

title: Kirchhoff's current law
description: Kirchhoff's Current Law says the currents flowing into a node must add up to zero.

title: Kirchhoff's voltage law
description: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law says if you travel around any loop in a circuit, the voltages across the elements add up to zero.

title: Electric power
description: In this video David derives the formula to find the power used by a resistor.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots examples
description: Sal solves the equation (x+3)²-4=0 and finds the x-intercepts of f(x)=(x-2)²-9.

title: Recognizing functions from table
description: Checking whether a table of people and their heights can represent a function that assigns a height to a name.

title: Intercepts from an equation
description: Sal finds the x and y-intercepts of -5x + 4y = 20.

title: Features of a circle from its graph
description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its center and its radius.

title: Intro to cube roots
description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: Two-way frequency tables and Venn diagrams
description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Constructing a scatter plot
description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Solving square-root equations (basic)
description: Sal solves the equation √(5x^2-8)=2x.

title: Pronoun number
description: The difference between something being singular or plural is what we call 'grammatical number' in English. Here's how that idea applies to pronouns!

title: Interpreting a trend line
description: Sal interprets a trend line that shows the relationship between study time and math test score for Shira.

title: x-intercept of a line
description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards, he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.

title: Extending geometric sequences
description: Sal finds the next term in the geometric sequence -1/32, 1/8, -1/2, 2,...

title: Subjects and predicates
description: A subject is the noun or pronoun-based part of a sentence, and a predicate is the verb-based part that the subject performs. Let’s explore how that works in context.

title: Simple and compound sentences
description: A simple sentence contains one independent clause. A compound sentence contains more than one! Put another way: a simple sentence contains a subject and a predicate, but a compound sentence contains more than one subject and more than one predicate.

title: Simplifying tricky fractions
description: Learn how to take complex looking fractions and make them much, much simpler.

title: Recognizing fragments
description: A sentence fragment is a chunk of language that hasn’t made it all the way to being a working sentence; it might be missing a verb, or there might not be a subject. Learn how to turn a fragment into a sentence in this video!

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Area of equilateral triangle (advanced)
description: Sal finds a shaded area defined by two equilateral triangles whose side lengths are given.

title: Ways to cross-section a cube
description: Learn about all the different ways we can obtain cross-sections of a cube.

title: Ordering negative numbers
description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Interpreting a scale drawing
description: Understand how a scale drawing is converted into real numbers using the scale factor.

title: Solving a scale drawing word problem
description: See how we solve a word problem by using a scale drawing and finding the scale factor.

title: Reactions in equilibrium
description: Equilibrium reactions and constants.

title: Heterogeneous equilibrium
description: Ignoring the solvent or the solid state molecules when calculating the equilibrium constant.

title: Subsets of sample spaces
description: Sal solves an example about subsets.

title: Evaluating simple definite integral
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Connecting the fundamental theorems of calculus
description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus, and we go through the connection here.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Definite integrals and negative area
description: With integrals, it can be helpful to introduce the notion of "negative area".  See why!

title: Scalar multiplication of vectors
description: Sal explains what happens graphically and to the components of a vector when we multiply it by a scalar.

title: Multiplying a vector by a scalar
description: Watch Sal change the magnitude of a vector by multiplying it by a scalar.

title: Transforming polygons using matrices
description: Sal transforms a triangle using a 2x2 matrix.

title: Features of a circle from its expanded equation
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0, and then he graphs the circle.

title: Addition word problem: horses
description: Sal solves an addition word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Subtraction word problem: tennis balls
description: Sal solves a 2-step subtraction word problem with numbers less than 100.

title: Volume with fractional cubes
description: Another way of finding the volume of a rectangular prism involves dividing it into fractional cubes, finding the volume of one, and then multiplying that volume by the number of cubes that fit into our rectangular prism.

title: Volume of a rectangular prism: fractional dimensions
description: Learn how to find the volume of a rectangular prism that has fractional side lengths. The prism in this video has dimensions 3/5 by 1 1/6 by 3/7.

title: System of equations word problem: walk & ride
description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video, we solve a problem about distances walking and riding bus to school.

title: System of equations word problem: infinite solutions
description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video, we solve a problem about a vegetable framer. In this case, the problem has infinite solutions, which means there's not enough information to find a single solution.

title: System of equations word problem: no solution
description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video, we solve a problem about a toy factory. In this case, the problem has no viable solution, which means the information describes an impossible situation.

title: Plotting inequalities
description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (> or <), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Plotting an inequality example
description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: Plotting inequalities
description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (> or <), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Plotting an inequality example
description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: Helping verbs
description: We've established that verbs can show actions and link ideas together. Now, let's talk about how some verbs can be used to help other verbs.

title: Linking verbs
description: In a previous video, we established that one thing verbs can do is show actions, like "the bear runs." Verbs can also link ideas to one another, like "the bear looks cheerful."

title: Converting units: US volume
description: Learn to convert 3 1/2 gallons to cups.

title: Adding units of volume
description: Learn to add 16 fluid ounces + 3 pints + 4 quarts.

title: Same length in different units
description: Learn how we can describe the length 4.5 yards in a variety of different units.

title: Multiplying mixed numbers
description: Sal introduces multiplying mixed numbers.

title: Even & odd polynomials
description: Sal analyzes three different polynomials to see if they are even, odd, or neither.

title: Introduction to improper integrals
description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​bounderies is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: Improper integral with two infinite bounds
description: Infinite both ways!

title: Divergent improper integral
description: Sometimes the value of an infinite integral is, well, infinite.

title: Writing expressions with variables
description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.

title: Introduction to nouns
description: A noun is a word that describes a person, place, thing, or idea. Examples of nouns include names, locations, objects in the physical world, or objects and concepts that do not exist in the physical world; for example, a dream or a theory.

title: Measuring volume as area times length
description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area times length.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines intro
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines
description: Parallel lines are lines in a plane that are always the same distance apart. Parallel lines never intersect. Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right (90 degrees) angle.

title: Classifying triangles by angles
description: You say you can't categorize a triangle because you don't know the length of the sides. Guess what? If you know the size of the angles you can!

title: Classifying triangles
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Worked example: Classifying triangles
description: Work through sample problems categorizing triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Intro to multiplying 2 fractions
description: Sal introduces multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Multiplying 2 fractions: 5/6 x 2/3
description:
How to multiply fractions?

The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.

title: Dividing by a multi-digit decimal
description: Sal shows that when there is a decimal divisor, you need to shift the decimal first and then divide.

title: Dividing decimals with hundredths
description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

title: Dividing decimals with hundredths example 3
description: Sal shows how to  tackle a division problem step by step when there is a decimal divisor.

title: Introduction to the Gilded Age
description: What was the Gilded Age? Kim and David discuss the vast wealth and crushing poverty that characterized the era.

title: The Gilded Age and the Second Industrial Revolution
description: Steel, telephones, elevators! Kim and David discuss the technological innovations that made the Gilded Age possible.

title: Misunderstanding evolution: a biologist's perspective on Social Darwinism
description: In the late nineteenth century, sociologists misused Darwin's theory of evolution to justify racism. KA's US history fellow Kim and Biology fellow Emily discuss how evolution really works and how sociologists in the Gilded Age misunderstood its application to human society.

title: Misunderstanding evolution: a historian's perspective on Social Darwinism
description: Does "survival of the fittest" apply to human culture? KA fellows Kim (US history) and Emily (Biology) continue their discussion of the theory of evolution and how Gilded Age sociologists mistakenly applied it to race and class.

title: Convert decimal from expanded form to standard form
description: Learn to write (4x1,000,000)+(3x1000)+(67x1/1000) in standard form.

title: Write decimal in expanded form
description: Learn to write 905.074 in expanded form.

title: Decimals in written form (thousandths)
description: Learn to write 20,000.507 using words.

title: Reading box plots
description: Is this some kind of cute cat video? No! Box and whisker plots seek to explain data by showing a spread of all the data points in a sample. The "whiskers" are the two opposite ends of the data. This video is more fun than a handful of catnip.

title: Constructing a box plot
description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together, shall we?

title: Complementary & supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Worked example: Rate problem
description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.

title: Multiplication as scaling with fractions
description: Sal compares the following expressions by thinking about multiplication as scaling: 2/3x7/8, 8/7x2/3, and (5x2)/(3x5)

title: Intro to adding mixed numbers
description: Sal adds 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Intro to subtracting mixed numbers
description: Sal subtracts 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Slope of a line secant to a curve
description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Approximating instantaneous rate of change with secant lines
description: Sal approximates the instantaneous rate of change of stores per year in a popular coffee chain.

title: Derivative as a limit
description: Sal arrives at a formal definition for the derivative by considering it as a limit of the slopes of secant lines that approach a tangent line.

title: Evaluating a limit expression for the derivative of a linear function
description: Sal interprets a limit expression as the derivative of a linear function at a point, and evaluates it.

title: The derivative of x² at x=3 using the formal definition
description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Formal and alternate form of the derivative
description: Sal introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Derivative intuition module
description: Sal walking through the derivative intuition module made by Ben Eater

title: Slope of secant line challenge
description: Sal interprets an expression as the slope of a secant line between a specific point on a graph and any other point on that graph.

title: The graphical relationship between a function & its derivative (part 1)
description: Given the graph of a function, Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines intro
description: Parallel lines never intersect, and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Drawing parallel line segments
description: Sal draws parallel line segments with given points.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines
description: Parallel lines are lines in a plane that are always the same distance apart. Parallel lines never intersect. Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right (90 degrees) angle.

title: Volume of a rectangular prism
description: Sal finds the area of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.

title: Measuring volume as area times length
description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area times length.

title: Introduction to heredity
description: Heredity and Classical Genetics. Dominant and recessive traits. Heterozygous and homozygous genotypes.

title: Worked example: Punnett squares
description: Learn how to use Punnett squares to calculate probabilities of different phenotypes. Includes worked examples of dihybrid crosses. independent assortment, incomplete dominance, codominance, and multiple alleles.

title: One-step division equations
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: One-step multiplication equations
description: Remember that what you do to one side, you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction, x/a? Let's do it together.

title: One-step equations intuition
description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?

title: Dividing both sides of an equation
description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.

title: Finding arc measures
description: Watch Sal solve a few problems where he finds a missing arc measure.

title: Intro to arc measure
description: Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360, conventions of minor and major arcs, and a comparison to arc length.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Worked example: p-series
description: p-series are infinite sums Σ(1/xᵖ) for some positive p. In this video you will see examples of identifying whether a p-series converges or diverges.

title: Worked example: positive & negative intervals
description: Finding the positive or negative intervals of a function from its graph.

title: Adding 1 vs. adding 10
description: Sal talks about the difference between adding 1 and adding 10.

title: The origins of Jim Crow - introduction
description: Who or what was Jim Crow? KA's US history fellow Kim talks about the origin of Jim Crow segregation in the American South.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - the Black Codes and Reconstruction
description: In the period after the Civil War in the American South, when Southern society reorganized to account for the end of slavery. In this video, Kim discusses how many Southern governments passed laws preventing African Americans from voting, among other things, which prompted Congress to pass the Fourteenth Amendment.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments
description: During Reconstruction, federal troops attempted to enforce the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments in the South.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - Compromise of 1877 and Plessy v. Ferguson
description: Federal troops left the South after the Compromise of 1877, ending Reconstruction. The Supreme Court ruled that segregation did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment in the Plessy v. Ferguson decision of 1896.

title: Expected profit from lottery ticket
description: Sal multiplies outcomes by probabilities to find the expected value of a lottery ticket.

title: Electromagnetic waves and the electromagnetic spectrum
Young's double slit introduction
description: We can see interference in action if we shine laser light through two slits onto a screen

title: Young's double slit equation
description: Let's derive a formula that relates all the variables in Young's double slit experiment

title: Young's double slit problem solving
description: An example problem involving a double slit experiment

title: Single slit interference
description: What happens when there's only one hole?

title: Thin Film Interference part 1
description: Thin film interference occurs when light waves reflecting off the top and bottom surfaces of a thin film interfere with one another. This type of interference is the reason that thin films, such as oil or soap bubbles, form colorful patterns.

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics
description: Sal factors x^2+4xy-5y^2 as (x-y)(x+5y).

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: rearranging
description: Sal rearranges 30x^2+11xy+y^2 as y^2+11xy+30x^2 and then factors it as (y+5x)(y+6x).

title: Factoring two-variable quadratics: grouping
description: Sal factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest ten
description: Sal rounds 1585 to the nearest ten.

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest hundred
description: Sal rounds 24,259 to the nearest hundred.

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest thousand
description: Sal rounds 423,275 to the  nearest thousand.

title: Rounding whole numbers: missing digit
description: Lindsay finds the missing digit in an estimation problem by using a number line.

title: Strategies for dividing by tenths
description: Sal uses equivalent fractions to divide both whole numbers and decimals by tenths.

title: Multi-digit division strategies for decimals
description: Sal uses understanding of place value, expanded form, and fractions to help divide with decimals.

title: Division strategies for decimal quotients
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value and fractions to introduce dividing with decimals.

title: One-sided limits from graphs
description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example, f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers, 1 for positive numbers, and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1, and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: One-sided limits from graphs: asymptote
description: Sal analyzes the left-sided limit of a function given its graph. It turns out the function has an asymptote, so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Evaluating definite integral from graph
description: If you already know the area under a curve, you can use it to compute an integral.

title: Christopher Columbus part 1
description: In this video, KA's US history intern Becca examines some common misconceptions about Christopher Columbus's voyage to the New World.

title: Christopher Columbus part 2
description: KA's US history intern Becca and US history fellow Kim discuss Christopher Columbus's legacy in the United States.

title: Features of a circle from its standard equation
description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Comparing areas of plots of land
description: Sal finds area of two rectangles to solve a word problem.

title: Radical functions differentiation intro
description: Sal differentiates f(x)=-4∛x, and evaluates the derivative at x=8. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Combined vector operations
description: Watch Sal find new vector 3u + 1/5w when u = (2, -1) and w = (-5, 5).

title: Worked example: evaluating piecewise functions
description: Evaluating piecewise functions at given inputs, both from a formula and from a graph.

title: Reading bar graphs: movies
description: Sal interprets bar graphs to answer questions about a context.

title: Reading bar graphs: Harry Potter
description: Sal interprets a bar graph.

title: Exponential decay intro
description: An exponential function a⋅rˣ is growing (increasing) if r>1 and decaying (decreasing) if 0

title: Dangling modifiers
description: A modifying word or phrase “dangles” when it doesn’t apply to the word it’s supposed to modify. Learn how to spot and fix this problem!

title: Multiplying binomials intro
description: Sal expresses (x-4)(x+7) as the standard trinomial x²+3x-28 and discusses how the general product (x+a)(x+b) can be written as x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Multiplying binomials: area model
description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is x+2 and width is x+3.

title: Visualizing vectors in 2 dimensions
description: Visualizing, adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions

title: Projectile at an angle
description: Figuring out the horizontal displacement for a projectile launched at an angle

title: Horizontally launched projectile
description: In this video David explains how to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. He also explains common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Launching and landing on different elevations
description: More complicated example involving launching and landing at different elevations

title: Total displacement for projectile
description: Reconstructing the total displacement vector for a projectile

title: Optimal angle for a projectile part 1: Components of initial velocity
description: You want a projectile to fly as far as possible, at which angle should you launch it? We'll start with formulas for the initial velocity.

title: Oxidizing and reducing agents
description: How to identify the oxidizing and reducing agents.

title: Balancing redox reactions in acid
description: How to balance a redox reaction in acid.

title: Balancing redox reactions in base
description: How to balance a redox reaction in base.

title: Disproportionation
description: Assigning oxidation states for the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, a disproportionation reaction.

title: Specular and diffuse reflection
description: Specular and Diffuse Reflection

title: Refraction and Snell's law
description: Refraction and Snell's Law

title: Snell's law example 1
description: Snell's Law Example 1

title: Total internal reflection
description: Critical incident angle and total internal reflection

title: Parabolic mirrors 2
description: Parabolic Mirrors 2

title: Concave lenses
description: Concave Lenses

title: Thin lens equation and problem solving
description: Some examples of using the thin lens equation

title: Multi-step unit conversion examples (metric)
description: Sal solves multi-step unit conversion examples with metric units of measure.

title: Intro to adjectives
description: Adjectives are the words we use to modify nouns.  David explains how, with the help of a bear.

title: Ordering by length
description: Sal orders 3 objects by length and compares the lengths of 2 objects indirectly by using a third object.

title: Introduction to irregular verbs
description: Words like "walk" and "look" are regular verbs – they behave in a predictable way. But there's a whole class of words in English, called irregular verbs, that are harder to predict. David, KA's Grammar Fellow, explains.

title: The funky -ed irregular verb
description: These are the most regular of the irregular verbs; while they don't behave exactly like regular verbs, like present tense "walk" become past tense "walked", they do maintain the "-ed" sound. It's just spelled differently.

title: The vowel-shift irregular verb
description: This group of irregular verbs have vowel sounds that change in a predictable way, when they go from the present to the past tense.

title: The irregular verb gets taken for a ride
description: Some irregular verbs have these strange -en endings that only show up in their past perfect/past participle forms. Let's take a look!

title: The truly irregular verbs
description: Some irregular verbs just won't be categorized. They don't fit into neat little boxes. These are those verbs.

title: Direction of vectors from components: 1st & 2nd quadrants
description: Sal first finds the direction angle of a vector in the first quadrant, then moves onto a trickier one in the second quadrant.

title: Direction of vectors from components: 3rd & 4th quadrants
description: Sal finds the direction angle of a vector in the third quadrant and a vector in the fourth quadrant.

title: Limits from tables
description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Scale of cells
description: Thinking about how large a cell is compared to viruses, proteins and simple molecules.

title: Cell theory
description: Introduction to cell theory. Roles of Hooke, Leeuwenhoek and others in its development.

title: Slicing a rectangular pyramid
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Transforming vectors using matrices
description: Sal transforms a 2-dimensional vector using a 2x2 matrix, and draws the original vector and its image on the plane.

title: Equations with one rational expression
description: Sal solves the equation (14x+4)/(-3x-2)=8.

title: Worked example: limit comparison test
description: To use the limit comparison test for a series S₁, we need to find another series S₂ that is similar in structure (so the infinite limit of S₁/S₂ is finite) and whose convergence is already determined. See a worked example of using the test in this video.

title: Comparing values with calculator
description: Learn how to compare 22.9% to √0.45 using a calculator.

title: Approximating square roots to hundredths
description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

title: Comparing means of distributions
description: Sal compares the means of two different distributions given as dot plots.

title: Means and medians of different distributions
description: Sal compares the mean and median based on a few different distributions.

title: Introduction to the semicolon
description: Paige introduces a piece of punctuation called the semicolon; this punctuation can link closely related independent clauses together in a sentence.

title: Sign of expressions challenge problems
description: Some examples that test our understanding of what happens when we multply or divided a bunch of positive or negative numbers.

title: Even & odd numbers of negatives
description: We can figure out whether multiplication and division problems give us a positive or negative result by thinking about how many negative numbers are used in the computation.

title: 1 and -1 to different powers
description: Use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression.

title: Analyzing vertical asymptotes of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the behavior of q(x)=(x²+3x+2)/(x+3) around its vertical asymptote at x=-3.

title: Solutions to 2-variable equations: graphical (old)
description: An old video of Sal checking whether (3,-4) is a solution of 5x+2y=7 by graphing the equation and checking if (3,-4) is on the line.

title: Absolute value as distance between numbers
description: In this video, we think about what |a-b| really means, and we verify that |a-b| = |b-a| by looking at an example.

title: Rational number word problem: school report
description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

title: Rational number word problem: cosmetics
description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.

title: Rational number word problem: cab
description: Budgeting money is one of the most valuable math skills you'll learn. Practice with us as we figure out how much money is left after a cab fare.

title: Diffusion - Introduction
description: Learn about how particles move from an area of greater concentration to an area of lesser concentration through the process of diffusion.

title: Concentration gradients
description: A concentration gradient occurs when the concentration of particles is higher in one area than another. In passive transport, particles will diffuse down a concentration gradient, from areas of higher concentration to areas of lower concentration, until they are evenly spaced.

title: Osmosis
description: Osmosis of water from an area of lower to an area of higher solute concentration across a semipermeable membrane.

title: Hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic solutions (tonicity)
description: Hypotonic, isotonic and hypertonic solutions (tonicity). Seeing the effect of various types of solution on the direction of osmosis.

title: Diffusion and osmosis
description: Learn about diffusion, osmosis, and concentration gradients and why these are important to cells.

title: Comparing fractions with > and < symbols
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Comparing fractions with the same denominator
description: Lindsay compares fractions with the same denominator. She compares one pair of fractions with visuals and another pair without visuals.

title: Area between curves
description: By integrating the difference of two functions, you can find the area between them.

title: Interpreting equations graphically
description: Sal interprets the intersection point of the graphs of functions f and g as the solution of the equation f(x)=g(x).

title: Interpreting equations graphically (example 2)
description: Sal finds the coordinates of points on a graph that are solutions to a given equation.

title: Intro to long division (no remainders)
description: Watch an introduction to long division with the problem 96÷4.

title: Long division: 280÷5
description: Learn to divide 280÷5 with long division.  The answer wil not have a remainder.

title: Decimal place value
description: Introduction to decimal place values and the value of decimal digits

title: Comparing irrational numbers with radicals
description: Learn how to sort a bunch of numbers (4√2  2√3  3√2  √17  3√3  5) from least to greatest without using a calculator.

title: Rational equation word problem
description: Sal models a context that concerns the number and price of pizza slices. The model turns out to be a rational equation.

title: Quadratic inequality word problem
description: Sal models a context that concerns a candy vending machine. The model turns out to be a quadratic inequality.

title: Exponential equation word problem
description: Sal models a context that concerns a bank savings account. The model turns out to be an exponential equation.

title: Product rule intro
description: Sal differentiates x²sin(x) using the product rule.

title: Quotient rule from product & chain rules
description: Sal shows how you can derive the quotient rule using the product rule and the chain rule (one less rule to memorize!)

title: Implicit differentiation
description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example, x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule, and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example, according to the chain rule, the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Implicit differentiation (advanced example)
description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Derivative of inverse sine
description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Differentiating composite exponential functions
description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Similar shapes & transformations
description: Sal is given pairs of polygons, and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Features of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Substitution with negative numbers
description: Practice substituting positive and negative values for variables.

title: Passive transport and selective permeability
description: Passive transport and selective permeability. Passive transport through diffusion.

title: Facilitated diffusion
description: Understanding how channel proteins and carrier proteins can facilitate diffusion across a cell membrane (passive transport).

title: Sodium potassium pump
description: How the the sodium-potassium (Na+/K+) pump works. Its role in establishing resting membrane potentials.

title: Electrochemical gradients and secondary active transport
description: How a cell can use a molecule's electrochemical gradient to power secondary active transport.

title: Uniporters, symporters and antiporters
description: Uniporters, symporters, and antiporters are proteins that are used in ​transport​ of substances across a cell membrane. Uniporters are involved in facilitated diffusion and work by binding to one molecule of substrate at a time to move it along its concentration gradient. Symporters and antiporters are involved in active transport. Antiporters transport molecules in opposite directions, while symporters transport molecules in the same direction.

title: Endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis
description: Bulk transport: endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis.

title: Exocytosis
description: Introduction to exocytosis!

title: Comparing decimal place values
description: Sal compares the threes in 7,346,521.032 by considering their place value.

title: Basic trig and exponential antiderivatives
description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x) and e^x?

title: Antiderivative of x^-1
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Example:  Different ways to pick officers
description: Thinking about the different ways we can pick officers in order to find the probability of one situation in particular.

title: Example: Combinatorics and probability
description: Probability of getting a set of cards

title: Probability with counting outcomes
description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.

title: Example: All the ways you can flip a coin
description: Manually going through the combinatorics to determine the probability of an event occuring

title: Exactly three heads in five flips
description: Probability of exactly 3 heads in 5 flips using combinations

title: Getting exactly two heads (combinatorics)
description: A different way to think about the probability of getting 2 heads in 4 flips

title: Probability & combinations (2 of 2)
description: Making at least 3 out of 5 free throws.

title: Probability using combinations
description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Example:  Lottery probability
description: What is the probability of winning a 4-number lottery?

title: Mega millions jackpot probability
description: Probability of winning the Mega Millions jackpot

title: Intersection and union of sets
description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Relative complement or difference between sets
description: Sal shows an example finding the relative complement or difference of two sets A and B.

title: Universal set and absolute complement
description: Sal moves onto more challenging set ideas and notation like the universal set and absolute complement.

title: Subset, strict subset, and superset
description: Sal explains the difference between a subset, a strict subset, and a superset. He also explains the notation behind these ideas.

title: Bringing the set operations together
description: Sal summarizes the set operations that he has discussed in the previous videos.

title: Simplifying expressions with rational numbers
description: Learn how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.

title: Worked example: Subtracting 3-digit numbers (regrouping)
description: Learn to use regrouping (borrowing) and place value to subtract 971-659.

title: Worked example: Subtracting 3-digit numbers (regrouping twice)
description: Sal using regrouping (borrowing) to subtract 913-286.

title: Worked example: Subtracting 3-digit numbers (regrouping from 0)
description: Sal has to borrow from a 0 to subtract 301-164.

title: Subtracting 3-digit numbers (regrouping) 2
description: Sal uses regrouping (borrowing) and place value to subtract 629-172.

title: Intro to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: Decimals in written form (hundredths)
description: Learn to write 63.15 using words.

title: Decimals in written form (thousandths)
description: Learn to write 20,000.507 using words.

title: Visually adding fractions: 5/6+1/4
description: Sal adds 5/6+1/4 using a fraction model for help.

title: Visually subtracting fractions: 3/4-5/8
description: Sal subtracts 3/4-5/8 using a fraction model for help.

title: Multiplying 1-digit numbers by 10, 100, and 1000

title: Parallel lines from equation
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Parallel lines from equation (example 2)
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Parallel lines from equation (example 3)
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Perpendicular lines from equation
description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are perpendicular.

title: Multiplying by tens word problem
description: Lindsay multiplies 90 times 5 to solve a word problem.

title: Multiplying by multiples of 10
description: Sal decomposes multiples of ten to multiply.

title: Rotating 2D shapes in 3D
description: If you rotate a 2D shape about an axis, the shape will define a 3D object. Watch Sal rotating various 2D shapes and see what 3D objects he gets!

title: Perfect progressive aspect
description: We use the perfect progressive aspect to talk about an action that was once ongoing, but has since completed, like "I had been waiting for twenty minutes."

title: Perfect Aspect
description: You use the perfect verb aspect to express when an action is completed, like "I have done the dishes."

title: Progressive Aspect
description: We use the progressive aspect to express that a verb action is ongoing, as in "I am eating."

title: Simple Aspect
description: Verb aspect allows a speaker to give even more information about when an event took place or is going to take place. The simple aspect of a verb is the same as its past, present, and future tenses, such as "I walked," "I walk," and "I will walk."

title: Converting mixed numbers to improper fractions
description: Converting Mixed Numbers to Improper Fractions

title: Rewriting improper fractions as mixed numbers
description: Sal rewrite 7/4 as a mixed number.

title: Rewriting mixed numbers as improper fractions
description: Sal rewrites 5 1/4 as an improper fraction.

title: Comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers
description: Worked examples comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers

title: Mixed numbers and improper fractions
description: Converting mixed numbers to improper fractions and improper fractions to mixed numbers

title: Linear equations word problems: earnings
description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.

title: Linear equations word problems: volcano
description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Extracellular matrix
description: Overview of how cells interact with the extracellular matrix.

title: Plant cell walls
description: Understanding the structure of plant cell walls.

title: Proportion word problem: hot dogs
description: Mika can eat 21 hot dogs in 66 minutes. She wants to know how many minutes it would take her to eat 35 hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.

title: Proportion word problem: cookies
description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. How much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?

title: Adding mixed numbers with regrouping
description: Sal adds 2 2/3 + 8 3/4.

title: Subtracting mixed numbers with regrouping (unlike denominators)
description: Sal subtracts 17 4/9 - 12 2/3.

title: Subtracting mixed numbers: 7 6/9 - 3 2/5
description: Sal subtracts 3 2/5 from 7 6/9 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Adding mixed numbers: 19 3/18 + 18 2/3
description: Sal adds 19 3/18 + 18 2/3 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators
description: Adding Mixed Numbers with Unlike Denominators

title: Adding fractions with unlike denominators
description: Sal adds fractions like 3/4 and 1/5.

description: Sal solves a word problem by constructing a numerical expression.

description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

description: Sal adds 7 + 6 using the number line.

description: Sal adds 8 + 7 by making a group of ten.

description: Sal subtracts fractions like 4/3 and 1/5.

title: Compound prepositions
description: These prepositions are called compound prepositions, or multisyllabic prepositions. Like most prepositions, they have both literal and figurative meanings. David explains.

title: Counting dollars
description: Sal adds to find the total value when given an amount US dollars.

title: Counting American coins
description: Sal adds to find ​the total value when given an amount US coins.

title: Meet the Comma
description: David and Paige introduce you to the superhero of the punctuation world: the comma! Practice this yourself on Khan Academy right now:

title: Addition and subtraction word problems: gorillas
description: Sal solves addition and subtraction word problems.

title: Comparison word problems: roly-polies
description: Sal solves word problems comparing 2 numbers.  Numbers in the problems are less than 10.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: For constant increments in x, a linear growth would increase by a constant difference, and an exponential growth would increase by a constant ratio.

title: Dividing whole numbers & fractions: t-shirts
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Multiplying unit fractions and whole numbers
description: Sal multiplies 1/2 x 5 using repeated addition and fraction models.

title: Counting by 10s
description: Sal counts by 10s.

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers visually
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

description: Sal uses two approaches to multiply 2/3x6.

description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

title: Creating picture and bar graphs 1
description: Sal creates and interprets bar and picture graphs.

title: Worked example: equivalent systems of equations
description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.

title: Worked example: non-equivalent systems of equations
description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.

title: More uses for commas
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, discuss tag questions, yes and no statements, and direct address -- all situations where the comma is super useful.

title: Commas in dialogue
description: “Today we’re going to talk about using commas in dialogue,” said David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians.

title: Multiplying positive and negative fractions
description: See examples of multiplying and dividing fractions with negative numbers.

title: Multiplying 2 fractions: 5/6 x 2/3
description:
How to multiply fractions?

The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.

title: Measuring lengths 2
description: Sal measures objects with a ruler.

title: Marginal cost & differential calculus
description: In economics, the idea of marginal cost can be nicely captured with the derivative.

title: Applied rates of change: marginal costs
description: Sal solves a problem involving the modeling of cost with a function, which means the function's derivative models the marginal cost.

title: Applied rate of change: forgetfulness
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Related rates: circle radius & area
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Related rates: balloon
description: In this example, you are analyzing the rate of change of a balloon's altitude based on the angle you have to crane your neck to look at it.

title: Related rates: water pouring into a cone
description: As you pour water into a cone, how does the rate of change of the depth of the water relate to the rate of change in volume.

title: Comparing whole numbers
description: Sal compares 394 and 397.

title: Analyzing tables of exponential functions
description: Sal is given a table of values of an exponential function and he analyzes it in order to find the common ratio and the initial value.

title: Analyzing graphs of exponential functions
description: Given the graph of an exponential function, Sal finds the formula of the function and a value that is outside the graph.

title: Analyzing graphs of exponential functions: negative initial value
description: Given the graph of an exponential function with a negative initial value, Sal finds the formula of the function and solves an equation.

title: Decomposing shapes to find area: add
description: Lindsay finds the area of an irregular shape by decomposing it into 3 rectangles and adding the area of the rectangles.

title: Decomposing shapes to find area: subtract
description: Lindsay finds the area of an irregular shape by decomposing it into 2 rectangles and subtracting the area of the rectangles.

title: Area word problem: house size
description: Sal decomposes an irregular shape to find area of entire figure.

title: Simplifying mixed radical and exponential expressions

title: Least common multiple

title: Least common multiple: repeating factors

title: Least common multiple of three numbers

title: Empirical, molecular, and structural formulas

title: Limiting reactant example problem 1
description: A limiting reagent problem to calculate mass of product and mass of excess reactant leftover after reaction.

title: Stoichiometry example problem 2

title: Worked example: rational vs. irrational expressions

title: Proof: sum & product of two rationals is rational

title: Proof: product of rational & irrational is irrational
description: The product of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that 3π is irrational.

title: Proof: sum of rational & irrational is irrational
description: The sum of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that ½+√2 is irrational.

title: Sums and products of irrational numbers
description: The sum of two irrational numbers can be rational and it can be irrational. It depends on which irrational numbers we're talking about exactly. The same goes for products for two irrational numbers. This video covers this fact with various examples.

title: Sample standard deviation and bias
description: Sal shows an example of calculating standard deviation and bias.

title: Measures of spread: range, variance & standard deviation
description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Monomial factorization
description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 24x^5 and determines whether they are correct.

title: Worked example: finding the missing monomial factor
description: Sal finds the missing factor F in the factorization of -30x^5 as (-10x^3)(F).

title: Worked example: finding missing monomial side in area model
description: Sal finds the length of a rectangle whose area is 42xy^3 and whose height is 14xy.

title: More empirical rule and z-score practice (from ck12.org)
description: More Empirical Rule and Z-score practice

title: Normal distribution problem: z-scores (from ck12.org)

title: Normal distribution problems: Empirical rule (from ck12.org)
description: Using the empirical rule (or 68-95-99.7 rule) to estimate probabilities for normal distributions

title: Analyzing trends in categorical data
description: Sal solves an example where he is asked to calculate relative frequencies and analyze trends in categorical data.

title: Filling out frequency table for independent events

title: Optimization: sum of squares
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Optimization: box volume (Part 1)

title: Optimization: box volume (Part 2)
description: Finishing up the last video by working through the formulas.

title: Optimization: profit
description: Who knows, you may end up running a shoe factory one day.  So it might not be a bad idea to know how to maximize profits.

title: Optimization: cost of materials
description: With all the storage you might have to handle for your shoe factory, I bet you'd also like to be able to minize the cost of storage.

title: Optimization: area of triangle & square (Part 1)

title: Optimization: area of triangle & square (Part 2)

title: Reverse chain rule introduction

title: Reverse chain rule example

title: Integral of tan x
description: It might not look like it at first, but the reverse chain rule let's us find the integral of tan(x)

title: Decomposing an angle
description: Sal finds the measure of angles by adding or subtracting.

title: Decomposing angles
description: Lindsay finds the measure of angle using addition.

title: Identifying type of transformation
description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

title: Place value when multiplying and dividing by 10
description: Lindsay discusses how multiplying and dividing by 10 affects place value.

title: Understanding place value
description: Sal discusses how a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.

title: Comparing place values
description: Sal compares numbers in different place values.

title: Worked example: average rate of change from equation
description: Finding the interval where a function has an average rate of change of ½ given its equation.

title: Graph interpretation word problem: temperature
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Graph interpretation word problem: basketball
description: When a function models a real-world context, we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video, we interpret the y-intercept of a graph that models a basketball free throw.

title: Constraining solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Sal determines which x-values make the ordered pair (x,-7) a solution of 2x-7y<25, both algebraically and graphically.

title: Relative clauses
description: A relative pronoun is a word like “that” or “which” or “who”, so a relative clause is a clause that begins with a relative pronoun. In the sentence “The dragon who breathed blue fire has retired,” “who breathed blue fire” is a relative clause. Learn more about these constructions by watching the video!

title: Bernini, Ecstasy of Saint Teresa
description:
Gian Lorenzo Bernini, Ecstasy of Saint Teresa, 1647-52 (Cornaro Chapel, Santa Maria della Vittoria, Rome). Speakers: Dr. Beth Harris and Dr. Steven Zucker

This is Saint Teresa's description of the event that Bernini depicts: "Beside me, on the left, appeared an angel in bodily form.... He was not tall but short, and very beautiful; and his face was so aflame that he appeared to be one of the highest rank of angels, who seem to be all on fire.... In his hands I saw a great golden spear, and at the iron tip there appeared to be a point of fire. This he plunged into my heart several times so that it penetrated to my entrails. When he pulled it out I felt that he took them with it, and left me utterly consumed by the great love of God. The pain was so severe that it made me utter several moans. The sweetness caused by this intense pain is so extreme that one cannot possibly wish it to cease, nor is one's soul content with anything but God. This is not a physical but a spiritual pain, though the body has some share in it—even a considerable share."

title: Rounding whole numbers: missing digit
description: Lindsay finds the missing digit in an estimation problem by using a number line.

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest hundred
description: Sal rounds 24,259 to the nearest hundred.

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest thousand
description: Sal rounds 423,275 to the  nearest thousand.

title: Rounding whole numbers to nearest ten
description: Sal rounds 1585 to the nearest ten.

title: Finding perimeter when a side length is missing

title: Perimeter: introduction

description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=2⁻ˣ-5, which is a horizontal reflection and shift of y=2ˣ.

title: Transforming exponential graphs (example 2)
description: Given the graph of y=2ˣ, Sal graphs y=(-1)2ˣ⁺³+4, which is a vertical reflection and a shift of y=2ˣ.

title: Graphing exponential functions

title: Finding inverse functions: linear

title: Finding inverse functions: quadratic
description: Sal finds the inverse of f(x)=(x+2)^2+1.

title: Finding inverse functions: quadratic (example 2)

description: Sal finds the inverse of h(x)=-∛(3x-6)+12.

title: Jacksonian Democracy - background and introduction
description: Modern American political culture began to emerge in the early nineteenth century. In this video, Kim discusses the transition from the United States' earlier aristocratic political culture to a more democratic one as the right to vote was extended to a broader segment of American citizens.

title: Jacksonian Democracy - the "corrupt bargain" and the election of 1824
description: In the contested presidential election of 1824, John Quincy Adams faced off against Andrew Jackson and Henry Clay.

title: Jacksonian Democracy - mudslinging and the election of 1828
description: Rematch! Kim discusses the presidential election of 1828, when Andrew Jackson once again ran against John Quincy Adams and won. This election was the first to employ many modern election tactics, such as mudslinging.

title: Jacksonian Democracy - spoils system, Bank War, and Trail of Tears
description: In the final video in this series, Kim discusses Andrew Jackson's presidency and how he attempted to increase the power of the executive branch. A growing movement of opposition to Jackson coalesced into the Whig Party, which employed many of the same tactics as Jackson in the election of 1840.

title: 5th roots
description: 5th roots

title: Passive transport and selective permeability
description: Passive transport and selective permeability. Passive transport through diffusion.

title: Facilitated diffusion
description: Understanding how channel proteins and carrier proteins can facilitate diffusion across a cell membrane (passive transport).

title: Testing solutions to systems of inequalities
description: Sal checks whether the ordered pair (2,5) is a solution of the following system: y≥2x+1 and x>1.

title: Division word problem: field goals
description: Sal solves a division word problem.

title: Multiplication word problem: pizza
description: Sal solves a multiplication word problem.

title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Subtraction word problems within 10
description: Sal solves word problems by subtracting small numbers (numbers 10 or less).

description: Sal uses the angle bisector theorem to solve for sides of a triangle.

description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Interpreting negative number statements
description: The examples in this video use negative numbers to represent real world situations. What are these negative numbers really telling us?

title: Inputs & outputs of inverse functions
description: Sal explains that if f(a)=b, then f ⁻¹(b)=a, or in other words, the inverse function of f outputs a when its input is b.

title: Graphing the inverse of a linear function
description: Sal is given a line segment on the coordinate plane, and he graphs the inverse of the function represented by that segment.

title: Writing a number in standard form
description: Learn to write six hundred forty-five million, five hundred eighty-four thousand, four hundred sixty-two with numbers.

title: Proportional relationships: graphs
description: Learn how to tell proportional relationships by drawing graphs. Key idea: the graph of a proportional relationship is a straight line through the origin.

title: Converting feet to inches
description: Learn to convert feet to inches.

title: Features of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Matching functions & their derivatives graphically
description: Given the graph of a function, we are asked to recognize the graph of its derivative.

title: Inscribed angle theorem proof
description: Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.

title: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions: monomials
description: Sal multiplies (6x³/5) X (2/3x) and divides (2x⁴/7) ➗ (5x⁴/4).

title: Polynomials intro
description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

title: Powers of complex numbers
description: Sal simplifies the 20th power of a complex number given in polar form.

title: Complex number equations: x³=1
description: Sal finds all complex solutions to the equation x^3=1.

title: Riemann approximation introduction
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: A more general Riemann sum
description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Variation in a species
description: How variation can be introduced into a species.

title: Subtracting rational expressions
description: Sal subtracts and simplifies (a-2)/(a+2) - (a-3)/(a²+4a+4).

title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations
description: Sal gives an example of how an extraneous solution arises when solving 2x-1=√(8-x).

title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations (example 2)
description: Sal finds the value of d for which √(3x+25)=d+2x has an extraneous solution at x=-3.

title: Distance & midpoint of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Intro to ellipses
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Volume of a cone
description: The formula for the volume of a cone is V=1/3hπr². Learn how to use this formula to solve an example problem.

title: Limits of combined functions
description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of an expression that combines the two functions. For example, the limit at 0 of the product of the functions.

title: Subtraction strategies with hundredths

title: More advanced subtraction strategies with hundredths
description: Sal uses place value and numbers in expanded form to subtract decimal to hundredths, such as 8.38-4.54.

title: Powers of the imaginary unit
description: The imaginary unit i is defined such that i²=-1. So what's i³? i³=i²⋅i=-i. What's i⁴? i⁴=i²⋅i²=(-1)²=1. What's i⁵? i⁵=i⁴⋅i=1⋅i=i. This pattern repeats itself all the time, so we can quickly tell what iⁿ for any positive integer n.

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Performing reflections
description: Sal shows how to perform a reflection on a quadrilateral using our interactive widget!

title: Adding to 10
description: Sal finds out how many bananas we need to add to 3 bananas to make 10 bananas.

title: Acute, right, & obtuse angles
description: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees.  Right angles measure 90 degrees.  Obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.  Learn about angles types and see examples of each.

title: Measuring angles in degrees

title: Exponent properties with products

title: Exponent properties with quotients
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Negative exponents
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Perfect square factorization intro
description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b², then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example, x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

title: Bouncing fruit collision example
description: In this video, David shows how to use conservation of momentum for a situation where two objects bounce off of each other.

title: Momentum: Ice skater throws a ball
description: A simple conservation of momentum problem involving an ice skater and a ball

title: Force vs. time graphs
description: In this video, David explains how to use a force vs. time graph to find impulse and solves an example problem to find the final velocity of a spaceship.

title: Inequality word problems
description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems.

title: Greater than and less than symbols
description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So, 9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are > (greater than or equal to) and < (less than or equal to).

title: Two-step equations intuition
description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples, but you can do it!

title: Intro to two-step equations
description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Worked example: two-step equations
description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2. It takes two steps because he first has to subtract 2 from both sides and then multiply both sides by 4.

title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
description: Let's practice some two step equations, some of which require merging terms and using the distributive property.

title: Vertices & direction of a hyperbola
description: Sal picks the graph of y²/9-x²/4=1 based on the hyperbola's center, direction, & vertices.

title: Vertices & direction of a hyperbola (example 2)
description: Sal matches an equation to a given graph of a hyperbola, based on the hyperbola's direction & vertices.

title: Intro to factors & divisibility
description: Sal explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial, and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.

title: Exponent properties with products
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Exponent properties with parentheses
description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c and (a^b)^c. See WHY they work and HOW to use them.

title: Possessive pronouns
description: Possessive pronouns describe what things belong to which people, like "her shoe" or "the book is mine." Possessive pronouns can be adjectives, like "his bicycle," or they can stand in for nouns, like "the seats are theirs." Neither of these forms should have apostrophes to show possession -- so it's ours (not our's) and yours (not your's).

title: Frequency tables & dot plots
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions: radicals (odd power)
description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of x/√(x²+1). Since the leading term is raised to an odd power (1), the limits at positive and negative infinity are different.

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions: radicals (even power)
description: Limit at infinity of rational expression with radical

title: Ratio word problem: boys to girls
description: Sal solves a tricky ratio word problem.

title: Ratio word problem: centimeters to kilometers
description: Sal uses ratios to figure out how far apart two cities should be on a map.

title: Adding negative numbers example
description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)

title: Adding numbers with different signs
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Understanding division of fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Dividing fractions: 2/5 ÷ 7/3
description: Learn to divide two fractions.  The answer is a fraction.

title: Systems of equations with substitution: -3x-4y=-2 & y=2x-5
description: Learn to solve the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.

title: Evaluating simple definite integral
description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus, we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Adding numbers with different signs
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Equivalent fractions and different wholes
description: Sal shows that two fractions are equivalent only if they refer to the same whole.

title: Expected value while fishing
description: Sal walks through an example where he multiplies probability by values and sums to find expected value.

title: Comparing insurance with expected value
description: Sal uses expected value to compare a couple of different insurance policies.

title: Adding with regrouping
description: Sal adds 35 + 27 thinking about place value.

title: Adding 2-digit numbers without regrouping 2
description: Sal adds 23 + 45 thinking about place value.

title: Integral of cos^3(x)
description: A specialized form of u-substitution involves taking advantage of trigonometric identities.

title: Integral of sin^2(x) cos^3(x)
description: Another example where u substitution combined with certain trigonometric identities can be used.

title: Integral of sin^4(x)
description: It is a bit involved, but we can use u-substitution to find the integral of sin^4(x)

title: Second derivatives
description: Sal finds the second derivative of y=6/x². Second derivative is the derivative of the derivative of y.

title: Worked example: evaluating piecewise functions
description: Evaluating piecewise functions at given inputs, both from a formula and from a graph.

title: Comparing fractions with > and < symbols
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Comparing fractions visually
description: Sal compares fractions by graphing them a number line and drawing fraction models.

title: Comparing fractions with the same numerator
description: Lindsay compares fractions with the same numerator. She compares one pair of fractions with visuals and another pair without visuals.

title: Comparing fractions with the same denominator
description: Lindsay compares fractions with the same denominator. She compares one pair of fractions with visuals and another pair without visuals.

title: Analyzing scalar multiplication
description: Sal analyzes the magnitude and direction of vectors that are a result of scalar multiplication of a vector whose magnitude is given.

title: Introduction to evolution and natural selection
description: Introduction to how groups of organisms evolve and how natural selection can lead to evolution.

title: Applying the Hardy-Weinberg equation
description: Using the Hardy-Weinberg equation to calculate allele and genotype frequencies.

title: Evidence for evolution
description: An overview of the different types of evidence that support evolution, including homologous and analogous features and vestigial structures.

title: Overview of protein structure
description: Primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary protein structure. Beta pleated sheets and alpha helices.

title: Gene expression and function
description:
Visit us (http://www.khanacademy.org/science/healthcare-and-medicine) for health and medicine content or (http://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat) for MCAT related content.  

These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment.
