Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.

title: Circulatory & respiratory systems
description: Hank takes us on a trip around the body - we follow the circulatory and respiratory systems as they deliver oxygen and remove carbon dioxide from cells, and help make it possible for our bodies to function.

title: Thomas Malthus and population growth
description: Thomas Malthus's views on population. Malthusian limits.

title: Flow of energy and matter through ecosystems
description: Seeing how energy and matter flows and is recycled from primary producers (autotrophs) to primary, secondary and tertiary consumers.

title: Worked example: power series from cos(x)
description: Finding a power series to represent x³cos(x²) using the Maclaurin series of cos(x).

title: Worked example: cosine function from power series
description: Given a power series, we recognize it as the Maclaurin series of cos(x³) and evaluate it at a given x-value.

title: Worked example: recognizing function from Taylor series
description: Sample AP Calculus question asking to recognize a function from its Taylor series.

title: Picking fairly
description: Sal determines if a few different methods of a magician choosing a volunteer are fair.

title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the modulus (which is the absolute value) and the argument (which is the angle) of √3/2+1/2*i.

title: Equivalent fraction models
description: Use same-sized wholes to show equivalent fractions.

title: Equivalent fractions with visuals
description: Sal uses same-sized wholes to show equivalent fractions.

title: Worked example: completing the square (leading coefficient ≠ 1)
description: Sal solves the equation 4x^2+40x-300=0 by completing the square.

title: Intro to complex number polar form
description: Sal adjusts the angle and radius of a point to match a number given in rectangular form. This way, we see how the polar form of the number relates to its rectangular form.

title: The Second Great Awakening - origins and major ideas
description: What was the Second Great Awakening? Kim discusses the origins and major ideas behind this period of religious revival in the early nineteenth century in the United States.

title: The Second Great Awakening - influence of the Market Revolution
description: Changes in work, geography, and economics influenced the emergence of the Second Great Awakening. In this video Kim explores some of the social and economic factors in the early nineteenth century that may have led to the religious revival.

title: The Second Great Awakening - reform and religious movements
description: The Second Great Awakening played a role in major reform movements of the nineteenth century, including temperance and abolition. In the last video in this series, Kim discusses some of the new religious movements and reform movements that grew out of the Second Great Awakening.

title: The early temperance movement - origins
description: What started the temperance movement, which attempted to curb the consumption of alcohol in the United States? KA's US history intern Becca discusses the temperance movement of the early 19th century.

title: The early temperance movement - spread and temporary decline
description: What happened to the nineteenth century temperance movement? KA's US history intern Becca discusses the rise of the American Temperance Society, teetotalism, and the temporary pause in the movement that accompanied the Civil War.

title: Intro to line plots
description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Subject, direct object, and indirect object
description: A subject is the noun phrase that drives the action of a sentence; in the sentence “Jake ate cereal,” Jake is the subject. The direct object is the thing that the subject acts upon, so in that last sentence, “cereal” is the direct object; it’s the thing Jake ate. An indirect object is an optional part of a sentence; it’s the recipient of an action. In the sentence “Jake gave me some cereal,” the word “me” is the indirect object; I’m the person who got cereal from Jake.

title: Using explicit formulas of geometric sequences
description: Sal finds the 5th term in the geometric sequence whose explicit formula is 3(-¼)^(i-1).

title: Using recursive formulas of geometric sequences
description: Sal finds the 4th term in the sequence whose recursive formula is a(1)=-⅛, a(i)=2a(i-1).

title: Regrouping with decimals: 0.25
description: Sal regroups 0.25 three different ways.

title: Regrouping with decimals: 21.3
description: Sal regroups 21.3 into various addition problems.

title: Regrouping with decimals: 86.93
description: Sal regroups 86.93 by its place values.

title: Common fractions (halves)
description: Lindsay discovers why 0.5 is equal to 1/2.

title: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2
description: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is larger than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.

title: U.S. customary units: weight
description: Sal discusses US customary units of mass or weight such as ounces, pounds, and tons.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem example
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Coordinating conjunctions
description: Coordinating conjunctions connect parts of sentences to each other. David explains how.

title: Decomposing a fraction visually
description: Sal uses a tape diagram to decompose 7/9.

title: Decomposing a mixed number
description: Sal uses fraction models to decompose 2 1/4.

title: Visually converting tenths and hundredths
description: Sal rewrites 8/10 with a denominator of 100.

title: Planar motion example: acceleration vector
description: The position of a particle moving in the xy-plane is given by the position vector (-3t³+4t²,t³+2). Sal analyzes it to find the acceleration vector of the particle at time t=3.

title: Derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x)
description: Sal finds the derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x) by writing them as quotients of sin(x) and cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x)
description: Sal finds the derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x) by writing them as 1/sin(x) or 1/cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Differentiability at a point: graphical
description: Sal gives a couple of examples where he finds the points on the graphs of a functions where the functions aren't differentiable.

title: Periodicity of algebraic models
description: Sal analyzes the periodicity of graphs that model real world situations.

title: Writing standard equation of a circle
description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane, Sal finds its standard equation, which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².

title: New operator definitions 2
description: Worked examples of working with more newly defined operators.

title: Recognizing fractions greater than 1
description: Lindsay uses fraction models to identify a fraction greater than 1.

title: More about fractions
description: Sal shows fractions as parts of a whole and parts of a group.

title: Intro to fractions
description: Sal divides wholes into equal-sized pieces to create unit fractions.

title: More than one equal section
description: Sal uses fractions to name parts of a whole.

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Adding numbers with different signs
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Subtracting a negative = adding a positive
description: Find out why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding the absolute value of that number.

title: Intro to direct & inverse variation
description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation
description: Sal gives many examples of two-variable equations where the variables vary directly, inversely, or neither.

title: Converting decimals to percents: 0.601
description: Percents can be written in decimal form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So, we divide the percent by 100 to get an equivalent decimal. Then, we remove the percent sign (%). For example, 65% can be converted to decimal form by solving 65÷100. So, 65%=0.65. Another way to think of dividing by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the left.

title: Converting decimals to percents: 1.501
description: Sal converts 1.501 to a percent.

title: Converting percents to decimals & fractions example
description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.

title: Determining invertible matrices
description: Sal shows why a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is not 0.

title: Intro to multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Multiplying decimals word problem
description: We're multiplying decimals again, but this time answering a common question: what's the cost of filling up the car tank?

title: Intro to ellipses
description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Counting unit squares to find area formula
description: Sal uses unit squares to see why multiplying side-lengths can also find the area of rectangles.

title: Transitioning from unit squares to area formula
description: Lindsay finds the area of a rectangle both by counting unit squares and multiplying side lengths.

title: Intro to area and unit squares
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Measuring rectangles with different unit squares
description: Sal finds area of a rectangle with different sized units.

title: Using the quadratic formula: number of solutions
description: Sal determines how many solutions the equation x²+14x+49=0 has by considering its quadratic formula, and more specifically, its discriminant.

title: Run-ons and comma splices
description: A run-on sentence doesn’t separate any of its independent clauses with the punctuation that it needs, and a comma splice incorrectly separates two independent clauses with a comma, instead of a comma-and-coordinating-conjunction.

title: Worked example: sequence convergence/divergence
description: How can we tell if a sequence converges or diverges? See Sal in action, determining the convergence/divergence of several sequences.

title: Adding & subtracting vectors
description: Sal shows how to add vectors by adding their components, then explains the intuition behind adding vectors using a graph.

title: Metric system: units of distance
description: Sal discusses metric units of length or distance such as millimeter, centimeter, meter, and kilometer.

title: Finding reasonable unit of measurement example
description: Sal chooses reasonable units of time activities like baking cookies.

title: Subtracting 1 vs. subtracting 10
description: Sal talks about the difference between subtracting 1 and subtracting 10.

title: Volume of rectangles inside rectangles
description: How many crates can we fit into a boxcar? We'll explain that there's more than one way to solve for the volume in this problem.

title: Volume of triangular prism & cube
description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Surface area of a cuboid
description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid, add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l), width (w), and height (h) of the prism and use the formula, SA=2lw+2lh+2hw, to find the surface area.

title: Adding decimals with ones, tenths and hundredths
description: Sal adds numbers, such as 3.53+4.72, by breaking them down into place values.

title: Adding decimals with hundredths
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to add decimals, such as 0.68+0.33.

title: Adding decimals: 9.087+15.31
description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Adding decimals: 0.822+5.65
description: Sal solves 0.822+5.65 using "standard algorithm".

title: Adding three decimals
description: Sal adds 7.056+605.7+5.67 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Squaring binomials of the form (x+a)²
description: Sal introduces perfect square expressions. For example, (x+7)² is expanded as x²+14x+49.

title: Special products of the form (x+a)(x-a)
description: Sal introduces difference of squares expressions. For example, (x+3)(x-3) is expanded as x²-9.

title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: fishing boat
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.

title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

title: Visualizing equivalent fractions
description: Sal uses fraction models to show equivalent fractions.

title: Intro to equivalent fractions
description: Sal introduces equivalent fractions with pizza.

title: Grammatical person and pronouns
description: There's this idea in grammar called grammatical person that helps describe who's being talked about in a sentence. David, KA's Grammar Fellow, explains.

title: Strategies for subtracting more complex decimals with tenths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals to the tenths place, such as 2-1.2.

title: Strategies for subtracting basic decimals
description: Sal uses place value and a number line to subtract decimals, such as 1.5-0.7.

title: Solving inscribed quadrilaterals
description: Example showing supplementary oppositie angles in inscribed quadrilateral.

title: Inscribed quadrilaterals proof
description: Sal uses the inscribed angle theorem and some algebra to prove that opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.

title: Dividing fractions: 2/5 ÷ 7/3
description: Learn to divide two fractions.  The answer is a fraction.

title: Understanding division of fractions
description: Using a number line, we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Dividing fractions: 3/5 ÷ 1/2
description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions are to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next, multiply the two numerators. Then, multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the fractions if needed.

title: Intro to area and unit squares
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Equation practice with complementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Equation practice with supplementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Adding polynomials: two variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3xy + 25) - (9y²x + 7xy - 20).

title: Introduction to contractions
description: Apostrophes are great at standing in for missing letters, allowing us to shorten words. Paige and David discuss contractions and the Principle of Least Effort.

title: Solving percent problems
description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.

title: Percent word problem: 100 is what percent of 80?
description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

title: Percent word problem: 78 is 15% of what number?
description: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: Number equations & number lines
description: Integer equations to describe diagram

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Volume of a rectangular prism: fractional dimensions
description: Learn how to find the volume of a rectangular prism that has fractional side lengths. The prism in this video has dimensions 3/5 by 1 1/6 by 3/7.

title: Find the mistake: two-step equations
description: When doing algebra, we sometimes make mistakes! It's important to be able to check our own work (and other people's work) for correctness.

title: Introduction to energy
description: Energy is defined as the ability to do work. Energy can be found in many things and can take different forms. For example, kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and potential energy is energy due to an object's position or structure. Energy is never lost, but it can be converted from one form to another.

title: First Law of Thermodynamics introduction
description: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can only be transferred or converted from one form to another.

title: Second Law of Thermodynamics and entropy
description: Second Law of Thermodynamics and entropy: the entropy of the universe constantly increases.

title: Gibbs free energy and spontaneous reactions
description: Gibbs free energy and spontaneous reactions.

title: Reaction coupling to create glucose-6-phosphate
description: Reaction coupling to create glucose-6-phosphate.

title: Enzymes
description: Enzymes as catalysts for reactions in biological systems; discussion of substrates, active sites, induced fit, and activation energy.

title: Enzyme cofactors and coenzymes
description: The cofactors and coenzymes (organic cofactors) that help enzymes catalyze reactions.

title: Competitive inhibition
description: Seeing how an inhibitor can "compete" for an enzyme with the intended substrate.

title: Noncompetitive inhibition
description: Seeing how a noncompetitive inhibitor can bind whether or not the substrate is bound, and vice versa.

title: Area & perimeter word problem: dog pen
description: Sal figures out the width of a dog pen.

title: Area & perimeter word problem: table
description: Sal solves for the dimension of a table.

title: Comparing areas word problem
description: Sal compares the area of two posters using their side-lengths.

title: Reasonable samples
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Area and the distributive property
description: Sal uses the distributive property to find area of rectangles.

title: Intro to area and unit squares
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Counting unit squares to find area formula
description: Sal uses unit squares to see why multiplying side-lengths can also find the area of rectangles.

title: Comparing areas word problem
description: Sal compares the area of two posters using their side-lengths.

title: Place value blocks
description: Lindsay identifies numbers represented by place value blocks.

title: Comparing fractions: tape diagram
description: Sal compares fractions with unlike denominators by drawing bars

title: Comparing fractions: fraction models
description: Sal compares fractions visually with pies

title: Comparing fractions: number line
description: Sal compares fractions on a number line

title: Multiplying fractions word problem: movies
description: Sal solves a multiplication fraction word problem about movies.

title: Multiplying fractions by whole numbers word problem
description: Lindsay solves a word problem that involves multiplying a fraction by a whole number.

title: Multiplying fractions word problem: milk
description: Sal solves a multiplication fraction word problem about milk.

title: Multiplying fractions word problem: pumpkin pie
description: Oops! Someone tried to solve this problem and made a mistake. See if you can spot the error.

title: Multiplying 2-digit by 1-digit
description: Learn to multiply a 2-digit number by a 1-digit number without regrouping.  In this video, we will multiply 32x3.

title: Multiplying 3-digit by 1-digit
description: Learn to multiply a 3-digit number by a 1-digit number without regrouping.  In this video, we will multiply 4x201.

title: Introduction to trigonometric substitution
description: Introduction to trigonometric substitution

title: Substitution with  x=sin(theta)
description: When you are integrating something that has the expression (1-x^2), try substituting sin(theta) for x.

title: More trig sub practice
description: Example of using trig substitution to solve an indefinite integral

title: More trig substitution with tangent
description: Another practice problem replacing x with tan(theta) in an integral.

title: Long trig sub problem
description: More practice with a hairy trig sub problem.

title: Trig substitution with tangent
description: When you are integration something which looks like 1+(x^2), try replacing x with tan(theta)

title: Trig and u substitution together (part 1)
description: All of the substitution!

title: Trig and u substitution together (part 2)
description: More of all of the substitution!

title: Deriving integration by parts formula
description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse, we get a powerful integration tool.

title: Integration by parts: Example 1
description: Integral of x cos(x)

title: Integration by parts: Example 2
description: Integral of ln x

title: Integration by  parts: Example 3
description: Integral of (x^2)(e^x)

title: Integration by parts: Example 4
description: Integral of (e^x)(cos(x))

title: Challenging definite integration
description: A rather difficult integration by parts problem.

title: u-substitution
description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: u-substitution example 2
description: Another example of using u-subsitution

title: u-substitution with exponential function
description: You can never get too much u-substitution practice

title: u-substitution example 3
description: Manipulating the expression to make u-substitution a little more obvious.

title: u-substitution with ln(x)
description: Doing u-substitution with ln(x)

title: (2^(ln x))/x antiderivative example
description: Finding  ∫(2^ln x)/x dx

title: Doing u-substitution twice
description: We do substitution two times to get the integral into a reasonable form

title: u-substitution and back substitution
description: Using u-substitution and "back substituting" for x to simplify an expression

title: Worked example: determining domain word problem (real numbers)
description: Determining the domain of a function that models the height of a plant over time.

title: Worked example: determining domain word problem (positive integers)
description: Determining the domain of a function that models the price of candy bars.

title: Worked example: determining domain word problem (all integers)
description: Determining the domain of a function that models going up and down a ladder.

title: Subtracting rational expressions: factored denominators
description: Sal subtracts two rational expressions whose denominators are factored. The denominators aren't the same but they share a factor.

title: Least common multiple of polynomials
description: Sal finds the least common multiple (LCM) of 3z³-6z²-9z and 7z⁴+21z³+14z².

title: Factoring quadratics: common factor + grouping
description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).

title: Factoring quadratics: negative common factor + grouping
Intro to logarithms
description: Sal explains what logarithms are and gives a few examples of finding logarithms.

title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms
description: Sal rewrites 100=10^2 as a logarithmic equation and log_5(1/125)=-3 as an exponential equation.

title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: graphs
description: Given a few points on the graph of an exponential function, Sal plots the corresponding points on the graph of the corresponding logarithmic function.

title: Relationship between exponentials & logarithms: tables
description: Given incomplete tables of values of b^x and its corresponding inverse function, log_b(y), Sal uses the inverse relationship of the functions to fill in the missing values.

title: Squaring binomials of the form (ax+b)²
description: Sal expands the perfect square (7x+10)² as 49x^2+140x+100.

title: Special products of the form (ax+b)(ax-b)
description: Sal expand the difference of squares (2x+8)(2x-8) as 4x²-64.

title: Special products of binomials: two variables
description: Sal finds the area of a square with side (6x-5y).

title: More examples of special products
description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.

title: Rounding to nearest 10
description: Learn to use a number line to round 2-digit numbers to the nearest ten.

title: Rounding to nearest 100
description: Learn to use a number line to round 3-digit numbers to the nearest hundred.

title: Rounding to nearest 10 and 100
description: Learn to round up to 4-digit numbers to the nearest ten and hundred.

title: Measuring area with partial unit squares
description: Lindsay finds the area of a shape by counting whole and partial unit squares.

title: Intro to area and unit squares
description: Sal covers figures with square units to find their area.

title: Worked example: matching an input to a function's output (graph)
description: Sal finds the input value for which g(x)=-2 given the graph of g.

title: Worked example: two inputs with the same output (graph)
description: Sal finds the input value other than -5 for which f(x)=f(-5), given the graph of f.

title: Intro to multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Developing strategies for multiplying decimals
description: Sal uses place value and equivalent fractions to multiply decimals.

title: Multiplying decimals: place value
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Finding missing side length when given perimeter
description: Lindsay finds missing side lengths on polygons when given all other side lengths and the perimeter.

title: Perimeter: introduction
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Perimeter of a shape
description: Sal finds perimeter of various shapes.

title: Naming angles
description: Sal names angles based on their vertex and endpoints.

title: Angles: introduction
description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle, like the vertex.

title: Understanding volume (liters)
description: Sal talks about what volume means. He also examines the volume of real objects in liters.

title: Metric system: units of volume
description: Learn about metric units of volume or capacity such as milliliter and liter.

title: Finding reasonable unit of measurement example
description: Sal chooses reasonable units of time activities like baking cookies.

title: Long division: 280÷5
description: Learn to divide 280÷5 with long division.  The answer wil not have a remainder.

title: Intro to long division (no remainders)
description: Watch an introduction to long division with the problem 96÷4.

title: Time differences example
description: Learn to find the difference between the times shown on two different analog clocks.

title: Telling time to the nearest minute (labeled clock)
description: Lindsay reads the time on labeled analog clocks to the nearest minute.

title: Direct comparison test
description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series, it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

title: Worked example: direct comparison test
description: Using the direct comparison test to determine that the infinite sum of 1/(2ⁿ+n) converges by comparing it to the infinite sum 1/2ⁿ.

title: Differential equations introduction
description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Worked example: linear solution to differential equation
description: If a particular solution to a differential equation is linear, y=mx+b, we can set up a system of equations to find m and b. See how it works in this video.

title: Dividing whole numbers by fractions: word problem
description: Learn to solve a word problem that involves dividing a whole number by a unit fraction.

title: Dividing whole numbers & fractions: t-shirts
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Worked example: Maclaurin polynomial
description: Finding the second degree Maclaurin polynomial of 1/√(x+1).

title: Worked example: coefficient in Maclaurin polynomial
description: Finding the coefficient of the x² term in a Maclaurin polynomial, given the formula for the value of any derivative at x=0.

title: Worked example: coefficient in Taylor polynomial
description: Finding the coefficient of the term containing (x+2)⁴ in the Taylor polynomial centered at x=-2 of x⁶-x³.

title: Decomposing shapes to find area: grids
description: Lindsay finds the area of an irregular shape by decomposing it into 2 rectangles.

title: Area word problem: house size
description: Sal decomposes an irregular shape to find area of entire figure.

title: Basic trig and exponential antiderivatives
description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x) and e^x?

title: Antiderivative of x^-1
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Multiplying 1-digit numbers by multiples of 10, 100, and 1000
description: Lindsay finds a pattern from multiplying 1-digit numbers by multiples of 10, 100, and 1000.

title: Multiplying 1-digit numbers by 10, 100, and 1000
description: Lindsay finds a pattern from multiplying 1-digit numbers by 10, 100, and 1000.

title: Finding the constant of integration: rational function
description: Sal finds f(-1) given that f'(x)=24/x³ and f(2)=12.

title: Finding the constant of integration: exponential function
description: Sal finds f(0) given that f'(x)=5eˣ and f(7)=40+5e⁷.

title: Finding area with fractional sides 1
description: Sal finds the area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths.

title: Finding area with fractional sides 2
description: Sal discusses intuition for area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths.

title: Multiplying 2 fractions: 5/6 x 2/3
description:
How to multiply fractions?

The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally, simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.

title: Creating an equation with no solutions
description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

title: Creating an equation with infinitely many solutions
description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides
description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

title: Equations with variables on both sides: 20-7x=6x-6
description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.

title: Solving for a side with the law of cosines
description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Solving for an angle with the law of cosines
description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure, and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.

title: Definite integral properties (graphical, 1 of 2)
description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Definite integral properties (graphical, 2 of 2)
description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Riemann sums and integrals
description: The moment you've been waiting for.  Here we connect the idea of Riemann sums with integrals.

title: Ranking area estimates
description: A good way to test your understanding of Riemann sums is to rank the values of various different sums.

title: Evaluating a function defined by an integral
description: Sal explains how to use a graph to evaluate a function defined by an integral.

title: Functions defined by integrals: switched interval
description: Sal evaluates a function defined by the integral of a graphed function. In order to evaluate he must switch the sides of the interval.

title: Riemann approximation introduction
description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: A more general Riemann sum
description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Riemann sum with sigma notation
description: Here we express the approximation of the area under a curve in sigma notation.

title: Riemann sum when function is negative
description: When a function is negative, Riemann sums seem to treat it as having "negative area".

title: Comparing multi-digit numbers
description: Lindsay compares multi-digit numbers such as 350,000 and 53,000.

title: Motion along a curve: finding rate of change
description: Given that a particle moves along the implicit curve x²y²=16 and given its rate of change with respect to x at some point, Sal finds the particle's rate of change with respect to y using implicit differentiation.

title: Motion along a curve: finding velocity magnitude
description: Given that a particle moves along the implicit curve xy=16 and given its rate of change with respect to y at some point, Sal finds the magnitude of the particle's velocity vector using implicit differentiation.

title: Definite integral of piecewise function
description: Sal evaluates definite integral of a piecewise function over an interval that goes through the two cases of the function.

title: Definite integral of absolute value function
description: Sal evaluates the definite integral of f(x)=|x+2| between -4 and 0.

title: Word problems with mass
description: Sal solves word problems involving mass.  Estimate the mass of items.

title: Understanding mass (grams and kilograms)
description: Sal talks about what mass means. He also examines the masses of real objects in grams and kilograms.

title: Comparing fractions with the same numerator
description: Lindsay compares fractions with the same numerator. She compares one pair of fractions with visuals and another pair without visuals.

title: Comparing fractions with > and < symbols
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Classifying quadrilaterals
description: Sal classifies quadrilaterals by their properties (such as parallel sides).

title: Comparing fractions of different wholes 1
description: Sal shades visual fraction models to compare fractions.

title: Comparing fractions of different wholes 2
description: Sal compares fractions of different wholes

title: More ways to multiply
description: Sal uses place value, the distributive property, associative property, and an area model to show more ways to multiply.

title: How to convert kg to mg and T to oz
description: Sal converts kilograms to milligrams and tons to ounces.

title: Worked example: matching an input to a function's output (equation)
description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13, given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Intro to quadrilaterals
description: Sal discovers attributes and features of four-sided shapes, including parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.

title: Intro to significant figures
description: Significant figures refers to the number of important single digits in a value, often a measurement.  This video is an introduction to significant figures.

title: Rules of significant figures
description: Learn the "rules of thumb" for significant figures.

title: Graphing absolute value functions
description: We can graph any equation of the form y=k|x-a|+h by thinking about function transformations (shifts, reflections, and scalings).

title: Relating division to multiplication
description: Sal talks about the relationship between multiplication and division problems.

title: Counting unit squares to find area formula
description: Sal uses unit squares to see why multiplying side-lengths can also find the area of rectangles.

title: Creating picture and bar graphs 1
description: Sal creates and interprets bar and picture graphs.

title: Adding fractions with like denominators
description: Sal adds 3/15+7/15.

title: Intro to remainders
description: Sal shows how a remainder is what's left over in a division problem.

title: Writing exponential functions
description: Writing the exponential function whose initial value is -2 and common ratio is 1/7.

title: Finding inverse of a 2x2 matrix using determinant & adjugate
description: Sal gives an example of how to find the inverse of a given 2x2 matrix.

title: Volume of a sphere
description: The formula for the volume of a sphere is V = 4/3 πr³. See the formula used in an example where we are given the diameter of the sphere.

title: Trig values of special angles
description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: Comparing distributions with dot plots (example problem)
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Lines, line segments, & rays
description: Learn the difference between lines, line segments, and rays.

title: Sinusoidal function from graph
description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2,-5) and the maximum point (2,1) are highlighted.

title: Simplifying rational expressions: common monomial factors
description: Sal simplifies the rational expressions (14x²+7x)/(14x) and (17z³+17z²)/(34z³-51z²) by taking common factors and canceling them.

title: Related rates: circle radius & area
description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes, and how fast its area changes?

title: Antiderivative of hairier expression
description: In this example, we find the antiderivative an expression which is not so simple.

title: Negative number word problem: Alaska
description: In this video, we figure out the temperature in Fairbanks, Alaska by adding and subtracting negative numbers.

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: nth term divergence test
description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero, the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

title: Slope-intercept equation from slope & point
description: Learn how to find the equation of the line with a slope of -3/4 that goes through the point (0,8).

title: Slope-intercept equation from two points
description: Learn how to find the equation of the line that goes through the points (-1, 6) and (5, -4).

title: Normal distribution problem: z-scores (from ck12.org)
description: Z-score practice

title: More empirical rule and z-score practice (from ck12.org)
description: More Empirical Rule and Z-score practice

title: Finding features of quadratic functions
description: Sal finds the zeros, the vertex, & the line of symmetry of quadratic functions given in vertex form, factored form, & standard form.

title: Coordinate plane graphing word problem
description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

title: Triangle angle challenge problem 2
description: Example of angle hunting!

title: Worked example: Triangle angles (intersecting lines)
description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles formed by intersecting lines

title: Triangle angle example
description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Infinite geometric series as a limit
description: Sal applies limits to the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series to get the sum of an infinite geometric series.

title: Interpreting numeric expressions example
description: Sal chooses the correct interpretation of the integer expression 3 + (-7).

title: Graphing hundredths from 0 to 0.1
description: Lindsay graphs 0.04 on a number line.

title: Identifying hundredths on a number line
description: Lindsay identifies decimals graphed on a number line.

title: Plotting decimal numbers on a number line
description: Sal finds decimals with hundredths on a number line.

title: Comparing decimal numbers on a number line
description: Sal compares decimals on a number line.

title: Percent word problem: recycling cans
description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

title: Percent word problem: penguins
description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.

title: Percent word problem: 100 is what percent of 80?
description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

title: Percent word problem: 78 is 15% of what number?
description: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: Percent word problem: guavas
description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.

title: Multiplying 10s
description: Lindsay multiplies multiples of 10 by other multiples of 10, such as 30x50.

title: Fraction to decimal with rounding
description: Sal writes 16/21 as a rounded decimal.

title: Worked example: Converting a fraction (7/8) to a decimal
description: Learn how to write the fraction, 7/8 as a decimal.

title: Fraction to decimal: 11/25
description: Sal writes 11/25 as a decimal.

title: Rewriting tricky fractions to decimals
description: Learn to convert the fraction, 17/93 to a decimal.

title: Area of a parallelogram
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Discontinuities of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes two rational functions to find their vertical asymptotes & removable discontinuities. He distinguishes those from the zeros of the functions.

title: Visually determining antiderivative
description: Given the graph of a function, can you identify the graph of its antiderivative?

title: Graphs of indefinite integrals
description: More practice identifying the graph of the antiderivative of a function.

title: Subtraction strategies with hundredths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals, such as 65.79-42.58.

title: More advanced subtraction strategies with hundredths
description: Sal uses place value and numbers in expanded form to subtract decimal to hundredths, such as 8.38-4.54.

title: Solving ratio problems with tables example 1
description: We're displaying ratios in a table format here, and then asking: given a ratio, solve for equivalent ratios. Here are a few examples to practice on.

title: Solving ratio problems with tables example 2
description: Let's compare 2 tables of ratios and interpret them to solve the word problem. This is a fun!

title: Solving ratio problems with graph
description: In this example we'll plot points on the x and y axis to reflect the given ratios.

title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 4
description: How may times have you been told, "Save your money!" We thought so. What if you wanted to save a fractional amount of your allowance? How would you go about figuring out how much to save?

title: Equivalent fractions
description: Learn how to write equivalent fractions.

title: Reflexive pronouns
description: Reflexive pronouns, like "myself" or "herself," show when the object of a sentence is also the subject of a sentence. Examples include "I saw myself in the mirror" or "We bought ourselves a snack at the farmer's market."

title: Multiplying a decimal by a power of 10
description: Learn to multiply 0.44 times 1000 using powers of 10.

title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10
description: Sal talks about why moving the decimal point to the left when dividing by a power of 10 makes sense.

title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10: pattern
description: Discover a pattern when dividing by powers of 10.

title: Counting objects 2
description: Learn to count dogs, mice, and cookies in random patterns.

title: Parametric functions differentiation
description: Sal finds the derivative of the function defined by the parametric equations x=sin(1+3t) and y=2t³, and evaluates it at t=-⅓.

title: Exponential functions differentiation intro
description: Sal finds the derivative of aˣ (for any positive base a) using the derivative of eˣ and the chain rule. He then differentiates 8⋅3ˣ.

title: Two-way relative frequency tables
description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: End behavior of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of several rational functions, that together cover all cases types of end behavior.

title: Volume of a rectangular prism: word problem
description: Sal explains how to find the volume of a rectangular prism fish tank that has fractional side lengths.

title: Power series of ln(1+x³)
description: We can represent ln(1+x³) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

title: Power series of arctan(2x)
description: We can represent arctan(2x) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

title: Finding function from power series by integrating
description: When a power series S₁ is an antiderivative of a geometric series S₂, we can find the function represented by S₁ by integrating the expression for S₂.

title: Slope from equation
description: Worked examples of finding the slope of a line given its equation, using many forms of equations.

title: GCF & LCM word problems
description: Here we have a couple of word problems--one searching for the least common multiple and the other for the greatest common factor. Just read them with us slowly and follow along. You'll get it.

title: Identifying an angle
description: Sal matches pictures of angles to their degrees.

title: Why dividing by zero is undefined
description: As much as we would like to have an answer for "what's 1 divided by 0?" it's sadly impossible to have an answer. The reason, in short, is that whatever we may answer, we will then have to agree that that answer times 0 equals to 1, and that cannot be ​true, because anything times 0 is 0.

title: U.S. customary units: distance
description: Sal discusses US customary units of length or distance such as inch, foot, and yard.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
description: If we compare linear and exponential growth, we will see that over time, *any* exponential growth will surpass *any* linear growth, no matter how steep it is.

title: Writing exponential functions from tables
description: Writing a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a⋅rˣ, given a table of values of those functions.

title: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers
description: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers

title: Division with area models
description: Sal uses area models to divide 268÷2 and 856÷8.

title: U.S. customary units: fluid volume
description: Sal discusses US customary units of volume or capacity such as teaspoon, fluid ounce, cup, pint, quart, and gallon.

title: Related rates: water pouring into a cone
description: As you pour water into a cone, how does the rate of change of the depth of the water relate to the rate of change in volume.

title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors
description: Sal divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.

title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors (example 2)
description: Sal divides (7x^6+x^3+2x+1) by X^2, and writes the solution as q(x)+r(x)/x^2, where the degree of the remainder, r(x), is less than the degree of x^2.

title: Intro to long division of polynomials
description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding how to rewrite quotients like that is *polynomial long division*.

title: Word problem: making change
description: Sal solves how much change Charles will get after his purchase.

title: Currency conversion word problem
description: Sal converts between American dollars and Chinese yuan.

title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-2
description:
We can use logarithms to solve *any* exponential equation of the form a⋅bᶜˣ=d. For example, this is how you can solve 3⋅10²ˣ=7:
1. Divide by 3: 10²ˣ=7/3
2. Use the definition of logarithm: 2x=log(7/3)
3. Divide by 2: x=log(7/3)/2 Now you can use a calculator to find the solution of the equation as a rounded decimal number
​

title: Choosing kinematic equations
description: How to set up problems with constant acceleration and choose the best kinematic equation to solve for the target unknown.

title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions
description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.

title: Linear equations word problem: marbles
description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone filling a glass tank with marbles. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations word problem: file transfer
description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing a top secret file transfer. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Isosceles & equilateral triangles problems
description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving, by Richard Rusczyk).

title: Scatter plots: studying, shoe size, and test scores
description: Sal answers a question about scatter plots that show the relationship between study time, shoe size, and test score.

title: Scatter plot: smokers
description: Sal chooses the scatter plot that shows that smoking rate drops by 0.5 point each year.

title: Intro to the trigonometric ratios
description: Sal introduces sine, cosine, and tangent, and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Trigonometric ratios in right triangles
description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.

title: Variation in a species
description: How variation can be introduced into a species.

title: Introduction to evolution and natural selection
description: Introduction to how groups of organisms evolve and how natural selection can lead to evolution.

title: Genetic drift, bottleneck effect, and founder effect
description: Learn how chance events can alter allele frequencies in populations, particularly when the populations are small, via genetic drift, the bottleneck effect, and the founder effect.

title: Speciation
description: Learn about speciation, including allopatric and sympatric speciation and mechanisms of reproductive isolation.

title: Exponent properties with quotients
description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Converting recursive & explicit forms of arithmetic sequences
description: Sal is given an arithmetic sequence in explicit form and he converts it to recursive form. Then he does so the other way around!

title: Intro to square roots
description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Understanding square roots
description: Learn how square root means what number multiplied by itself will result in the given number.

title: Intro to reflective symmetry
description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Intro to rotational symmetry
description: Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.

title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries
description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0,9) and (3,4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries (example 2)
description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4,-2) and (0,5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Comparing linear functions word problem: climb
description: Sal is given the formula and a table of values that represent two people climbing a wall, and is asked to determine which one started out higher.

title: Comparing linear functions word problem: walk
description: Sal is given a table of values that represents four people walking to school, and is asked to determine which one started out farther from the school.

title: Comparing linear functions word problem: work
description: Sal is given a table of values that represents a person walking to work, and is asked to determine which verbal description represents someone starting at the same distance from work.

title: Multiplying monomials to find area: two variables
description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4xy and width 2y as a monomial.

title: Multiplying monomials challenge
description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (3x^a)(bx^4)=-24x^6 true for all x-values.

title: Fallacies: Fallacy of Composition
description:
In this video, Paul Henne describes the fallacy of composition, an informal fallacy that arises when we assume that some whole has the same properties as its parts. He also discusses why there aren't colorless cats.

Speaker: Paul Henne, Duke University

title: Fallacies: Fallacy of Division
description:
In this video, Paul Henne describes the fallacy of division, the informal fallacy that arises when we assume that the parts of some whole must have the same properties as the whole they make up. He also discusses why water molecules aren't wet. 

Speaker: Paul Henne, Duke University

title: Functions continuous on all real numbers
description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous on all real numbers: eˣ and/or √x. In general, the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Functions continuous at specific x-values
description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous at x=3: ln(x-3) and/or eˣ⁻³. In general, the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Line of best fit: smoking in 1945
description: Sal estimates the percentage of American adults who smoked in 1945 using a scatter plot.

title: Graphing a circle from its standard equation
description: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.

title: Two-variable inequalities from their graphs
description: Sal is given a graph and he analyzes it to find the two-variable inequality it represents.

title: Factors and multiples: days of the week
description: Sal uses factors and multiples to figure out days of the week.

title: Math patterns: table
description: Sal explains a pattern with the number of seats at a table.

title: Math patterns: toothpicks
description: Sal explores a pattern of creating figures with toothpicks.

title: Combination example: 9 card hands
description: Thinking about how many ways we can construct a hand of 9 cards

title: Finding the point not graphed
description: Some of the given ordered pairs are already graphed on the coordinate pane in this example, but not all of them. Can you tell which haven't?

title: Plotting a point (ordered pair)
description: We're plotting an ordered pair on the x (horizontal) axis and y (vertical) axis of the coordinate plane.

title: Points on the coordinate plane examples
description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points, lines, and more.

title: Introduction to adding decimals: tenths
description: Sal adds tenths, like 0.1+0.8 using visuals and place value.

title: Adding decimals with ones and tenths parts
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to add decimals, such as 4+5.7.

title: Telling time (labeled clock)
description: Sal tells time on a labeled analog clock.

title: Writing decimal numbers shown in grids
description: Sal uses grid diagrams to determine what decimal is represented by a shaded area.

title: Drawing acute, right and obtuse angles
description: Learn how to draw acute, right, and obtuse angles with given points.

title: Exponents and powers of 10 patterns
description: Now that we understand how to interpret an exponent and how the patterns in zeros are related to the exponent, we can solve more complicated problems!

title: Multiplying a decimal by a power of 10
description: Learn to multiply 0.44 times 1000 using powers of 10.

title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10
description: Sal talks about why moving the decimal point to the left when dividing by a power of 10 makes sense.

title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10: pattern
description: Discover a pattern when dividing by powers of 10.

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Determining translations
description: Sal is given two triangles on the coordinate plane, and determines the translation that maps one of them into the other.

title: Division using place value
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to divide 5600÷8 and 846÷2.

title: Verifying inverse functions by composition
description: Sal composes f(x)=(x+7)³-1 and g(x)=∛(x+1)-7, and finds that f(g(x))=g(f(x))=x, which means the functions are inverses!

title: Verifying inverse functions by composition: not inverse
description: Sal composes f(x)=2x-3 and g(x)=½x+3, and finds that f(g(x)) ≠ g(f(x)) ≠ x, which means the functions are not inverses.

title: Decomposing hundredths
description: Sal decomposes 47/100 into tenths and hundredths.

title: Decomposing hundredths on number line
description: Sal decomposes 26/100 into tenths and hundredths using a number line.

title: Multiplying fractions by whole numbers on a number line
description: Sal multipiies fractions by whole numbers using the number line

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers 1
description: Sal uses two approaches to multiply 2/3x6.

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers visually
description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers 2
description: Sal relates mixed numbers to whole number/fraction multiplication problem.

title: Worked example: exponential solution to differential equation
description: The solution of the general differential equation dy/dx=ky (for some k) is C⋅eᵏˣ (for some C). See how this is derived and used for finding a particular solution to a differential equation.

title: Multiplying 2-digit numbers
description: Learn to multiply two-digit numbers.  In this video, we will multiply 36 times 27.

title: Finding missing side when given area
description: Lindsay finds the missing side length on a rectangle when given the area of the rectangle.

title: Power rule
description: Sal introduces the power rule, which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Justifying the power rule
description: Before actually proving the power rule, Sal shows why the power rule makes sense by considering the derivatives of x¹ and x².

title: Derivatives of sin(x), cos(x), tan(x), eˣ & ln(x)
description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Chain rule introduction
description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words, it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example, sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x², we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Differentiating composite functions 3
description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=√(3x²-x) using the chain rule.

title: Derivative of sin(ln(x²))
description: Sal differentiates sin(ln(x²)) by applying the chain rule twice.

title: Area of a parallelogram on the coordinate plane
description: Learn how to find the area of a parallelogram on the coordinate plane.

title: Comparing areas and perimeters of rectangles
description: Sal compares the areas and perimeters of rectangles to a given rectangle.

title: Alternating series test
description: When a series alternates (plus, minus, plus, minus,...) there's a fairly simple way to determine whether it converges or diverges: see if the terms of the series approach 0.

title: Conditional & absolute convergence
description: "Absolute convergence" means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term, while "Conditional convergence" means the series converges but not absolutely.

title: Worked example: alternating series
description: Example using the alternating series test to determine which values of a variable will make the series converge.

title: Making predictions with probability
description: Predict the number of times a spinner will land on an elephant.

title: Perfect progressive aspect
description: We use the perfect progressive aspect to talk about an action that was once ongoing, but has since completed, like "I had been waiting for twenty minutes."

title: Nested fractions
description: Sal starts with a simple case of multiplying two fractions and proceeds to simplifying a nested fraction expression.

title: Classifying shapes by line and angles types
description: Sal categorizes shapes based on their sides and angles.

title: Classifying shapes by lines and angles
description: Lindsay classifies a shape based on hints about its sides and angles.

title: Classifying triangles
description: Learn to categorize triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Worked example: Classifying triangles
description: Work through sample problems categorizing triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, or obtuse.

title: Absolute value & angle of complex numbers
description: Sal finds the modulus (which is the absolute value) and the argument (which is the angle) of √3/2+1/2*i.

title: Simplifying exponential expressions
description: Sal simplifies the expression 10*9^(0.5t+2)*5^(3t) as 810*375^t.

title: Multiplying decimals: place value
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Multiplying decimals example
description: To multiply decimals, first multiply as if there is no decimal. Next, count the number of digits after the decimal in each factor. Finally, put the same number of digits behind the decimal in the product. For example, if we multiply 7.61✕9.2, we will have 3 digits behind the decimal in our product because there are 3 digits behind the decimals in the factors.

title: Multiplying challenging decimals
description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

title: Congruent line segments
description: Let's take line segments a little further. How do we know if line segments are congruent? Let's watch this example of counting points to see if they have the exact same length.

title: Introduction to piecewise functions
description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules, like "for every x, return x²." However, there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example, "If x<0, return 2x, and if x≥0, return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*, because their rules aren't uniform, but consist of multiple pieces

title: Worked example: graphing piecewise functions
description: Graphing a piecewise function given its formula. In this case, the function consists of three separate lines.

title: Dividing a decimal by a whole number
description: Sal shows how to keep track of the decimal point when dividing a decimal by a whole number.

title: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2
description: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is larger than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.

title: Dividing a whole number by a decimal
description: When dividing a whole number by a decimal, you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.

title: Adding fractions (denominators 10 & 100)
description: Sal adds 3/10+7/100 by finding a common denominator.

title: Identifying unit fractions word problem
description: Lindsay solves a word problem by using a unit fraction.

title: Intro to fractions
description: Sal divides wholes into equal-sized pieces to create unit fractions.

title: Multiplying rational expressions: multiple variables
description: Sal multiplies and simplifies (3x²y)/(2ab) X (14a²b)/(18xy²).

title: Dividing rational expressions: unknown expression
description: Sal finds the polynomial D for which (20y²-80)/D ÷ (4y²-8y)/(y³+9y²)=1 is true for all values of y for which it's defined.

title: Worked example: convergent geometric series
description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series 8+8/3+8/9+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is less than 1, the series converges to a finite number.

title: Worked example: divergent geometric series
description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series -0.5+1.5-4.5+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is greater than 1, the series doesn't converge.

title: Arc length from subtended angle
description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Subtended angle from arc length
description: Watch Sal solve an example where he finds the central angle given arc length.

title: Factor with the distributive property
description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor numerical expressions (no variables).

title: Distributive property over addition
description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.

title: Distributive property over subtraction
description: Learn how to apply the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive property or distributive law.

title: Worked example: absolute value equation with two solutions
description: Solving the equation 8|x+7|+4 = -6|x+7|+6 which has two possible solutions.

title: Worked example: absolute value equations with one solution
description: Solving the equation |3x-9|=0 which has a single possible solution.

title: Worked example: absolute value equations with no solution
description: Solving the equation 4|x+10|+4 = 6|x+10|+10 to find that it has no possible solution.

title: End behavior of algebraic models
description: Sal analyzes the end behavior of graphs that model real world situations.

title: Interpreting change in exponential models: changing units
description: Sal analyzes the rate of change of various exponential models for different time units by manipulating the functions that model the situations.

title: Intro to vectors & scalars
description: Distance, displacement, speed and velocity. Difference between vectors and scalars.

title: Position vs. time graphs
description: Learn how to read a position vs. time graph. He then explains how to use the graph to determine the following quantities: displacement, distance, average velocity, average speed, instantaneous velocity, and instantaneous speed.

title: Calculating average velocity or speed
description: Although speed and velocity are often words used interchangeably, in physics, they are distinct concepts. Speed is calculated by dividing the distance traveled by time. It does not have direction. Average velocity is the displacement (change in position) divided by time.

title: Acceleration
description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: Airbus A380 take-off time
description: Figuring how long it takes an a380 to take off given a constant acceleration

title: Airbus A380 take-off distance
description: How long of a runway does an A380 need?

title: Average velocity for constant acceleration
description: Calculating average velocity when acceleration is constant

title: Deriving displacement as a function of time, acceleration, and initial velocity
description: Deriving displacement as a function of time, constant acceleration and initial velocity

title: Plotting projectile displacement, acceleration, and velocity
description: Plotting projectile displacement, acceleration, and velocity as a function to change in time

title: Impact velocity from given height
description: Determining how fast something will be traveling upon impact when it is released from a given height

title: Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals
description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Indefinite integrals of x raised to a power
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Antiderivative of x^-1
description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Basic trig and exponential antiderivatives
description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x), cos(x) and e^x?

title: Antiderivative of hairier expression
description: In this example, we find the antiderivative an expression which is not so simple.

title: Number of solutions to equations
description: See how some equations have one solution, others have no solutions, and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Worked example: number of solutions to equations
description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.

title: Introduction to minimum and maximum points
description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points, both absolute and relative.

title: Identifying relative minimum and maximum values
description: Sal analyzes graphs of functions to find relative extremum points.

title: Finding absolute extrema on a closed interval
description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1,4].

title: Concavity introduction
description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity, what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down," and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Analyzing concavity (graphical)
description: Sal walks through an exercise where you are asked to recognize the concavity of a function in certain regions.

title: Sketching graphs using calculus (example 1)
description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Optimization: sum of squares
description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Optimization: box volume (Part 1)
description: If you are making a box out of a flat piece of cardboard, how do you maximize the volume of that box?

title: Optimization: box volume (Part 2)
description: Finishing up the last video by working through the formulas.

title: Complementary & supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Vertical angles
description: By using our knowledge of supplementary, adjacent, and vertical angles, we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

title: Compound probability of independent events
description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events, or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind, too, that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Free-throw probability
description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal how to determine the probability of making 10 free throws in a row. Hint: the answer is surprising!

title: Probability without equally likely events
description: Up until now, we've looked at probabilities surrounding only equally likely events. What about probabilities when we don't have equally likely events? Say, we have unfair coins?

title: Independent events example: test taking
description: Have you ever taken a test and discovered you have no choice but to guess on a couple of problems? In this example problem, we are considering the probability of two independent events occurring.

title: Die rolling probability with independent events
description: We hope you're not a gambler, but if you had to bet on whether you can roll even numbers three times in a row, you might want to figure this probability first.

title: Three-pointer vs free-throw probability
description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier, LeBron James, asks Sal if there's a high probability of making three free throws in a row or one three-pointer. Before solving the problem, jot down what you think the answer will be!

title: Atomic radius trends on periodic table
description: How atomic radius is defined, and trends across a period and down a group.

title: Atomic and ionic radii
description: Explaining group and period trends in atomic and ionic radii.

title: Electronegativity
description: Defines electronegativity and compares to electron affinity. Explains group and period trends in electronegativity using atomic radii.

title: Electronegativity and bonding
description: Electronegativity differences in bonding using the Pauling scale. Classifying bonds as covalent, polar covalent, or ionic.

title: Ionization energy trends
description: Definition of ion and ionization energy, and trends in ionization energy across a period and down a group.

title: Cell size
description: Thinking about the limiting factors of cell size. Focus on volume to surface area ratio.

title: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

title: Overview of animal and plant cells
description: Overview of animal and plant cells. Topics include cell walls, vacuoles, chloroplasts, peroxisomes, lysosomes, mitochondria, etc.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi bodies
description: Structure of the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body (Golgi apparatus). Their role in protein secretion.

title: Endomembrane system
description: An overview of the membrane-bound structures that form the endomembrane system in eukaryotic cells.

title: Mitochondria
description: Visit us (http://www.khanacademy.org/science/healthcare-and-medicine) for health and medicine content or (http://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat) for MCAT related content. These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.
