title: Extracellular matrix
description: Overview of how cells interact with the extracellular matrix.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi bodies
description: Structure of the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body (Golgi apparatus). Their role in protein secretion.

title: Endomembrane system
description: An overview of the membrane-bound structures that form the endomembrane system in eukaryotic cells.

title: Mitochondria
description: The structure and role of mitochondria (plural for mitochondrion). Outer membrane, inner membrane, cristae, porins, etc.

title: The cytoskeleton
description: Exploring the cell cytoskeleton, including microfilaments and microtubules (with a brief mention of intermediate filaments).

title: Intro to theoretical probability
description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Simple probability: yellow marble
description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag, we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes, and then how many of them meet our constraints.

title: Simple probability: non-blue marble
description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

title: Finding probablity example 3
description: Now we're working out the probability of randomly selecting a yellow marble from a bag of multi-colored marbles. Let's practice together.

title: Triangle angle example
description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Worked example: Triangle angles (intersecting lines)
description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles formed by intersecting lines

title: Worked example: Triangle angles (diagram)
description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles that are part of diagrams

title: Triangle angle challenge problem 2
description: Example of angle hunting!

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.

title: Multi-step inequalities
description: Sal solves several multi-step linear inequalities.

title: Inequalities with variables on both sides
description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9, draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.

title: Two-step inequality word problem: R&B
description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.

title: Two-step inequality word problem: apples
description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.

title: Introduction to ratios
description: What a ratio is. Simple ratio problems.

title: Ratios as fractions
description: How are fractions and ratios the same? How are they different? Is 2:5 the same as 2/5?

title: Subtraction strategies with hundredths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals, such as 65.79-42.58.

title: More advanced subtraction strategies with hundredths
description: Sal uses place value and numbers in expanded form to subtract decimal to hundredths, such as 8.38-4.54.

title: Prime numbers
description: Prime numbers are numbers that are only divisible by themselves and 1. Learn more about their properties, and see some examples.

title: Recognizing prime and composite numbers
description: Can you recognize the prime numbers in this group of numbers? Which are prime, composite, or neither?

title: Division strategies for decimal quotients
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value and fractions to introduce dividing with decimals.

title: Multi-digit division strategies for decimals
description: Sal uses understanding of place value, expanded form, and fractions to help divide with decimals.

title: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Regrouping whole numbers: 675
description: Sal regroups 675 into various addition problems.

title: Regrouping whole numbers: 76,830
description: Sal regroups 76,830 by its place values.

title: Regrouping whole numbers: 430
description: Sal regroups 430 five different ways.

title: Squeeze theorem intro
description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers, and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k), then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0, by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Using the squeeze theorem
description: An example applying the squeeze theorem.

title: Worked example: finite geometric series (sigma notation)
description: Sal evaluates the geometric series Σ2(3ᵏ) for k=0 to 99 using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Worked examples: finite geometric series
description: Sal evaluates three geometric series (defined in various ways) using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Creating equivalent fractions
description: Sal creates equivalent fractions by dividing a fraction model and number line into smaller parts.

title: Equivalent fraction visually
description: Sal uses number lines and fraction models to show equivalent fractions.

title: Differentiability at a point: algebraic (function is differentiable)
description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case, the function is both continuous and differentiable.

title: Differentiability at a point: algebraic (function isn't differentiable)
description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case, the function is continuous but not differentiable.

title: Subtracting decimals: 9.57-8.09
description: Sal subtracts 9.57-8.09 using "standard algorithm".

title: Subtracting decimals: 10.1-3.93
description: Sal subtracts 10.1-3.93 using "standard algorithm".

title: Worked example: identifying separable equations
description: Separable equations can be written in the form dy/dx=f(x)g(y). See how we analyze various differential equations to see if they are separable.

title: Worked example: finding a particular solution to a separable equation
description: Solving a separable differential equation given initial conditions. In this video, the equation is dy/dx=2y² with y(1)=1.

title: Worked example: separable equation with an implicit solution
description: Sometimes the solution of a separable differential equation can't be written as an explicit function. This doesn't mean we can't use it!

title: Testing solutions to inequalities
description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: Applied rates of change: marginal costs
description: Sal solves a problem involving the modeling of cost with a function, which means the function's derivative models the marginal cost.

title: Applied rate of change: forgetfulness
description: Let's face it, sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Exponential vs. linear  models: verbal
description: Sal sorts various descriptions of real-world situation according to the type of growth they describe: linear or exponential.

title: Exponential vs. linear models: table
description: Determining whether real world model is linear or exponential, where the model is given as a table.

title: Comparing features of quadratic functions
description: Sal compares the y-intercepts, the zeros, and the concavity of quadratic functions given graphically and algebraically.

title: Comparing maximum points of quadratic functions
description: Given several quadratic functions represented in different forms, Sal finds the one with the lowest maximum value.

title: Product rule intro
description: Sal differentiates x²sin(x) using the product rule.

title: Differentiating products
description: Sal differentiates eˣcos(x) using the product rule.

title: Comparing decimals 1
description: Sal compares decimals like 0.7 and 0.09 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Comparing decimals 2
description: Sal compares decimals like 0.0093 and 0.01 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Comparing decimals 3
description: Sal compares decimals like 45.675 and 45.645 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Comparing decimals: 9.97 and 9.798
description: Sal compares 9.97 and 9.798 using place value.

title: Comparing decimals: 156.378 and 156.348
description: Sal compares 2 decimals using place value.

title: Recognizing prime and composite numbers
description: Can you recognize the prime numbers in this group of numbers? Which are prime, composite, or neither?

title: Prime numbers
description: Prime numbers are numbers that are only divisible by themselves and 1. Learn more about their properties, and see some examples.

title: Worked example: Solving proportions
description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers, too.

title: Proportion word problem: cookies
description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. How much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?

title: Implicit differentiation example
description: Implicit differentiation of (x-y)²=x+y-1

title: Finding slope of tangent line with implicit differentiation
description: Sal finds the slope of the tangent line to the curve x²+(y-x)³=28 at x=1 using implicit differentiation.

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.

title: Inequalities using addition and subtraction
description: Inequalities Using Addition and Subtraction

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions
description: Sal analyzes the limits at infinity of three different rational functions. He finds there are three general cases of how the limits behave.

title: Limits at infinity of rational functions (example)
description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10).

title: Slope of secant lines: arbitrary difference
description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (2,ln2) and (2+h,ln(2+h)).

title: Slope of secant lines: arbitrary point
description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (e,1) and (x,lnx).

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Performing rotations
description: Sal shows how to perform a rotation on a pentagon using our interactive widget!

title: Systems of equations with graphing: y=7/5x-5 & y=3/5x-1
description: Sal graphs the following system of equations and solves it by looking for the intersection point: y=7/5x-5 and y=3/5x-1.

title: Systems of equations with graphing: exact & approximate solutions
description: Sal solves a system of two linear equations in standard form, and then approximates the solution of a system whose solution isn't clearly visible.

title: Measuring volume with unit cubes
description: Learn to measure volume of rectangular prisms with cube units.

title: Volume of a cube
description: Sal introduces volume and compares it to length and area.  He also introduces cube units.

title: Linear equations word problems: earnings
description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.

title: Linear graphs word problem: cats
description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Comparing functions: x-intercepts
description: Given several functions represented in different forms (as a formula, as a graph, and as a table of values), Sal finds the one with that has no x-intercepts.

title: Comparing maximum points of quadratic functions
description: Given several quadratic functions represented in different forms, Sal finds the one with the lowest maximum value.

title: Comparing functions: shared features
description: Sal is given the formula of one function and the graph of the other, and he determines which features are shared by both functions.

title: Factoring perfect squares: 4th degree polynomial
description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables (example 2)
description: Sal factors 49x^2-49y^2 as (7x+7y)(7x-7y) or as 49(x+y)(x-y).

title: Solving equations graphically (1 of 2)
description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].

title: Solving equations graphically (2 of 2)
description: Sal solves the equation e^x=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)] by considering the graphs of y=e^x and y=1/[x(x-1)(x-2)].

title: Product rule example: table of values
description: Given the values of f and h (and their derivatives) at x=3, Sal evaluates the derivative of f(x)⋅h(x) at x=3.

title: Product rule example: mixed implicit & explicit
description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=1/x, Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)⋅g(x) at x=-1.

title: Finding factors and multiples
description: Sal uses divisibility rules to determine if numbers are factors of 154 and then finds multiples of 14.

title: Finding factors of a number
description: Sal finds the factors of 120.

title: Magnetic force on a proton example (part 1)
description: Sal does an example problem to determine the size and direction of the magnetic force on a proton moving through a magnetic field.

title: Magnetic force on a proton example (part 2)
description: Sal determines the radius of the circle traveled by the proton in the previous example by using the formula for centripetal acceleration.

title: Magnetic force on a current carrying wire
description: Sal derives the formula F=ILB to determine the force on a current carrying wire.

title: Magnetic field created by a current carrying wire
description: See how a wire carrying a current creates a magnetic field.

title: Magnetic force between two currents going in opposite directions
description: Sal shows how to determine the magnetic force between two currents going in opposite directions.

title: Flux and magnetic flux
description: Introduction and intuition for flux and magnetic flux.

title: Faraday's Law example
description: Example calculating induced current based on change in flux.

title: Emf induced in rod traveling through magnetic field
description: Emf induced in rod traveling through magnetic field

title: Lines, line segments, & rays
description: Learn the difference between lines, line segments, and rays.

title: Specifying planes in three dimensions
description: In a three-dimensional space, a plane can be defined by three points it contains, as long as those points are not on the same line. Learn more about it in this video.

title: Manipulating expressions using structure
description: Given that a+b=0, Sal finds an expression equivalent to a*b.

title: Manipulating expressions using structure (example 2)
description: Given that a+b=2a, Sal finds an expression equivalent to b-a.

title: Word problems with volume
description: Sal solves some practice problems using volume.

title: Understanding volume (liters)
description: Sal talks about what volume means. He also examines the volume of real objects in liters.

title: Representing 1 as a fraction
description: Sal uses fraction models and a number line to represent 1 as a fraction.

title: Whole numbers as fractions
description: Use fraction models and a number line to represent 3 as a fraction.

title: Subtracting decimals: 9.005 - 3.6
description: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.

title: Subtracting decimals: 39.1 - 0.794
description: In this example where we subtract decimals we do so up to the thousandths place. It's a little tricky, but not if we do it together.

title: Secant lines (with simplification): arbitrary difference
description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=4 and x=4+h on the graph of y=2x²+1.

title: Secant lines (with simplification): arbitrary point
description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=3 and x=t on the graph of y=2x²+5x.

title: Systems of equations with graphing: exact & approximate solutions
description: Sal solves a system of two linear equations in standard form, and then approximates the solution of a system whose solution isn't clearly visible.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: x-4y=-18 & -x+3y=11
description: Sal solves the following system of equations by eliminating x: x-4y=-18 and -x+3y=11.

title: Systems of equations with elimination (and manipulation)
description: In some cases, we need to slightly manipulate a system of equations before we can solve it using the elimination method. So how it's done in this video.

title: Systems of equations with substitution: -3x-4y=-2 & y=2x-5
description: Learn to solve the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.

title: Number of solutions to a system of equations graphically
description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.

title: Number of solutions to a system of equations algebraically
description: Sal solves several examples where he reasons about the number of solutions of systems of equations using algebraic reasoning.

title: Statistical significance of experiment
description: Sal determines if the results of an experiment about advertising are statistically significant.

title: Statistical significance on bus speeds
description: Sal determines if the results of an experiment about bus speeds are statistically significant.

title: Vectors word problem: hiking
description: Sal solves a word problem with vectors where he finds the total straight-line distance traveled over a few days.

title: Vectors word problem: tug of war
description: Sal solves a word problem where three vector forces act upon a ring in different magnitudes & directions.

title: Vectors word problem: pushing a box
Degrees to radians
description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.

title: Radians to degrees
description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.

title: Radians & degrees
description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

title: Magnitude of a vector from graph
description: Sal finds the magnitude of a vector given its graph.

title: Magnitude of a vector from components
description: Sal finds the magnitude of a vector given its components of (5, -3).

title: Magnitude of a vector from initial & terminal points
description: Sal finds the magnitude of the vector with initial point (-7, 3) and terminal point (2, -1).

title: Arc length from subtended angle: radians
description: Sal finds the length of an arc using the radius and the radian measure of the angle subtended by the arc.

title: Arc length as fraction of circumference
description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Adding by making a group of 10
description: Sal adds 5+68 by breaking the 5 into a 2 and a 3.

title: Adding 53+17 by making a group of 10
description: Sal adds 53+17 by breaking apart the numbers and making a group of 10.

title: Solving square-root equations: one solution
description: Sal solves the equation 3+√(5x+6)=12.

title: Solving square-root equations: two solutions
description: Sal solves the equation 6+3w=√(2w+12)+2w which has two solutions.

title: Solving square-root equations: no solution
description: Sal solves the equation √(3x-7)+√(2x-1)=0, only to find out that the single solution is extraneous, which means the equation has no solution.

title: Rotational kinematic formulas
description: In this video David explains the rotational kinematic formulas and does a couple sample problems using them.

title: Moments
description: Introduction to moments

title: Finding torque for angled forces
description: In this video David explains how to determine the torque exerted by a non perpendicular force.

title: Rotational version of Newton's second law
description: In this video David explains moment of inertia and the rotational version of Newton's second law and shows how to solve an example problem.

title: Rotational kinetic energy
description: In this video David explains what rotational kinetic energy is and how to calculate it.

title: Rolling without slipping problems
description: In this video David explains how to solve problems where an object rolls without slipping.

title: Constant angular momentum when no net torque
description: Just like how linear momentum is constant when there's no net force, angular momentum is constant where there's no net torque

title: Ball hits rod angular momentum example
description: In this video David explains how a mass can have angular momentum even if it is traveling along a straight line. Then David shows how to solve the conservation of angular momentum problem where a ball hits a rod which can rotate.

title: Rewriting fractions as decimals
description: Lindsay rewrites two fractions as decimals. The fractions have denominators of 10 and 100.

title: Second derivative test
description: Sal justifies the second derivative test, which is a way of determining relative minima & maxima, and gives an example.

title: Telling time to the nearest minute (labeled clock)
description: Lindsay reads the time on labeled analog clocks to the nearest minute.

title: Telling time to the nearest minute (unlabeled clock)
description: Lindsay reads the time on unlabeled analog clocks to the nearest minute.

title: Telling time (labeled clock)
description: Sal tells time on a labeled analog clock.

title: Telling time (unlabeled clock)
description: Sal tells time on unlabeled analog clocks.

title: Disguised derivatives
description: Sal interprets an elaborate limit expression as 5 times the derivative of log(x) at x=2. This way, he can evaluate the limit using differentiation rules instead of directly analyzing the limit (which is hard!).

title: Subject-verb agreement
description: Agreement is the art of making sure that sentence parts agree with one another; you want to make sure that your subjects and verbs match up.

title: Trig limit using pythagorean identity
description: Sal finds the limit at θ=0 of (1-cosθ)/(2sin²θ) by rewriting the expression using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Trig limit using double angle identity
description: Sal finds the limit at θ=-π/4 of (1+√2sinθ)/(cos2θ) by rewriting the expression using the cosine double angle identity.

title: Hydrogen bonding in water
description: Hydrogen bonding in water.

title: Water as a solvent
description: Water as a solvent. Polar solutes. Hydrophilic and hydrophobic substances.

title: Capillary action and why we see a meniscus
description: How capillary action and the meniscus are related to intermolecular forces in water.

title: Liquid water denser than solid water (ice)
description: Water less dense as ice. Why lakes don't freeze solid.

title: Heat of vaporization of water and ethanol
description: Heat of vaporization of water and ethanol.

title: Specific heat of water
description: Specific heat of water. A calorie as the specific heat of water. How water moderates temperature.

title: Definition of pH
description: The definition of pH and acidic and basic solutions

title: Introduction to buffers
description: Introduction to buffer systems, which regulate pH in blood.

title: Indefinite integrals of x raised to a power
description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Unbounded limits: graphical
description: Sal analyzes a function with an asymptote and finds the correct description of the two one-sided limits of the function at that asymptote.

title: Linear approximation example
description: Sal finds a linear expression that approximates y=1/(x-1) around x=-1. This is done by finding the equation of the line tangent to the graph at x=-1, a process called "linear approximation."

title: Quotient rule example
description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=2x³, Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)/g(x) at x=-1.

title: Powers of fractions
description: Just like whole numbers with exponents, fractions are repeatedly multiplied. If you know how to multiply fractions, you're over half way there.

title: Writing linear equations in all forms
description: Sal finds the equation of a line that passes through (-3,6) and (6,0) in point-slope, slope-intercept, and standard form.

title: Placing absolute values on the number line
description: Learn how to place | - 27 |, -17, -28, and 22.4 on the number line.

title: Comparing absolute values on the number line
description: Given, a, b, and c on the number line, Sal determines if statements like | a | < | c | are true.

title: Testing solutions to absolute value inequalities
description: Sal determines if values of x are solutions to an absolute value inequality. For example, does x = -5 satisfy | x | > 5?

title: Adding polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

title: Logarithmic functions differentiation
description: Sal differentiates the logarithmic function log₄(x²+x) using our knowledge of the derivative of logₐ(x) and the chain rule.

title: Analyzing concavity (graphical)
description: Sal walks through an exercise where you are asked to recognize the concavity of a function in certain regions.

title: Foci of an ellipse from equation
description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other, and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Comparing decimals visually
description: Sal compares 0.17 and 0.2 using grid diagrams.

title: How to classify complex numbers (example)
description: Sal first simplifies complex expressions, and then explains how to classify numbers as real, pure imaginary, or complex.

title: Equation practice with midpoints
description: Given an information about the distance of a segment's midpoint from its endpoints, Sal forms and solves an equation in order to find the length of the segment.

title: Strong acids and strong bases
description: Common strong acids and strong bases. Examples of calculating the pH of a nitric acid solution, sodium hydroxide solution, and a calcium hydroxide solution.

title: Negative powers differentiation
description: Sal differentiates g(x)=2/(x³)-1/(x²), and evaluates the derivative at x=2. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Fundamentals: Implicit Premise
description:
This video will rock your world! You should watch it. This pithy little argument contains an implicit premise: "If a video will rock your world, you should watch it". In this video, Kelley will go over how to identify implicit premises in all sorts of arguments and discuss when it is and is not acceptable to leave a premise implicit.

Speaker: Kelley Schiffman, Yale University

title: Converting units of time
description: Learn to convert hours, minutes, and seconds.

title: Worked example: Evaluating functions from equation
description: Learn how to evaluate f(x)=49-x² at x=5.

title: Plotting numbers on the complex plane
description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Radical functions differentiation
description: Sal differentiates ∜(x³+4x²+7) and evaluates the derivative at x=-3.

title: Reading a line plot with fractions
description: Sal reads a line plot that records average monthly rainfall for various cities.

title: Rational functions differentiation
description: Sal differentiates the rational function (5-3x)/(x²+3x). This function (and any other rational function) can be differentiated using the Quotient rule!

title: The age of empire
description: Why does the United States have territory outside of the Lower 48 states? KA's US history fellow Kim Kutz talks about the growing interest in becoming an imperial power in the 1890s.

title: Intermediate value theorem example
description: Given that a continuous function f obtains f(-2)=3 and f(1)=6, Sal picks the statement that is guaranteed by the Intermediate value theorem.

title: Introduction to work and energy
description: Introduction to work and energy

title: Work and the work-energy principle
description: David explains the link between work and kinetic energy

title: Conservation of energy
description: Using the law of conservation of energy to see how potential energy is converted into kinetic energy

title: Potential energy stored in a spring
description: Work needed to compress a spring is the same thing as the potential energy stored in the compressed spring.

title: Thermal energy from friction
description: In this video David shows how to find the energy generated by the force of friction and solves an example conservation of energy problem involving thermal energy.

title: Power
description: IIII haaaave the powerrrr! Power is the rate at which work is done.

title: Equation practice with vertical angles
description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Equation of a parabola from focus & directrix
description: The equation of a parabola is derived from the focus and directrix, and then the general formula is used to solve an example.

title: Worked example: evaluating functions from graph
description: Evaluating a function at x=-1 using the graph of that function.

title: Approximating with powers of 10
description: Learn how to approximate how much larger the world population was than the US population in 2014.

title: Chain rule example
description: Given the values of f and g (and their derivatives) at some x-values, Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(g(x)) at a specific x-value.

title: Domain of advanced functions
description: Sal covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.

title: Domain of advanced functions
description: Sal covers many different kinds of functions and shows how to determine their domain.

title: Foci of an ellipse from equation
description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other, and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Classifying numbers
description: Learn how to classify numbers as whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers.

title: Polar & rectangular forms of complex numbers
description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Frequency tables & dot plots
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Approximating square roots
description: Learn how to find the approximate values of square roots. The examples used in this video are √32, √55, and √123. The technique used is to compare the squares of whole numbers to the number we're taking the square root of.

title: Evaluating composite functions
description: Sal evaluates (h⚬g)(-6) for g(x)=x²+5x-3 and h(y)=3(y-1)²-5.

title: Difference of squares intro
description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares, i.e. a²-b², then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

title: Equivalent vectors
description: Sal determines if two vectors shown on a graph are equivalent by seeing if they have the same magnitude and direction.

title: Quadratic word problem: ball
description: Sal solves a word problem about a ball being shot in the air. The equation for the height of the ball as a function of time is quadratic.

title: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers (multiplication and division)
description: In this video, we figure out whether or not some expressions are equivalent. To do this, we think about properties of multiplication and division.

title: Worked example: finding unit vector with given direction
description: Learn what a unit vector is and how to find a unit vector in the direction of a given vector.

title: Dependent probability introduction
description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Analyzing event probability for independence
description: Sal uses an example about shirts, scarves, hats, and pants to explain how to use probabilities to figure out if two events are independent.

title: Independent & dependent probability
description: This time around we're not going to tell you whether we're working on a dependent or independent probability event problem. You tell us!

title: Tangents of polynomials
description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the graph of f(x)=x³-6x²+x-5 at x=1.

title: Volume through decomposition
description: Sal finds the volume of an irregular 3D figure by breaking the figure into 2 rectangular prisms and finding the volume of each part.

title: Volume in unit cubes by decomposing shape
description: Find volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side.  Find a missing side length on a rectangular prism when given the volume.

title: Intro to partial fraction expansion
description: Sal explains what partial fraction expansion is by rewriting (x²-2x-37)/(x²-3x-40) as the sum of 1 and two rational expressions with linear denominators.

title: Partial fraction expansion
description: Sal performs partial fraction expansion upon (10x²+12x+20)/(x³-8).

title: Partial fraction expansion: repeated factors
description: Sal performs partial fraction expansion upon (6x²-19x+15)/(x-1)(x-2)².

title: Strategy of the Civil War
description: The strategy of the Civil War for the Confederacy (the South) was to outlast the political will of the United States (the North) to continue the fighting the war by demonstrating that the war would be long and costly. The Confederacy also hoped to entice European powers such as the United Kingdom to assist them against the United States in order to protect their cotton supply. The strategy for the United States was to surround the territory of the South in the Anaconda Plan, blockading the Atlantic Ocean and controlling the Mississippi, to keep goods from going into or out of the South and forcing them to surrender.

title: Later stages of the Civil War - 1863
description: In the year 1863, US General Ulysses S. Grant succeeds in securing the western theatre of war and moves east to take on Robert E. Lee.

title: Later stages of the Civil War - the election of 1864 and Sherman's March
description: KA's US history fellow Kim discusses the year 1864 of the Civil War, including Sherman's March to the Sea and the election of 1864.

title: Later stages of the Civil War - Appomattox and Lincoln's assassination
description: The end of the Civil War, including Lee's surrender at Appomattox and the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

title: Start of the Civil War - secession and Fort Sumter
description: From Lincoln's election to the formation of the Confederacy and Fort Sumter.

title: Early phases of Civil War and Antietam
description: Early phases of the Civil War, from Bull Run to Antietam.

title: Significance of the battle of Antietam
description: Why was Antietam such an important battle in the Civil War? Kim discusses the international effects of the battle of Antietam.

title: The battle of Gettysburg
description: The battle of Gettysburg was a major turning point in the Civil War. In this video, Kim discusses the battle and its consequences.

title: The Gettysburg Address - setting and context
description: The Gettysburg Address was delivered by Abraham Lincoln on November 19, 1863. In this video, Kim sets the stage for the address and describes the scene at the cemetery.

title: The Gettysburg Address - full text and analysis
description: A close reading of the Gettysburg Address.

title: Big takeaways from the Civil War
description: Why does the Civil War matter? Kim discusses the importance of the Civil War and its effects on American society.

title: 2-step word problem: running
description: Solve a 2-step word problem by drawing a picture and creating an equation.

title: 2-step estimation problem: marbles
description: Sal solves a 2-step estimation word problem.

title: 2-step word problem: theater
description: Solve a two-step word problem by drawing a picture and creating an equation.

title: 2-step word problem: truffles
description: Sal solves a two-step word problem by drawing a picture and creating an equation.

title: Finite geometric series word problem: social media
description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Finite geometric series word problem: mortgage
description: Figuring out the formula for fixed mortgage payments using the sum of a geometric series

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions: 0.15
description: Decimals can be written in fraction form. To convert a decimal to a fraction, place the decimal number over its place value. For example, in 0.6, the six is in the tenths place, so we place 6 over 10 to create the equivalent fraction, 6/10. If needed, simplify the fraction.

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions: 0.8
description: Sal converts 0.8 to a fraction.

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions: 0.36
description: Sal converts 0.36 to a fraction.

title: Graphing tenths from 0 to 1
description: Lindsay graphs 0.6 on a number line.

title: Identifying tenths on a number line
description: Lindsay identifies a point graphed on a number line.

title: Comparing decimal numbers on a number line
description: Sal compares decimals on a number line.

title: Determining reflections
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane, and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.

title: Reflecting shapes
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Transforming the square-root function
description: Sal shows various examples of functions and their graphs that are a result of shifting and/or flipping y=√x.

title: Square-root functions & their graphs
description: Sal is given a drawing with four graphs and four formulas of square-root functions. He uses transformations to match each formula with its appropriate graph.

title: Graphs of square-root functions
description: Sal graphs y=√x. Then, he shows a few examples of how we can shift and stretch the graphs of y=√x and y=x^2, and how the equations of those graphs look.

title: Exploring standard deviation 1 module
description: Ben Eater and Sal Khan talk through the Khan Academy Standard Deviation 1 Module: http://www.khanacademy.org/math/statistics/e/exploring_standard_deviation_1

title: Sample standard deviation and bias
description: Sal shows an example of calculating standard deviation and bias.

title: Measures of spread: range, variance & standard deviation
description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Limits by rationalizing
description: Sal finds the limits of (x+1)/(√(x+5)-2) by "rationalizing the denominator" of the expression.

title: Performing sequences of transformations
description: Sal reflects and then translates a given pentagon, and determines whether the resulting figure is congruent to the source figure.

title: Determining mappings (incl. dilations)
description: Sal maps a given quadrilateral onto another using a translation, a dilation, and a reflection. The quadrilaterals are not congruent because a dilation was used.

title: Intro to geometric transformations
description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Determining reflections
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane, and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.

title: Derivative of ln(x) as a limit
description: Enough abstract stuff already, let's see what the formal and alternative forms of the derivative look like in practice.

title: Interpreting a limit to find the derivative it describes
description: Sal interprets a limit expression to find that it describes the derivative of f(x)=x³ at the point x=5.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how, in some sense, integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Applying the fundamental theorem of calculus
description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Slightly trickier fundamental theorem problem
description: Sometimes you need to swap the bounds of integration before applying the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Both bounds being a function of x
description: How do you apply the fundamental theorem of calculus when both integral bounds are a function of x.

title: Proof of fundamental theorem of calculus
description: See why this surpising result is true.

title: Adding whole numbers by their place values
description: Lindsay adds numbers like 19 thousands + 7 tens by thinking about their place values.

title: Regrouping whole number place values
description: Lindsay regroups whole numbers by their place values.

title: Regrouping numbers into various place values
description: Sal regroups 4500 different ways.

title: Empires before World War I
description: Austria-Hungary. Ottoman empire. British, German, French and Russian empires.

title: Alliances leading to World War I
description: There are a number of European alliances that contributed to the broad scope of World War I. Prominent among these are the 1839 Treaty of London, which promised that the United Kingdom would protect Belgium's neutrality, the 1879 Dual Alliance treaty between Germany and Austria-Hungary to protect each other in the event of Russian attack, the 1892 Franco-Russian Military Convention that promised mutual assistance in the face of attack, the Triple Entente linking the United Kingdom and France (and later Italy), and the Triple Alliance linking Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy (at first).

title: Beginning of World War II
description: An overview of the run up to and very beginnings of World War II.

title: United States enters World War I
description: Learn about the United States' reasons for entering World War I.

title: Zimmermann Telegram
description: An intercepted telegram between Germany and Mexico led the United States to declare war.

title: Blockades, u-boats and sinking of the Lusitania
description: Learn about the naval warfare between Britain and Germany that led to the sinking of the Lusitania.

title: Dividing complex numbers
description: Sal divides (6+3i) by (7-5i).

title: Strategies for subtracting basic decimals
description: Sal uses place value and a number line to subtract decimals, such as 1.5-0.7.

title: Strategies for subtracting more complex decimals with tenths
description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals to the tenths place, such as 2-1.2.

title: Introduction to kinetics
description: Kinetics is the study of reaction rates and how they are affected. Many factors, such as concentration, pressure, temperature, and enzyme activity, can impact the rate of a reaction. For example, a molecule's kinetic energy is directly proportional to its temperature, so increasing the temperature will result in an increase in reaction rate.

title: Rate of reaction
description: Definition of reaction rate, and examples of calculating the average rate of reaction.

title: Rate law and reaction order
description: Using method of initial rates to determine the order of a reaction.

title: Experimental determination of rate laws
description: Example using initial rates to find the order in each reactant, the overall order, and the rate constant k.

title: Centripetal force and acceleration intuition
description: The direction of the force in cases of circular motion at constant speeds

title: Visual understanding of centripetal acceleration formula
description: Visual understanding of how centripetal acceleration relates to velocity and radius

title: Centripetal force problem solving
description: In this video David gives some problem solving strategies for centripetal force problems and explains many common misconceptions people have about centripetal forces.

title: Yo-yo in vertical circle example
description: In this video David explains how to find the tension in a string that is whirling a yo-yo in a vertical circle.

title: Introduction to gravity
description: Basics of gravity and the Law of Universal Gravitation

title: Space station speed in orbit
description: Speed necessary for the space station to stay in orbit

title: Reflecting shapes
description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Comparing with multiplication: basics
description: Sal solves multiplication comparison problems.

title: Comparing with multiplication: giraffe
description: Sal solves 2 multiplication comparison word problems.

title: Comparing with multiplication: money
description: Sal solves 2 multiplication comparison word problems.

title: Proof: Segments tangent to circle from outside point are congruent

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 1)

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 2)

title: Tangents of circles problem (example 3)
description: Sal finds a missing length using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Exponent example 1
description: Sal explains the difference between 5 × 3 and 5 to the third power

title: Limits by direct substitution
description: Sal explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

title: Dividing by 2-digits: 9815÷65
description: Learn to divide 9815÷65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Dividing by 2-digits: 7182÷42
description: Learn to divide 7182÷42.  There is no remainder.

title: Intro to arcsine
description: Sal introduces arcsine, which is the inverse function of sine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Intro to arctangent
description: Sal introduces arctangent, which is the inverse function of tangent, and discusses its principal range.

title: Intro to arccosine
description: Sal introduces arccosine, which is the inverse function of cosine, and discusses its principal range.

title: Passive transport and selective permeability
description: Passive transport and selective permeability. Passive transport through diffusion.

title: Hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic solutions (tonicity)
description: Hypotonic, isotonic and hypertonic solutions (tonicity). Seeing the effect of various types of solution on the direction of osmosis.

title: Facilitated diffusion
description: Understanding how channel proteins and carrier proteins can facilitate diffusion across a cell membrane (passive transport).

title: Electrochemical gradients and secondary active transport
description: How a cell can use a molecule's electrochemical gradient to power secondary active transport.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi bodies
description: Structure of the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body (Golgi apparatus). Their role in protein secretion.

title: Mitochondria
description: The structure and role of mitochondria (plural for mitochondrion). Outer membrane, inner membrane, cristae, porins, etc.

title: How to convert kg to mg and T to oz
description: Sal converts kilograms to milligrams and tons to ounces.

title: Mean value theorem example: polynomial
description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=x²-6x+8 over the interval [2,5].

title: Mean value theorem example: square root function
description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=√(4x-3) over the interval [1,3].

title: When is an integral defined function 0
description: Solving for where a function defined by an integral equals 0.

title: Solving for a side with the law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length, and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Solving for an angle with the law of sines
description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure, and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Fundamentals: Validity
description:
Paul Henne discusses the philosophical concept of validity. After reviewing the structure of an argument, he defines validity: an argument is valid if and only if its premises guarantee the conclusion. He reviews a few examples of validity and invalidity, and he leaves you with one example to figure out on your own.
Speaker: Paul Henne, Duke University

title: Intro to adding mixed numbers
description: Sal adds 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Intro to subtracting mixed numbers
description: Sal subtracts 2 mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

title: Adding mixed numbers with like denominators
description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can add numbers....you can add fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can add mixed numbers! Watch.

title: Subtracting mixed numbers with like denominators
description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can subtract numbers....you can subtract fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can subtract mixed numbers! Watch.

title: Multiplying positive & negative numbers
description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Dividing positive and negative numbers
description: Discover the basics of dividing with negative numbers.

title: Multiplying numbers with different signs
description: Find the product of numbers with different signs.

title: Why a negative times a negative is a positive
description: Use the distributive property to understand the products of negative numbers.

title: Why a negative times a negative makes sense
description: Use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an understanding of multiplying negative numbers.

title: Adding and subtracting 3 fractions
description: Sal solves 1/4+3/5 -3/10 by rewriting each fraction to have a common denominator.

title: Solving for the missing fraction
description: Sal solves missing fraction problems like __ + 1/16 = 3/2.

title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: fishing boat
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.

title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Animal communication
description: Visit us (http://www.khanacademy.org/science/healthcare-and-medicine) for health and medicine content or (http://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat) for MCAT related content. These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.

title: Anatomy of a neuron
description: Neurons (or nerve cells) are specialized cells that transmit and receive electrical signals in the body. Neurons are composed of three main parts: dendrites, a cell body, and an axon. Signals are received through the dendrites, travel to the cell body, and continue down the axon until they reach the synapse (the communication point between two neurons).

title: Saltatory conduction in neurons
description: Myelin sheaths, nodes of Ranvier, and saltatory conduction in neurons.

title: Atomic number, mass number, and isotopes
description: How to use the atomic number and the mass number to represent different isotopes

title: Atomic weight and atomic mass
description: Atomic mass is the total mass of protons and neutrons in an individual atom or isotope. Atomic weight is the average mass of all of the naturally-occurring isotopes of an element. Both atomic mass and atomic weight are represented using a unit called the atomic mass unit (amu), which was defined using carbon's most common isotope, carbon-12.

title: Comparing absolute values
description: Learn how to compare absolute value like | -9 | and | -7 |.

title: Absolute value examples
description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5, -10, and 12.

title: Adding numbers with different signs
description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Coordinate plane graphing word problem
description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

title: Writing basic expressions with variables
description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Multi-step unit conversion examples  (U.S. Customary)
description: Sal solves multi-step unit conversion example using U.S. Customary units of measure.

title: Finding factors of a number
description: Sal finds the factors of 120.

title: An overview and the 13th Amendment
description: Jeffrey Rosen of the National Constitution Center in conversation with Walter Isaacson of the Aspen Institute.

title: The 14th Amendment
description: Jeffrey Rosen of the National Constitution Center in conversation with Walter Isaacson of the Aspen Institute.

title: The 15th Amendment
description: Jeffrey Rosen of the National Constitution Center in conversation with Walter Isaacson of the Aspen Institute.

title: The origins of Jim Crow - introduction
description: Who or what was Jim Crow? KA's US history fellow Kim talks about the origin of Jim Crow segregation in the American South.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - the Black Codes and Reconstruction
description: In the period after the Civil War in the American South, when Southern society reorganized to account for the end of slavery. In this video, Kim discusses how many Southern governments passed laws preventing African Americans from voting, among other things, which prompted Congress to pass the Fourteenth Amendment.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments
description: During Reconstruction, federal troops attempted to enforce the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments in the South.

title: Origins of Jim Crow - Compromise of 1877 and Plessy v. Ferguson
description: Federal troops left the South after the Compromise of 1877, ending Reconstruction. The Supreme Court ruled that segregation did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment in the Plessy v. Ferguson decision of 1896.

title: Worked example: domain and range from graph
description: Finding the domain and the range of a function that is given graphically.

title: Fundamentals: Necessary and Sufficient Conditions
description:
In this video, Kelley discusses one of the most basic tools in the philosophers' tool kit: the distinction between necessary and sufficient conditions. Through the use of ordinary language glosses and plenty of examples this mighty distinction is brought down to earth and presented in a ready-to-use fashion.

Speaker: Kelley Schiffman, Yale University

title: Finding place value
description: Sal finds the place value of 3 in 4356.

title: Perimeter of a shape
description: Sal finds perimeter of various shapes.

title: Perimeter: introduction
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Interpreting picture graphs: paint
description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem involving a picture graph.

title: Interpreting picture graphs: notebook
description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem involving a picture graph.

title: Reading pictographs
description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Mean, median, & mode example
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Area of a triangle
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Metric system: units of weight
description: Sal discusses metric units of mass or weight such as milligram, gram, and kilogram.

title: Understanding mass (grams and kilograms)
description: Sal talks about what mass means. He also examines the masses of real objects in grams and kilograms.

title: Exponents with negative bases
description: Learn to what we know about negative numbers to determine how negative bases with exponents are affected and what patterns develop. Also learn how order of operations affect the pattern.

title: The 0 & 1st power
description: Discover a pattern that explains why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.

title: Place value example: 42
description: Sal shows 42 as 4 tens and 2 ones.

title: Place value example: 25
description: Sal shows 25 as 2 tens and 5 ones.

title: Definite integral of rational function
description: Sal finds the definite integral of (16-x³)/x³ between -1 and -2 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral of radical function
description: Sal finds the definite integral of 12∛x between -1 and 8 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral of trig function
description: Sal finds the definite integral of 9sin(x) between 11π/2 and 6π.

title: Definite integral involving natural log
description: Sal finds the definite integral of (6+x²)/x³ between 2 and 4. To do that, he has to use the integral of 1/x, which is ln(x).

title: Graphing quadratics: vertex form
description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in vertex form. Here, Sal graphs y=-2(x-2)²+5.

title: Modeling with composite functions
description: Sal determines the correct functions to compose (and the correct order) in order to model a given relationship, and vice versa.

title: Modeling with composite functions (example 2)
description: Sal models the volume of fuel in a tank as a function of time, by using composing given formulas for the volume as a function of depth and depth as a function of time.

title: Add and subtract: pieces of fruit
description: Sal adds fruit and subtracts fruit. The examples he uses are 5+3 and 5-3.

title: Graph from slope-intercept equation
description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.

title: Intro to adverbs
description: Adverbs are a kind of modifier that you can use to change verbs or adjectives, like 'very' or 'carefully'.

title: Writing expressions word problems
description: Learn how to write expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Equations with parentheses
description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

title: Solving for a side in right triangles with trigonometry
description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units, and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.

title: System of equations word problem: walk & ride
description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video, we solve a problem about distances walking and riding bus to school.

title: Solving exponential equations using logarithms: base-10
description: Sal solves the equation 10^(2t-3)=7.

title: Writing a number as a fraction and decimal
description: Sal shows the connection between decimals and fractions using a grid diagram and number lines.

title: Writing decimal numbers shown in grids
description: Sal uses grid diagrams to determine what decimal is represented by a shaded area.

title: The idea of division
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Intro to division
description: Introduction to division.

title: Adding & subtracting rational expressions: like denominators
description: Sal adds 6/(2x²-7) + (-3x-8)/(2x²-7) and subtracts (9x²+3)/(14x²-9) - (-3x²+5)/(14x²-9).

title: Simplifying square roots (variables)
description: A worked example of simplifying radical with a variable in it. In this example, we simplify 3√(500x³).

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.

title: Dividing mixed numbers
description: Sal shows us how to change mixed numbers into improper fractions, divide, and then change the answer back to a mixed number.

title: Dependent & independent variables
description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Dependent & independent variables: graphing
description: It's helpful to express an equation on a graph where we plot at least 2 points. Watch and we'll show you.

title: Dependent & independent variables: equation
description: We're flipping the last video on its head and doing the opposite. This time we give you the graph and ask you to express it as an equation.

title: Perimeter word problem: tables
description: Lindsay solves a perimeter word problem that involves combining two perimeters.

title: Perimeter word problem: skating rink
description: Lindsay finds the area of an irregular shape by decomposing it into 2 rectangles.

title: Perimeter: introduction
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Measurement word problem: distance home
description: Sal solves a US customary distance word problem involving yards and feet.

title: Measurement word problem: elevator
description: Sal solves a US customary mass (weight) word problem involving pounds and tons.

title: Measurement word problem: running laps
description: Sal solves a US customary distance word problem involving miles, yards, and feet.

title: Measurement word problem: blood drive
description: Sal solves a US customary volume word problem involving pints and gallons.

title: Mitosis
description: Mitosis is how cells divide! Learn what happens in all the phases of mitosis: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.

title: Rewriting a fraction as a decimal: 3/5
description: Sal rewrites 3/5 as a decimal.

title: Rewriting a fraction as a decimal: 6/12
description: Sal rewrites 6/12 as a decimal.

title: Rewriting a fraction as a decimal: 21/60
description: Sal rewrites 21/60 as a decimal.

title: Justification for polar arc length formula
description: Sal shows the polar arc length formula, and explains why it is true.

title: Arc length of petal of polar graph
description: What is the arc length of the polar curve r = 4sin(theta)?

title: Interpreting absolute value
description: Given that Jenna's weight changed -3 lbs, Sarah's changed 2.5 lbs, and Bill's changed 4 lbs, who lost the most weight? Who had the largest change in weight?

title: Understanding fractions as division
description: Sal shows how a/b and a÷b are equivalent. That is, the fraction bar and the division symbol mean the same thing.

title: Creating mixed numbers with fraction division
description: Sal explains the relationship between fractions, division, and mixed numbers.

title: Creating a fraction through division
description: Sal explains how 3 ÷ 2 is the same as 3 • 1/2, which is the same as 3/2.

title: Mixed numbers on a number line
description: Sal locates 3/2 on a number line.

title: Making picture graphs and line plots
description: To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place an Xs over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Multiplication as groups of objects
description: Sal uses arrays to show different ways to multiply and get the same solution.

title: Testing solutions to inequalities
description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3,5) and (1,-7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.

title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram
description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

title: Area of a triangle
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Parentheses
description: Parentheses set off extra information (such as a writer's remarks, an interruption, or a reference) from the rest of a sentence. Learn how to use them in this video!

title: Ordering triangle sides and angles example
description: Sal first solves a problem where he orders the sides of a triangle given the angles, then solves a problem where he orders the angles of a triangle given the sides.

title: Rewriting roots as rational exponents
description: Sal solves several problems about the equivalence of expressions with roots and rational exponents. For example, rewrite ⁶√(g⁵) as g^⅚.

title: Volume of solids: Example 1
description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume of solids: Example 2
description: This time, the cross section of our solid is given as the area between two curves.

title: Dividing by 2-digits: 7182÷42
description: Learn to divide 7182÷42.  There is no remainder.

title: Dividing by 2-digits: 9815÷65
description: Learn to divide 9815÷65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Analyzing structure with linear inequalities: fruits
description: Given a real-world context about the number of fruits bought, we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Analyzing structure with linear inequalities: balls
description: Given a real-world context about the number of balls in a bag, we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Sum of interior angles of a polygon
description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Sum of the exterior angles of a polygon
description: Sal demonstrates how the the sum of the exterior angles of a convex polygon is 360 degrees.

title: Prime factorization
description: Prime Factorization

title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10
description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests.

title: Recognizing divisibility
description: Recognizing Divisibility.

title: The why of the 3 divisibility rule
description: Why you can add the digits to see if something is divisible by 3

title: The why of the 9 divisibility rule
description: Why you can test divisibility by 9 by just adding the digits

title: Determining congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the SSS, ASA, SAS, and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.

title: Congruent triangles & the SSS postulate/criterion
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Triangle congruence postulates/criteria
description: Sal introduces and justifies the SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA, better to watch next video.

title: Factoring binomials: common factor
description: Sal factors 8x²y+12xy² as (4xy)(2x+3y) by taking out the greatest common factor.

title: Factoring polynomials: common factor area model
description: Sal finds the measures of a rectangle whose area is 12x⁴+6x³+15x² by taking the greatest common factor.

title: Factoring polynomials: common binomial factor
description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.

title: Intro to matrices
description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Meet the preposition
description: Prepositions help show us where things are in space and time.

title: Worked example: Completing the square (intro)
description: Sal completes x²-44x into a perfect square.

title: Intro to linear equation standard form
description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example, 2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form, it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Graphing a linear equation: 5x+2y=20
description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.

title: Translating shapes
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

title: Translation challenge problem
description: A translation acting on the coordinate plane takes the point (-169,434) to point (-203, -68). What are the coordinates of the image of point (31, -529) under this translation?

title: Adding decimals with ones, tenths and hundredths
description: Sal adds numbers, such as 3.53+4.72, by breaking them down into place values.

title: Adding decimals with hundredths
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to add decimals, such as 0.68+0.33.

title: Adding & subtracting matrices
description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Worked examples: slope-intercept intro
description: Worked examples practicing the relationship between slope, y-intercept, and linear equation in slope-intercept form.

title: Subtracting in scientific notation
description: Learn how to subtract numbers written in scientific notation. The problem solved in this video is (4.1 * 10^-2) - (2.6 * 10^-3).

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Venn diagrams and the addition rule for probability

title: Probability with Venn diagrams
description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Points inside/outside/on a circle
description: Sal uses the distance formula to determine whether the point (-6,-6) is inside, outside, or on the circle centered at (-1,-3) with radius 6.

title: Using arithmetic sequences formulas
description: Sal finds terms of arithmetic sequences using their explicit and recursive formulas.

title: Worked example: using recursive formula for arithmetic sequence
description: Example finding the 4th term in a recursively defined arithmetic sequence.

title: Equations for proportional relationships
description: Learn how to write a proportional equation y=kx where k is the so-called "constant of proportionality".

title: Perimeter: introduction
description: Perimeter is the distance around the edge of a shape. Learn how to find the perimeter by adding up the side lengths of various shapes

title: Perimeter of a shape
description: Sal finds perimeter of various shapes.

title: Interpreting time in exponential models
description: Sal finds the time interval over which a quantity changes by a given factor in various exponential models.

title: Features of sinusoidal functions
description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline, amplitude, & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Shifting absolute value graphs
description: The graph of y=|x-k|+h is the graph of y=|x| shifted k units to the right and h units up. See worked examples practicing this relationship.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form (1 of 2)
description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Vector addition & magnitude
description: Sal explains some interesting properties of the magnitude of vector sums.

title: Intro to rational exponents
description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example, what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Arithmetic series in sigma notation
description: Sal writes the arithmetic sum 7+9+1+...+403+405 in sigma notation. There are actually two common ways of doing this.

title: Square root of decimal
description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.

title: Multiplying binomials
description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.

title: Equations with rational expressions
description: Sal solves (x²-10x+21)/(3x-12)=(x-5)/(x-4), which has one real solution and one extraneous solution.

title: Interpreting absolute value as distance
description: In this video, we work through a bunch of examples that stretch our thinking on absolute value.

title: Initial value & common ratio of exponential functions
description: Get comfortable with the basic ingredients of exponential functions: the Initial value and the common ratio.

title: Sigma notation for sums
description: Sigma, Σ, is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Worked example: relative maxima and minima
description: Sal gives multiple examples where he identifies relative maximum points, relative minimum points, absolute maximum points, and absolute minimum points.

title: Adding vectors in magnitude & direction form (2 of 2)
description: Watch Sal finish the problem he started in part 1 by converting the sum back to magnitude and direction form.

title: Three types of sentence
description: Three essential types of sentence are declarative sentences (which are statements), interrogative sentences (which are questions), and imperative sentences (which are orders). Join us as we give examples of each!

title: Midpoint formula
description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane, or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Cylinder volume & surface area
description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Sums of consecutive integers
description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: Complex number conjugates
description: Sal finds the conjugate of (7-5i).

title: Subtracting mixed numbers: 7 6/9 - 3 2/5
description: Sal subtracts 3 2/5 from 7 6/9 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Adding mixed numbers: 19 3/18 + 18 2/3
description: Sal adds 19 3/18 + 18 2/3 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators
description: Adding Mixed Numbers with Unlike Denominators

title: Adding mixed numbers
description: Adding Mixed Numbers

title: Subtracting mixed numbers
description: Subtracting Mixed Numbers

title: Subtracting mixed numbers 2
description: Subtracting Mixed Numbers 2

title: Sp hybridization
description: In sp hybridization, the 2s orbital and a 2p orbital hybridize to form two sp orbitals, each consisting of 50% s character and 50% p character. The front lobes point away from each other (creating ​a 180° angle between the two orbitals), and the back lobes also point in opposite directions. This results in a linear structure.

title: sp³ hybridization
description: sp³ hybrid orbitals and properties of sigma bonds.

title: sp² hybridization
description: sp² hybrid orbitals and properties of pi bonds.

title: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal
description: Sal divides 63÷35.

title: Division strategies for decimal quotients
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value and fractions to introduce dividing with decimals.

title: Multi-digit division strategies for decimals
description: Sal uses understanding of place value, expanded form, and fractions to help divide with decimals.

title: Translating expressions with parentheses
description: Sal interprets written statements and writes them as mathematical expressions.

title: Graphing data on line plots
description: Sal shows measurements on line plots (also called dot plots).

title: Subtracting polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (16x+14) - (3x² + x - 9).

title: Interpreting change in exponential models: with manipulation
description: Sal analyzes the rate of change of various exponential models, where the function that models the situation needs some manipulation.

title: Rotating shapes
description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin, and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Adding & subtracting decimals word problem
description: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.

title: Adding decimals word problem
description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Radius & diameter from circumference
description: Sal finds the radius and diameter of a circle given the circumference.

title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.
