title: Irregular plural nouns – the MUTANT PLURALS
description: English has seven words that behave very strangely when you change them from the singular to the plural. These are called THE MUTANT PLURALS of English. They're super cool.

title: Solving hairy proportions
description: Sal solves the equation (x-9)/12=2/3.

title: New operator definitions 1
description: Sal solves a few problems where a new operator is defined and Sal evaluates some expression with it.

title: Intro to complex numbers
description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: Explicit & recursive formulas for geometric sequences
description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.

title: Multiplying & dividing powers (integer exponents)
description: For any base a and for any exponents n and m, aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ and aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data
description: Sal constructs functions that model the growth of trees over time. To do that, he identifies which growth is linear and which is exponential.

title: Linear vs. exponential growth: from data (example 2)
description: Sal constructs a function that models cooling water. To do that, he decides whether the function is linear or exponential.

title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients
description: Sal solves the equations ax+3x=bx+5 and a(5-x)=bx-8 for x. Note that these equations include other unknowns (a and b) but we solve them for x.

title: Trig word problem: modeling daily temperature
description: Sal solves a word problem about the daily change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

title: Trig word problem: modeling annual temperature
description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

title: Graphing quadratics: vertex form
description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in vertex form. Here, Sal graphs y=-2(x-2)²+5.

title: Graphing quadratics: standard form
description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in standard form. Here, Sal graphs y=5x²-20x+15.

title: Restricting domains of functions to make them invertible
description: Sal is given the graph of a trigonometric function, and he discusses ways in which he can change the function to make it invertible.

title: Explicit formulas for arithmetic sequences
description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.

title: Factoring with the distributive property
description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: The distributive property with variables
description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor out the greatest common factor from an algebraic expression like 2+4x.

title: Elements and atoms
description: How elements relate to atoms. The basics of how protons, electrons, and neutrons make up an atom.

title: Introduction to the atom
description: Learn how atoms are made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Elements are defined by the atomic number, the number of protons in the nucleus. The mass of an atom is determined by the total number of protons and neutrons.

title: Orbitals
description: Introduction to orbitals. Relates energy shell to rows and periods in the periodic table.

title: More on orbitals and electron configuration
description: How electron configuration is related to orbitals and the structure of the periodic table.

title: Valence electrons and bonding
description: How to get Lewis structures from electron configuration, and how valence electrons are involved in forming bonds.

title: Groups of the periodic table
description: What is a group in the periodic table, and what do elements in a group have in common?

title: Comparing whole number place values
description: Sal compares whole numbers written in expanded form, written form, and number form.

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Finite geometric series in sigma notation
description: Sal writes the geometric sum 2+6+18+54 in sigma notation. There are actually two common ways of doing this.

title: Fundamentals: Introduction to Critical Thinking
description:
Geoff Pynn gets you started on the critical thinking journey. He tells you what critical thinking is, what an argument is, and what the difference between a deductive and an ampliative argument is. 

Speaker: Dr. Geoff Pynn, Assistant Professor, Northern Illinois University

title: Amplitude & period of sinusoidal functions from equation
description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).

title: Trig word problem: stars
description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Coordinate plane word problem
description: Watch Sal solve an example where has to determine which of the Minions a wizard can reach using the coordinate plane.

title: Finding units of rate constant k
description: How to find the units for the rate constant k for a zero, first, or second order reaction.

title: Half-life of a first-order reaction
description: Deriving half-life equation of a first-order reaction starting from the integrated rate law.

title: Plotting data for a second-order reaction
description: Example of graphing second order rate data to see a linear relationship, and calculating rate constant k from the slope.

title: Adding complex numbers
description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .

title: Subtracting complex numbers
description: Sal subtracts (6-18i) from (2-3i).

title: Fundamentals: Intrinsic vs. Instrumental Value
description:
What sort of things do we value and why? In this video Kelley distinguishes two different kinds of value: (1) Intrinsic value--the value that something has in itself--and (2) instrumental value--the value that something has because it helps us to get or achieve some other thing. This philosophically and practically useful distinction is illuminated through the use of plenty of examples and ordinary language glosses. 

Speaker: Kelley Schiffman, Yale University

title: Worked example: Solving equations by completing the square
description: Sal solves x²-2x-8=0 by rewriting the equation as (x-1)²-9=0 (which is done by completing the square!).

title: Worked example: Rewriting expressions by completing the square
description: Sal rewrites x²+16x+9 as (x+8)²-55 by completing the square.

title: Determining if a function is invertible
description: Sal analyzes the mapping diagram of a function to see if the function is invertible.

title: Equation for simple harmonic oscillators
description: In this video David explains the equation that represents the motion of a simple harmonic oscillator and solves an example problem.

title: Period dependence for mass on spring
description: In this video David explains what affects the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. mass and spring constant). He also explains what does not affect the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. amplitude and gravitational acceleration).

title: Pendulums
description: In this video David explains how a pendulum can be treated as a simple harmonic oscillator, and then explains what affects, as well as what does not affect, the period of a pendulum.

title: The equation of a wave
description: In this video David shows how to determine the equation of a wave, how that equation works, and what the equation represents.

title: Wave interference
description: In this video David explains wave interference and solves a few examples to find the value of the total wave when two wave pulses overlap.

title: Speed of Sound
description: How fast does sound actually travel?

title: Standing waves on strings
description: In this video David explains how and why standing waves occur, and well as how to determine the wavelengths for a standing wave on a string.

title: Standing waves in closed tubes
description: Find out why you can make music by blowing into empty bottles

title: Irregular plural nouns – the MUTANT PLURALS
description: English has seven words that behave very strangely when you change them from the singular to the plural. These are called THE MUTANT PLURALS of English. They're super cool.

title: Irregular plural nouns – foreign plurals
description: You don't need to know how to speak Latin and Greek in order to understand English, but some words in English come from those languages. It's helpful to know how some Greek and Latin words change from singular to plural.

title: Irregular plural nouns – base plurals
description: Some nouns look the same whether they're singular or plural – these nouns are called "base plurals", and we'll demonstrate how they behave the only way I know how... by using sheep!

title: Irregular plural nouns – words that end in -en
description: The plural of "whale" is "whales", but what's the plural of "child"? David, Khan Academy's resident grammarian, explains.

title: Irregular plural nouns – -f to -ves
description: The plural of "dog" is "dogs", but what is the plural of "leaf"? Khan Academy's resident grammarian explains.

title: Adding 3-digit numbers (no regrouping)
description: Sal adds 327 + 251 thinking about place value.

title: Adding 1s, 10s, and 100s
description: Sal adds 3-digit numbers by adding ones, tens, and hundreds.

title: Adding fractions with different signs
description: Use a number line to add fractions with different signs.

title: Adding & subtracting fractions
description: Add and subtract negative fractions with unlike denominators.

title: Solving exponential equations using exponent properties (advanced)
description: Sal solves equations like 32^(x/3) = 8^(x-12) and 5^(4x+3) / 25^(9-x) = 5^(2x+5).

title: Probability models example: frozen yogurt
description: Model the probability of a frozen yogurt line having 0, 1, or 2 people in it.

title: Using the Pythagorean trig identity
description: Given that sin(θ)=1/2 and that θ is in the second quadrant, Sal finds tan(θ) using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Recursive formulas for arithmetic sequences
description: Sal finds the recursive formula of the arithmetic sequence 4, 3⅘, 3⅗, 3⅖,...

title: Using similar & congruent triangles
description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Order of operations example
description: Simplify this tricky expression using the order of operations.   Expression include negative numbers and exponents.

title: Intro to order of operations
description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Worked example: Order of operations (PEMDAS)
description: Work through a challenging order of operations example with only positive numbers.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio.

title: Dividing line segments: graphical
description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Solving quadratics using structure
description: Sal solves (2x-3)^2=4x-6 by substituting p for 2x-3 and obtaining the simpler equation p^2=2p.

title: Graphing exponential growth & decay
description: Graphing the exponential functions y=27⋅(⅓)ˣ and y=-30⋅2ˣ.

title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof
description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Negative symbol as opposite
description: Sal explains more challenging opposites like -(-3).

title: Number opposites challenge problems
description: Sal solves a few challenging problems with number opposites on the number line.

title: Worked example: evaluating expressions using structure (more examples)
description: A few more examples where Sal evaluates expressions with multiple unknown variables.

title: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
description: Learn how to read and understand graphs of proportional relationships

title: Inequality word problem: one variable
description: This time we're creating a variable to represent a number, and then writing an inequality. We're building on our knowledge.

title: Greater than and less than symbols
description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So, 9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are > (greater than or equal to) and < (less than or equal to).

title: Inequality word problems
description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems.

title: Plotting inequalities
description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (> or <), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Graphing systems of inequalities
description: Sal graphs the solution set of the system "y≥2x+1 and y<2x-5 and x>1."

title: Telescoping series
description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video, we use partial fraction decomposition to find sum of telescoping series.

title: Divergent telescoping series
description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video we take a close look at the series 1-1+1-1+1-...

title: Sum of n squares (part 1)
description: What is the sum of the first n squares, 1 + 4 + 9 + 16 + ... + n²? In this video we begin the journey towards finding a formula for this sum.

title: Sum of n squares (part 2)
description: What is the sum of the first n squares, 1 + 4 + 9 + 16 + ... + n²? In this video we find one possible formula for this sum.

title: Sum of n squares (part 3)
description: The sum of the first n squares, 1 + 4 + 9 + 16 + ... + n², is given by the formula ⅙n(n+1)(2n+1). In this video we factor and rewrite the formula that we found in the previous video and obtain the common formula given above.

title: Worked example: evaluating series (advanced)
description: Using properties of sigma notation to rewrite an elaborate sum as a combination of simpler sums, which we know the formula for.

title: Multiplying binomials intro
description: Sal expresses (x-4)(x+7) as the standard trinomial x²+3x-28 and discusses how the general product (x+a)(x+b) can be written as x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Simplifying square-root expressions
description: Worked examples of taking expressions with square roots and taking all of the perfect squares out of the square roots. For example, 2√(7x)⋅3√(14x²) can be written as 42x√(2x).

title: Increasing, decreasing, positive or negative intervals
description: Function values can be positive or negative, and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Normal distribution problem: z-scores (from ck12.org)
description: Z-score practice

title: More empirical rule and z-score practice (from ck12.org)
description: More Empirical Rule and Z-score practice

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Average rate of change word problem: table
description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit, over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video, we compare the average rate of change of temperature over different time periods.

title: Average rate of change word problem: graph
description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit, over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video, we find the average rate of descent of a skydiver over a specific time interval.

title: Rewriting roots as rational exponents
description: Sal solves several problems about the equivalence of expressions with roots and rational exponents. For example, rewrite ⁶√(g⁵) as g^⅚.

title: Fraction word problem: spider eyes
description: Sal solves a fraction word problem about spider eyes.  The fractions have common denominators.

title: Fraction word problem: piano
description: Sal solves a fraction word problem about practicing piano.  The fractions have common denominators.

title: Fraction word problem: lizard
description: Sal solves a fraction word problem about the length of a lizard.  The fractions have common denominators.

title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials
description: Sal multiplies -4x² by (3x² + 25x - 7).

title: Getting data from expected value
description: Sal finds two missing frequencies given the total frequency and the expected value.

title: Probability of a compound event
description: Learn how to use sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

title: Compound events example with tree diagram
description: Sal figures out the probability of flipping three coins and getting at least two tails.

title: Compound events example using diagram (mistake in video)
description: Sal uses a diagram to find the probability of rolling a four-sided die and a six-sided die and not getting a 1.

title: Writing proportions example
description: Some examples of writing two ratios and setting them equal to each other to solve proportion word problems.

title: Buffer solution pH calculations
description: Example of calculating the pH of a buffer solution using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, including the pH of the buffer solution after adding some NaOH.

title: Buffers and Henderson-Hasselbalch
description: Getting an intuitive understanding of buffers using le Chatelier's principle. Derivation of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

title: pH and pKa relationship for buffers
description: How the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation can be used to look at the ratio of conjugate acid and base using relationship between buffer pH and pKa.

title: Addition & subtraction: find the missing value (part 1 of 2)
description: Sal solves some missing value problems: -1 = 7 - __ and -10 + __ = -5 and 4 = -2 + __ and 6 + __ = -8

title: Addition & subtraction: find the missing value (part 2 of 2)
description: Sal solves more missing value problems: 4 = -8 - __  and  __ - (-2) = -7  and  -4 = __ - 9

title: Multiplying monomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Oxidation state trends in periodic table
description: Trends in common oxidation states for main group elements.

title: Practice determining oxidation states
description: Determining oxidation numbers in magnesium oxide and magnesium hydroxide.

title: Introduction to redox reactions
description: Finding the half reactions in a combustion reaction, and identifying what is getting oxidized and reduced.

title: Redox reaction with iron
description: For the reaction between Fe and HCl, identifying the half reactions and what is getting oxidized and reduced.

title: Time differences example
description: Learn to find the difference between the times shown on two different analog clocks.

title: DNA replication and RNA transcription and translation
description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

title: Bacteria
description: Introduction to bacteria.

title: Simple Aspect
description: Verb aspect allows a speaker to give even more information about when an event took place or is going to take place. The simple aspect of a verb is the same as its past, present, and future tenses, such as "I walked," "I walk," and "I will walk."

title: Simple and compound sentences
description: A simple sentence contains one independent clause. A compound sentence contains more than one! Put another way: a simple sentence contains a subject and a predicate, but a compound sentence contains more than one subject and more than one predicate.

title: Modeling with one-step equations
description: Learn how to write basic equations to model real-world situations.

title: One-step equations word problem: super yoga (1 of 2)
description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: One-step equations word problem: super yoga (2 of 2)
description: If you're coming to this video before seeing the previous one, back up! Otherwise, we're solving one-step equations to learn which Super Plan is the best value for our budget.

title: Biology overview
description: Overview of biology, the study of life.

title: The scientific method
description: How the scientific method is used to ask questions and test explanations.

title: Time word problem: Susan's break
description: Sal solves a time word problem and involves converting hours and minutes.

title: Measurement word problem: tea party
description: Sal solves a metric volume word problem involving milliliters and liters.

title: Techniques for generating a simple random sample
description: Techniques for generating a simple random sample

title: Dividing whole numbers by fractions: word problem
description: Learn to solve a word problem that involves dividing a whole number by a unit fraction.

title: Dividing whole numbers & fractions: t-shirts
description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Finding mistakes in one-step equations
description: Learn how to spot mistakes in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

title: Weak base equilibrium
description: Quick overview of Kb and pKb. Examples of calculating the pH of a weak base solution.

title: Ka and acid strength
description: How to write an equilibrium expression for an acid-base reaction and how to evaluate the strength of an acid using Ka

title: Weak acid equilibrium
description: Quick overview of Ka and pKa. Example of calculating the pH of a weak acid solution.

title: Multiplying with area model: 78 x 65
description: Sal uses an area model to multiply 78x65.

title: Multiplying with area model: 16 x 27
description: Sal uses an area model to multiply 16x27.

title: Multiplying with distributive property
description: Sal uses the distributive property to multiply 87x63.

title: Rates with fractions
description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.

title: Definition of pH
description: Introduction to pH and the pH scale. Examples of calculating pH of pure water, bleach, and orange juice.

title: pH, pOH of strong acids and bases
description: Deriving the relationship between pKw, pH, and pOH. Calculating the pH or pOH of strong acids and bases.

title: Bronsted-Lowry definition of acids and bases
description: Bronsted-Lowry definition of acids and bases. Conjugate acids and bases.

title: Conjugate acids and bases
description: Introduction to conjugate acids and bases

title: Adding decimals with ones and tenths parts
description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to add decimals, such as 4+5.7.

title: Introduction to adding decimals: tenths
description: Sal adds tenths, like 0.1+0.8 using visuals and place value.

title: What is a pronoun?
description: Pronouns are words that can replace nouns, like the way "it" replaces "elephant" in "I looked at the elephant. It was grey."

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Mean, median, & mode example
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Interpreting linear expressions: diamonds
description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

title: Interpreting linear expressions: flowers
description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.

title: Comparing multi-digit numbers
description: Lindsay compares multi-digit numbers such as 350,000 and 53,000.

title: Weak base equilibrium
description: Quick overview of Kb and pKb. Examples of calculating the pH of a weak base solution.

title: pH of salt solutions
description: The pH of a salt solution is determined by the relative strength of its ​conjugated acid-base pair. Salts can be acidic, neutral, or basic. Salts that form from a strong acid and a weak base are acid salts, like ammonium chloride (NH4Cl). Salts that form from a weak acid and a strong base are basic salts, like sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3).

title: Acid-base properties of salts
description: Examples of different kinds of neutralization reactions, and analyzing the pH of the resulting salt solution.

title: Expression value intuition
description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x, 5/x + 5, and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Limiting reactant example problem 1
description: A limiting reagent problem to calculate mass of product and mass of excess reactant leftover after reaction.

title: Stoichiometry: Limiting reagent
description: Stoichiometry problem where we find the limiting reagent and calculate grams of product formed.

title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals
description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

title: One-step division equations
description: Let's ease into this, shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: One-step multiplication equations
description: Remember that what you do to one side, you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction, x/a? Let's do it together.

title: Stoichiometry example problem 1
description: Figuring out grams of reactants and product produced from reaction of phosphorous and chlorine.

title: Stoichiometry example problem 2
description: Calculating mass of oxygen needed and grams of product formed from the combustion of 25.0 g of glucose.

title: Stoichiometry
description: Stoichiometry expresses the quantitative relationship between reactants and products in a chemical equation. Stoichiometric coefficients in a balanced equation indicate molar ratios in that reaction. Stoichiometry allows us to predict certain values, such as the percent yield of a product or the molar mass of a gas.

title: Find measure of vertical angles
description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles, watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.

title: Find measure of angles word problem
description: Solve this word problem to find the measure of angles. In this example you'll split up a pie (don't forget to share!)

title: Equation practice with supplementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Equation practice with complementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Overview of cell signaling
description: Overview of cell signaling. Autocrine, paracrine and endocrine signaling.

title: Example of a signal transduction pathway
description: Illustrating the complexity of signal transduction with a MAPK pathway. How mutations in the pathway are linked to cancer.

title: Cell signaling in yeast reproduction
description: Yeast can reproduce sexually through a signaling pathway known as the mating factor pathway. In this process, two haploid yeast cells combine to form a diploid cell. Yeast cells secrete a signal molecule called mating factor that attracts them to their mates. Once the mating factor of one yeast binds to the receptor on another yeast, an outgrowth called a "shmoo" forms, which allows the yeast cells to fuse together.

title: Impact on median & mean: increasing an outlier
description: Sal thinks through the effects of modifying a value in a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Impact on median & mean: removing an outlier
description: Sal thinks through the effects of removing a low outlier from a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Meet the preposition
description: Prepositions help show us where things are in space and time.

title: Time word problem: travel time
description: Sal solves what time do you leave if you are traveling 39 minutes and need to be home at 6:15.

title: Time word problem: Susan's break
description: Sal solves a time word problem and involves converting hours and minutes.

title: Counting in pictures
description: Sal counts the number of objects in pictures.

title: Subtracting fractions with like denominators
description: Sal subtracts 8/18-5/18.

title: Ordering negative numbers
description: Sal puts -25, -30, -7, -10, and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Subtracting 2-digit numbers without regrouping 1
description: Sal subtracts 23 from 65 by thinking about tens and ones.

title: Subtracting two-digit numbers without regrouping (example 2)
description: Sal subtracts 31 from 64 by thinking about tens and ones.

title: Identifying tenths on a number line
description: Lindsay identifies a point graphed on a number line.

title: Graphing tenths from 0 to 1
description: Lindsay graphs 0.6 on a number line.

title: Comparing decimal numbers on a number line
description: Sal compares decimals on a number line.

title: Coordinates of a missing vertex
description: Given three of the vertices of a rectangle, can you find the fourth?

title: Dimensions of a rectangle from coordinates
description: Given the vertices of a rectangle, can you find the lengths of the sides?

title: Coordinates of rectangle example
description: Sal solves a challenging problem involving a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane.

title: Constructing a box plot
description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together, shall we?

title: Drawing a trapezoid on the coordinate plane example
description: Watch Sal solve an example problem where he draws an isosceles trapezoid on the coordinate plane.

title: Drawing a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane example
description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Distributive property with variables
description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to algebraic expressions.

title: Common divisibility examples
description: Common Divisibility Examples

title: Decimals & fractions on the number line
description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

title: Adding decimals: 9.087+15.31
description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Adding decimals: 0.822+5.65
description: Sal solves 0.822+5.65 using "standard algorithm".

title: Adding three decimals
description: Sal adds 7.056+605.7+5.67 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)
description: Sal factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b) (example 2)
description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-10) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).

title: More examples of factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)
description: Can't get enough of Sal factoring simple quadratics? Here's a handful of examples just for you!

title: Volume through decomposition
description: Sal finds the volume of an irregular 3D figure by breaking the figure into 2 rectangular prisms and finding the volume of each part.

title: Volume in unit cubes by decomposing shape
description: Find volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side.  Find a missing side length on a rectangular prism when given the volume.

title: Worked example: Rounding decimals to nearest tenth
description: Learn to round 9.564 to the nearest tenth.

title: Creating the largest number
description: Sal arranges digits to make the largest possible number.

title: Reflecting points in the coordinate plane
description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself, but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Developing strategies for multiplying decimals
description: Sal uses place value and equivalent fractions to multiply decimals.

title: Intro to multiplying decimals
description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Modal verbs
description: There's a class of helper verbs known as modals that we use to express a bunch of conditions: we can use them to give advice, make guesses at how necessary or likely something is, make requests of people, and so on. They're super useful.

title: Equivalent expressions
description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

title: Shapes of distributions
description: Some distributions are symmetrical, with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed," with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: Worked example: estimating sin(0.4) using Lagrange error bound
description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating the sine function.

title: Worked example: estimating eˣ using Lagrange error bound
description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating eˣ at x=1.45.

title: Dashes
description: Dashes are like little actors—they can behave like colons, pairs of commas, or parentheses.  Learn how to use them in this video!

title: Introduction to the semicolon
description: Paige introduces a piece of punctuation called the semicolon; this punctuation can link closely related independent clauses together in a sentence.

title: Semicolons and complex lists
description: We use semicolons to punctuate a complex list, which is when list items contain commas. For example, “I visited Paris, France; Paris, Texas; and Paris, Illinois.” Paige explains.

title: Finding a percent
description: Percent means per-hundred.  Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

title: Percent of a whole number
description: There are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages, decimals, and fractions. Watch as Sal finds the percentage of a whole number.

title: Percent word problem: recycling cans
description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

title: Beginnings of life
description: Life and photosynthesis start to thrive in the Archean Eon

title: Origins of life
description: An overview of the question of how life first arose on Earth.

title: Frequency tables & dot plots
description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Mean, median, & mode example
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Area of a triangle on a grid
description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.

title: Area of a quadrilateral on a grid
description: Learn to break up oddly shaped quadrilaterals into shapes where finding the area is more easily determined.

title: Intro to dimensional analysis
description: Sal shows how we can treat units of measurement algebraically, and use these tools in order to convert between different units of the same quantity.

title: Area of trapezoid on the coordinate plane
description: Sal finds the area of a trapezoid using the distance formula and the trapezoid area formula.

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Median & range puzzlers
description: Sal solves an interesting median and range challenge problem.

title: The encomienda system and colonial racism part 1
description: KA's US history intern Becca and US history fellow Kim discuss the emergence of the encomienda system in the Spanish colonies of North America.

title: The Atlantic slave trade and colonial racism part 2
description: US history intern Becca and US history fellow Kim discuss the beginning of the Atlantic slave trade and the emergence of a race-based system of slavery in the Americas.

title: Shifting parabolas
description: The graph of y=(x-k)²+h is the resulting of shifting (or translating) the graph of y=x², k units to the right and h units up. For example, y=(x-3)²-4 is the result of shifting y=x² 3 units to the right and -4 units up, which is the same as 4 units down.

title: Coordinate plane word problem examples
description: In this word problem, we need to plot the ordered pairs and then figure out the difference in the y coodinate between the two. This will give us our answer!

title: Comparing dot plots, histograms, and box plots
description: Sal solves practice problems where he thinks about which data displays would be helpful in which situations.

title: Finding patterns in numbers
description: Sal finds patterns in a sequences of numbers, such as 3, 6, 9, 12...

title: Intro to even and odd numbers
description: Learn about even and odd numbers, how to figure out if a number is even or odd, and what happens when you add them.

title: Marginal distribution and conditional distribution
description: Marginal distribution and conditional distribution

title: Equal parts of circles and rectangles
description: Sal determines if shapes are divided into 2 or 4 equal sections.

title: Statistics intro: Mean, median, & mode
description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Mean, median, & mode example
description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Comparing with multiplication: giraffe
description: Sal solves 2 multiplication comparison word problems.

title: Comparing with multiplication: magic
description: Sal solves a multiplication comparison word problem with Harry Potter characters.

title: Comparing with multiplication: age
description: Sal solves a multiplication comparison word problem.

title: Missing numbers on the number line examples
description: Given a few negative numbers on a number line, let's see if we can determine what negative numbers are elsewhere on the number line.

title: Intro to negative numbers
description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures, you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Time word problem: puzzle
description: Lindsay finds out how long it took to solve a puzzle when given the start and finish time.

title: Time word problem: travel time
description: Sal solves what time do you leave if you are traveling 39 minutes and need to be home at 6:15.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.

title: Ordering decimals 1
description: Sal orders 5 decimals from least to greatest.

title: Ordering decimals 2
description: Sal orders 5 decimals from least to greatest.

title: Common and proper nouns
description: What's the difference between a common noun and a proper noun?

title: Coordinating conjunctions
description: Coordinating conjunctions connect parts of sentences to each other. David explains how.

title: Definite and indefinite articles
description: 'A' and 'an' are the indefinite articles of English; 'the' is the definite article.  David explains what that means!

title: Irregular plural nouns – foreign plurals
description: You don't need to know how to speak Latin and Greek in order to understand English, but some words in English come from those languages. It's helpful to know how some Greek and Latin words change from singular to plural.

title: Acceleration
description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: Airbus A380 take-off time
description: Figuring how long it takes an a380 to take off given a constant acceleration

title: Airbus A380 take-off distance
description: How long of a runway does an A380 need?

title: Le Chatelier's principle
description: Le Chatlier's principle (also known as "Chatelier's principle" or "The Equilibrium Law") states that when a system experiences a disturbance (such as concentration, temperature, or pressure changes), it will respond to restore a new equilibrium state. For example, if more reactants are added to a system, Le Chatlier's principle predicts that the reaction will generate more products to offset the change and restore equilibrium.

title: Introduction to verbs
description: Let's explore what verbs are, and what they do! David, KA's Grammar Fellow, explains.

title: Phrases and clauses
description: A phrase is any collection of words that behaves like a part of speech, like a noun phrase (“my brother Stu”), an adjectival phrase (“in a different shade of blue”), or an adverbial phrase (“with elegance and tact”). A clause is any noun phrase plus a verb; they can be sentences, but they don’t always have to be. You’ll see!

title: Complex sentences
description: Complex sentences are simple sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them. Paige and Rosie explain how to spot them and use them in this video.

title: Compound-complex sentences
description: Compound-complex sentences are compound sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them. Paige and Rosie explain how to spot and use them.

title: Intro to articles
description: Articles—words like the, a, and an—are special adjectives we use to indicate whether a noun is specific or not specific.

title: Appropriate units
description: Examples for determining the appropriate units to use to measure a quantity of interest.

title: Titration introduction
description: Introduction to acid-base titrations using example of titrating 20.0 mL of HCl of unknown concentration with 0.100 M NaOH. Covers indicators, endpoint, equivalence point, and calculating the unknown concentration.

title: Titration roundup
description: Making sure you fully understand titration curves by comparing the initial pH and pH at equivalence point for different types.

title: Titration curves and acid-base indicators
description: Choosing the best indicator for different titrations depending on the pH at the equivalence point.

title: Titration of a weak acid with a strong base
description: Calculating the pH for titration of acetic acid with strong base NaOH before adding any base and at half-equivalence point.

title: Titration of a weak acid with a strong base (continued)
description: Calculating the pH for titration of acetic acid with strong base NaOH at equivalence point and past the equivalence point.

title: Partial derivatives, introduction
description: Partial derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you tweak just one of the variables in its input.

title: Graphical understanding of partial derivatives
description: One of the best ways to think about partial derivatives is by slicing the graph of a multivariable function.

title: Gradient
description: The gradient captures all the partial derivative information of a scalar-valued multivariable function.

title: Gradient and graphs
description: Learn how the gradient can be thought of as pointing in the "direction of steepest ascent". This is a rather important interpretation for the gradient.

title: Gradient and contour maps
description: Gradient vectors always point perpendicular to contour lines.

title: Directional derivative
description: Directional derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you move along some vector in its input space.

title: Directional derivatives and slope
description: The directional derivative can be used to compute the slope of a slice of a graph, but you must be careful to use a unit vector.

title: Scaling & reflecting absolute value functions: graph
description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of an absolute value function from its graph.

title: Scaling & reflecting absolute value functions: equation
description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of an absolute value function from a description of the transformation performed on y=|x|.

title: Personal pronouns
description: Let's meet the personal pronouns!

title: Counting unit squares to find area formula
description: Sal uses unit squares to see why multiplying side-lengths can also find the area of rectangles.

title: Choosing kinematic equations
description: How to set up problems with constant acceleration and choose the best kinematic equation to solve for the target unknown.

title: Airbus A380 take-off distance
description: How long of a runway does an A380 need?

title: Acceleration of aircraft carrier take-off
description: Using what we know about take-off velocity and runway length to determine acceleration

title: Impact velocity from given height
description: Determining how fast something will be traveling upon impact when it is released from a given height

title: Bay of Pigs Invasion
description: The Bay of Pigs Invasion.

title: Cuban Missile Crisis
description: The Cuban Missile Crisis.

title: Vietnam War
description: Overview of the Vietnam War.

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Intro to the Pythagorean theorem 2
description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem example
description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

title: Introduction to the semicolon
description: Paige introduces a piece of punctuation called the semicolon; this punctuation can link closely related independent clauses together in a sentence.

title: Solutions from slope field
description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

title: Worked example: range of solution curve from slope field
description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation. In this example, we analyze the range of a specific solution.

title: Irregular plural nouns – -f to -ves
description: The plural of "dog" is "dogs", but what is the plural of "leaf"? Khan Academy's resident grammarian explains.

title: Dataset individuals and categorical variables
description: An "individual" is Worked example of Khan Academy exercise involving types of variables.

title: Getting to 10 by filling boxes
description: Sal shows how to add two numbers to make 10. He uses 3 + ___ = 10 and 6 + ___ = 10 as examples.

title: Mean value theorem
description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a,b] and differentiable on the open interval (a,b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a,b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a,b]. In other words, the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a,b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a,b].

title: Mean value theorem example: polynomial
description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=x²-6x+8 over the interval [2,5].

title: Comparing numbers on the number line
description: Sal uses number line to compare numbers less than or equal to 10.

title: Subtraction word problem: basketball
description: Sal solves a word problem with the term "fewer".

title: Introduction to the apostrophe
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, introduce a new piece of punctuation: the apostrophe!

title: Fundamentals: Normative and Descriptive Claims
description:
We humans are a chatty bunch--we talk A LOT. But each claim we make can be sorted neatly into one of two categories: it either describes something or it evaluates something (philosophers call these descriptive and normative claims respectively). In this video Kelley illustrates the descriptive/normative distinction, and its importance, with the use of ample examples

Speaker: Kelley Schiffman, Yale University

title: Scaling & reflecting parabolas
description: The graph of y=k⋅x² is the graph of y=x² scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0, it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example, we find the equation of a parabola from its graph.

title: Choosing between its and it’s
description: David and Paige explain the meaning of two English words that look and sound very similar but act very different: _its_ and _it's_.

title: Ordering by length
description: Sal orders 3 objects by length and compares the lengths of 2 objects indirectly by using a third object.

title: Correlative conjunctions
description: Correlative conjunctions work in pairs to connect parts of sentences. David teaches you how they do it!

title: Counting by category
description: Sal categorizes objects then count the number of things in each category.

title: Prepositions of neither space nor time
description: Some prepositions describe relationships between people or things. These prepositions don’t include information about time or space.

title: The idea of division
description: Sal uses an array and understanding of multiplication to divide.

title: Quadratic word problems (vertex form)
description: Given a quadratic function that models the height of an object being launched from a platform, we analyze the function to answer questions like "what is the height of the platform?" or "when does the object reach its maximum height?"

title: Missing numbers in addition and subtraction
description: Sal solves missing number in problems like 73 = ___ + 57.

title: Dependent and independent clauses
description: An independent clause is a sentence that has a subject and a verb and requires no extra information to understand. Dependent clauses, which start with subordinating conjunctions such as "while," "that," or "unless," give background information but cannot stand on their own as sentences.

title: Adjective order
description: Learn about the adjective order of Standard American English and your new favorite memory aid: DOSA-SCOMP.

title: Progressive Aspect
description: We use the progressive aspect to express that a verb action is ongoing, as in "I am eating."

title: Standard of Ur from the Royal Tombs at Ur
description: Standard of Ur, c. 2600-2400 B.C.E., 21.59 x 49.5 x 12 cm (British Museum) Speakers: Dr. Steven Zucker & Dr. Beth Harris

title: Subtracting a 1-digit number with regrouping
description: Sal subtracts 35-8.

title: Intro to fractions
description: Sal divides wholes into equal-sized pieces to create unit fractions.

title: Cutting shapes into equal parts
description: Lindsay figures out if 4 pieces of pie are each equal to 1/4 of the pie.

title: Subtracting 3-digit numbers (no regrouping)
description: Sal shows how to subtract 357-251 with place value.

title: Subtracting 1s, 10s, and 100s
description: Sal subtracts 3-digit numbers by subtracting ones, tens, and hundreds.

title: Apostrophes and plurals
description: There is *one* extremely rare case in which we use apostrophes to make things plural. David and Paige, KA's resident grammarians, discuss this unusual case.

title: More on orbitals and electron configuration
description: How electron configuration is related to orbitals and the structure of the periodic table.

title: Electron configurations for the third and fourth periods
description: How to write the electron configurations for elements in the third and fourth periods of the periodic table. includes using noble gas notation.

title: Electron configuration for d block element
description: Introduces rules for elements in d-block. Goes through example of Fe, and discusses relative reactivity and energy of 4s and 3d electrons.

title: Electron configurations 2
description: Figuring out configurations for the d-block elements

title: Cell size
description: Thinking about the limiting factors of cell size. Focus on volume to surface area ratio.

title: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

title: Endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis
description: Bulk transport: endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis.

title: Exocytosis
description: Introduction to exocytosis!

title: Picture graphs
description: A picture graph, or pictograph, is a graph used to display information that uses images or symbols to represent data. For example, a picture graph displaying ​the amount of points scored by 5 basketball players could use the image of a basketball to represent 2 points and then display a basketball over each player's name for every 2 points she scored

title: Adding 2-digit numbers without regrouping 1
description: Sal adds 71 + 24.

title: Adding 2-digit numbers without regrouping 2
description: Sal adds 23 + 45 thinking about place value.

title: Reading bar graphs: dog bones
description: Sal reads and interprets bar graphs.

title: Adding by making a group of 10
description: Sal adds 5+68 by breaking the 5 into a 2 and a 3.

title: Regrouping to add 1-digit number
description: Sal adds 35 + 6.

title: Intro to place value
description: Sal uses the number 37 to explain why we use a "ones place" and a "tens place" when writing numbers.

title: Addition word problems within 10
description: Sal solves word problems by adding small numbers (numbers 10 or less).

title: Punctuating a list
description: Learn how to use commas to punctuate a written list of people, things, actions, or events.

title: Parallel structure
description: Parallel structure isn’t a set rule, but more of a stylistic choice: it helps sentence elements maintain a pattern. This is a very special episode because it’s Paige’s last video with us as a KA intern! We will miss having Paige as a contributor to the Grammar Team.

title: Marginal distribution and conditional distribution

title: Pronoun-antecedent agreement
description: An antecedent is “the thing that came before”. When you use a pronoun, it’s standing in for a word you used previously—that’s the antecedent. Join us as we demonstrate how to make sure that your pronouns and antecedents match up with one another: that’s called agreement!

title: Intro to line plots
description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Making picture graphs and line plots
description: To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place an Xs over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Perfect Aspect
description: You use the perfect verb aspect to express when an action is completed, like "I have done the dishes."

description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot, ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next, place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set, place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Worked example: interval of convergence
description: The interval of converges of a power series is the interval of input values for which the series converges. To find it, we employ various techniques. See how it's done in this video.

title: Comparing whole numbers
description: Sal compares 394 and 397.

title: Greater than and less than symbols
description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So, 9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are > (greater than or equal to) and < (less than or equal to).

title: Area of a triangle
description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Halves and fourths
description: When a whole is divided into equal size pieces, the pieces are fractions of the whole. If the whole is divided into 2 equal sized pieces, each piece is ​one half of the whole. If the whole is divided into 4 equal sized pieces, each piece is one fourth of the whole.

title: Sodium potassium pump
description: How the the sodium-potassium (Na+/K+) pump works. Its role in establishing resting membrane potentials.

title: Electrochemical gradients and secondary active transport
description: How a cell can use a molecule's electrochemical gradient to power secondary active transport.

title: Uniporters, symporters and antiporters
description: Uniporters, symporters, and antiporters are proteins that are used in ​transport​ of substances across a cell membrane. Uniporters are involved in facilitated diffusion and work by binding to one molecule of substrate at a time to move it along its concentration gradient. Symporters and antiporters are involved in active transport. Antiporters transport molecules in opposite directions, while symporters transport molecules in the same direction.

description:

title: Surface area using a net: triangular prism
description: Learn how to compute the surface area of a triangular prism.

title: Surface area of a cuboid
description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid, add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l), width (w), and height (h) of the prism and use the formula, SA=2lw+2lh+2hw, to find the surface area.

title: Surface area of a box using nets
description: Learn how to find the surface area of cereal box using nets.

title: Irregular plural nouns – base plurals

title: Commas and Adjectives
description: Commas separate adjectives when those adjectives belong to the same category: determiner, opinion, size, age, shape, color, ​origin and material. So two adjectives that are both opinions (a mushy, sticky apple) should have a comma between them, but two adjectives that are an opinion and color (a mushy green apple) should not.
